    Porphyrinoid–Cyclodextrin Assemblies in Biomedical Research: An Update

    • Irene M. Mavridis*
      Irene M. Mavridis
      Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, National Center for Scientific Research “Demokritos”, Patriarchou Gregoriou & 27 Neapoleos Str., Agia Paraskevi, Attiki 15341, Greece
      *I.M.M. Phone: 0030 210 6503793. E-mail: [email protected]
      More by Irene M. Mavridis
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-9176-5604
      •  and 
    • Konstantina Yannakopoulou*
      Konstantina Yannakopoulou
      Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, National Center for Scientific Research “Demokritos”, Patriarchou Gregoriou & 27 Neapoleos Str., Agia Paraskevi, Attiki 15341, Greece
      *K.Y. Phone: 0030 210 6503796. E-mail: [email protected]
      More by Konstantina Yannakopoulou
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-0725-4906
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 7, 3391–3424
    Publication Date (Web):December 6, 2019

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Porphyrinoids, well-known cofactors in fundamental processes of life, have stimulated interest as synthetic models of natural systems and integral components of photodynamic therapy, but their utilization is compromised by self-aggregation in aqueous media. The capacity of cyclodextrins to include hydrophobic molecules in their cavity provides porphyrinoids with a protective environment against oxidation and the ability to disperse efficiently in biological fluids. Moreover, engineered cyclodextrin–porphyrinoid assemblies enhance the photodynamic abilities of porphyrinoids, can carry chemotherapeutics for synergistic modalities, and can be enriched with functions including cell recognition, tissue penetration, and imaging. This Perspective includes synthetic porphyrinoid–cyclodextrin models of proteins participating in fundamental processes, such as enzymatic catalysis, respiration, and electron transfer. In addition, since porphyrinoid–cyclodextrin systems comprise third generation photosensitizers, recent developments for their utilization in photomedicine, that is, multimodal therapy for cancer (e.g., PDT, PTT) and antimicrobial treatment, and eventually in biocompatible therapeutic or diagnostic platforms for next-generation nanomedicine and theranostics are discussed.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cyclodextrins (CDs) are macrocyclic compounds of carbohydrate nature (comprising 6, 7, and 8 α-1,4-connected glucopyranose rings, named α-, β-, and γCDs, respectively (Figure 1), which have the ability to include in their cavity a vast variety of hydrophobic compounds or moieties by forming inclusion complexes.(1) The parent CDs maintain a hollow cone structure (as depicted in Figure 1), especially βCD, due to an intraglucopyranose hydrogen bonding network established at their secondary side as determined by X-ray crystallography.(2) Alkylation of the hydroxyl groups interrupts the H-bonding network and endows the macrocycles with increased aqueous solubility and flexibility mostly manifested with the propensity to become distorted and adopt an optimal structure to engulf particular guest molecules (induced fit). CDs increase not only the aqueous solubility of the enclosed guests but also their physicochemical stability and bioavailability, thus possibly controlling and regulating their release.(3) This advantage is the reason that many applications involve inclusion complexes of modified CDs. Outstanding examples are the sulfobutyl ether-βCD, 2-hydroxypropyl-βCD (HPβCD, Figure 1), as well as the negatively charged γCD derivative octakis[6-deoxy-6-(3-sulfanylpropionic acid)]-γCD that forms an exceptionally strong inclusion complex with the positively charged neuromuscular blockers rocuronium bromide and vecuronium bromide and presently is a clinically used drug for the reversal of general anesthesia, approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the U.S.A.(4)
    More than 100 years since their discovery, over 10000 t of cyclodextrins are produced annually.(3) The increasing use of CDs and their supramolecular assemblies over the years has been achieved by a slow process as a result of tedious research worldwide. The latter has contributed to a good knowledge of their structure, function, and physicochemical properties and has revealed their favorable toxicological profiles.(5) Although the majority of applications of CDs comprise inclusion complexes,(1) including more than 50 pharmaceutical compounds as drug/CD complexes on the market, research on CD derivatives is intense encompassing many scientific fields (chemistry,(6) biology/biochemistry,(7) pharmaceutics,(8) medicine,(9) materials science,(10) analysis,(11) separations(12) and environment(13)). A great part of CD research is dedicated to nanomedicine and biomedical applications highlighting the breadth of opportunities for marketable products. Thus, innovative CD derivatives and constructs synthesized are intended for imaging purposes, novel ways of gene delivery, development of biosensors for diagnosis, tissue engineering, or novel nanomaterials that can serve as clever drug carriers for improved or targeted release, such as nanoparticles, hydrogels, nanosponges, nanofibers, molecular imprints, and combinations of the above ultimately finding their way toward clinical practice.(14)
    Porphyrinoids are very important molecules participating as cofactors in fundamental processes of life, such as respiration, electron transfer, and photosynthesis.(15) The following molecular systems are defined as porphyrinoids (Figure 2): (i) porphyrins, aromatic macrocycles of tetrapyrroles linked by methine groups (meso positions) possessing 22 π electrons of which 18 are involved in conjugation, derivatives of heme, found in hemoglobin, myoglobin, and cytochrome proteins; (ii) chlorins, reduced analogues of porphyrins with 20 π electrons of which 18 are involved in conjugation, as well as bacteriochlorins, reduced chlorins with 18 π electrons all involved in conjugation; (iii) phthalocyanines, tetraaza-derivatives of porphyrins with phenyl groups fused on the β-sites of each pyrrole; (iv) corroles and corrins, porphyrin derivatives lacking one methine linker, the former being aromatic with 20 π electrons (18 involved in conjugation) and NH groups on three pyrroles and the latter being nonaromatic with 12 π electrons and one NH group. A corrin constitutes the core of vitamin B12. The molecules are deeply colored and are characterized by very strong absorption (ε ca. 105) and emission, as well as by metal-coordinating properties and charge transfer capacity.
    Due to their importance, porphyrinoids have stimulated enormous interest as synthetic analogues of natural systems. In contrast to their charged counterparts, neutral porphyrinoid derivatives do not dissolve in water, where they have the tendency to form aggregates above a critical porphyrinoid concentration. Aggregation hampers seriously their function and use in biomedical applications; namely, it reduces their light-absorption ability, quenches their fluorescence, and compromises their photodynamic efficiency severely. Host–guest inclusion complexation provides a convenient way to circumvent this difficulty, because the intervening host molecules can sequester each porphyrinoid molecule and prevent self-aggregation. Cyclodextrins are the ideal macrocycles for the deaggregation task, because they can enclose inside their cavities part or the whole of the porphyrinoid molecule if it carries the appropriate substituents. Porphyrins unsubstituted at the meso-positions (Figure 2) do not form inclusion complexes with CDs.(16) In contrast, when aryl groups are directly attached to the meso porphyrin positions, exceedingly strong inclusion complexes are formed. The first such 2:1 host/guest complex has been reported by Manka and Lawrence(17) between a porphyrin substituted at the four meso-positions by 4-aminopropyloxyphenyl groups and two molecules of 2,6-DMβCD (Figure 1) reaching the porphyrin core via their secondary side and entrapping two meso substituents in a trans fashion. Subsequently, this structure has been repeatedly revealed by NMR spectroscopy(18,19) and established as a regular pattern in all similar systems studied. Kano et al.(16) have reported higher binding (K11 and K21) and rate constants (k1 and k2) for 1:1 and 2:1 sequential complexation steps, respectively, between TMβCD (Figure 1) and negatively charged meso-tetraarylporphyrins than the positively charged counterparts in aqueous ethylene glycol solutions. To better characterize the binding events with several CDs, the custom-made water-soluble anionic porphyrin 1 (Table 1)(20) has been studied by NMR spectroscopy and isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC). Porphyrin 1 is accessible to the CD cavity only from the unsubstituted meso-phenyl group, the remaining three made sufficiently bulky and hydrophilic via carboxyl groups to prevent inclusion. TMβCD forms one of the strongest complex (K11 = 6.9 × 106 M–1, Table 1) due to intermolecular interactions of the secondary OMe groups of the host with the porphyrin core. The complex is so strong that it can be detected by MALDI-TOF MS, in contrast to the much weaker complex formed with βCD (Table 1).
    Table 1. Binding Constants, K, for 1:1 Complexation of 1 with CDs in Phosphate Buffer at pH 7 and 25 °C
    The above have been confirmed by the molecular structures of four inclusion complexes of TMβCD with three porphyrin molecules with different meso-tetraaryl groups and one with a coordinating metal (TPP, Ni-TPP, TCPP, TPyP, Figure 3) determined by X-ray crystallography (Figure 4A for the TPyP/TMβCD complex).(21,22) All structures show that each porphyrin molecule is isolated inside a CD dimer. All four complexes accommodate the porphyrin core between the secondary sides of the hosts, which “cap” two opposite aryl rings. The CD macrocycles are distorted by the different tilting of each glucopyranose moiety with respect to the molecular axis of TMβCD and arise from induced fit, the numerous small movements of the host to accommodate the guest better. The resulting host–guest interactions can be very strong as observed before, when inclusion complex formation with TMβCD and TMαCD(23) led to efficient enantioseparations of the guests. In the case of the TPyP/TMβCD complex several close intermolecular C–H···O contacts (in the range 2.93 to 3.10 Å) are observed between the pyrrole hydrogen atoms and methoxy oxygen atoms at the secondary side of the host. Rotation of the complex by 90° about its axis (Figure 4B) reveals a bending of the CD in order to bring opposite sides of TMβCD closer to the porphyrin core. Further, the enclosed pyridyl rings are very well accommodated inside the cavity forming C–H···O close contacts (in the range 2.80–3.04 Å) between pyridyl hydrogen atoms and host glucosidic oxygen atoms.
    This Perspective deals with the recent progress in porphyrinoid–cyclodextrin inclusion complexes, conjugates, and nanostructured assemblies that demonstrate promising properties for biomedical applications. The knowledge that methylated cyclodextrins, especially TMβCD, have been proven to be extremely capable hosts to form very strong inclusion complexes with meso-aryl-substituted porphyrins has been used to design dependable and specific structural patterns of practically inseparable porphyrinoid–CD pairs for hemoprotein models that have the potential to find applications in the clinic. On the other hand, porphyrinoids and CDs that either form inclusion complexes or are linked covalently to form conjugates or participate in nanoassemblies have been studied extensively in order to develop photosensitizers for photomedicine. The role of CDs in this case is not only to solubilize and protect the porphyrinoid from oxidation but frequently to act as a vehicle to carry additional drugs, targeting moieties, or labels for localization and imaging purposes. The approach adopted herein focuses on the structure-based emerging functionalities of the systems studied. Emphasis is placed on recent literature, but previous studies are also summarized or referred to for the sake of providing the required background regarding the gradual knowledge gained, which has guided the improvements applied to the systems. The reader is referred to an earlier review article(25) for more details on previous literature and to a more recent one(26) for more details for certain of the systems presented herein.

    2. Synthetic Porphyrinoid–Cyclodextrin Biomimetic Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The porphyrinoid moieties of metalloporphyrin proteins participate in a variety of fundamental biological functions, including oxygen transport and storage and enzymatic reactions. The protein part provides the appropriate hydrophobic environment to prevent deleterious porphyrin–porphyrin interactions or the means for transportation inside cells and tissues. The design of synthetic models mimicking these proteins started quite a long time ago with two goals (i) to expand our knowledge of the mechanism of function in life processes and (ii) to develop products for medicinal, pharmaceutical, food, and agrochemical interest. The already described tendency of porphyrinoids to form strong inclusion complexes by encapsulation into one or two cyclodextrin macrocycles provides features of biomimetic actions similar to those of the protein matrix as solubilization in aqueous media and isolation of the porphyrin molecules inside a hydrophobic environment, thus enhancing their light absorption and emission properties. The recent literature contains characteristic examples of covalently linked porphyrinoid–CD conjugates and porphyrinoid/CD inclusion complexes as biomimetic systems.

    2.1. Enzyme Models for Chemical Substrates

    R. Breslow has been a pioneer in the development of cyclodextrin-based artificial enzymes mimicking the function of natural enzymes.(27,28) A representative example among the enzyme mimics developed by his group is Mn-porphyrin−βCD conjugate 2,(29) a synthetic model of cytochrome P-450 that catalyzes the oxidation of various compounds, namely hydroxylation of alkanes, epoxidation of alkenes, and oxidation of DNA. Compound 2 catalyzes regio- and stereospecifically the hydroxylation of a saturated carbon atom of suitably modified steroids, such as 3. Key features of substrate 3 are the two t-butylphenyl moieties that warrant inclusion into two opposite βCD moieties, thus stretching the substrate across the face of the metalloporphyrin catalyst 2 and creating the environment for regioselectivity of the reaction.
    A related system is the Zn(II)-TPP−βCD conjugate 4 designed by molecular modeling that mimics β-carotene-15,15′-monooxygenase,(30) which oxidizes only the central (out of nine) E-conjugated double bond in β-carotene. The conjugate forms a supramolecular complex (K = 8.3 × 106 M–1) with β-carotene by enclosure of its two cyclohexenyl end groups in the two βCD cavities with the polyene chain spanning the entire length of the porphyrin and the central double bond positioned close to the Zn(II) ion. Catalytic cleavage experiments, carried out using the Ru(II) analog of 4 in the presence of an oxidant, produces retinal (5) as the major product, along with 12′- and 10′-apocarotenals as byproducts. The latter are generated by eccentric double bond cleavage, in contrast to the natural enzyme, which catalyzes regiospecifically the central bond cleavage of all natural carotenoids. Nonetheless, the reaction mechanism is believed to involve epoxidation as in the natural enzyme. Noticeably, if one of the cyclohexenyl groups of β-carotene is substituted by a phenyl group, exclusive central cleavage is catalyzed by 4 producing only 5. This is explained by the formation of a stronger inclusion complex and stabilization of the substrate position with the central double bond close to the metal ion.
    Along the same lines, the porphyrin–cyclodextrin conjugate 6 has been synthesized recently by the covalent bonding of the Mn(III) coordination complex of Mn(III)-TPP to the primary side of αCD. Conjugate 6 catalyzes the epoxidation of cis-polybutadiene(31) and exhibits preference toward trans-epoxide (72%). In contrast, both the free Mn(III)-TPP and the methylated αCD analog 7 (Mn(III)-TPP–TMαCD) exhibit cis-epoxide preference (ca. 70%) for the same reaction. Induced circular dichroism supports a “folded” (clamp-like) geometry for 6, as opposed to 7, which acquires an extended conformation. Based on quantum semiempirical calculations it has been suggested that an αCD primary hydroxyl group coordinates the Mn(III) ion stabilizing the folded structure 6. This is supported by epoxidation studies indicating a “clamp-like mechanism”, by which the enzyme model captures temporarily the cis-polybutadiene within the restricted space between the αCD torus and the porphyrin lid placing the double bond close to the reaction center, possibly a Mn(V)-oxo species. The remaining five primary hydroxyl groups of αCD act synergistically to keep the required H-bonding with the substrate during the reaction, and they are considered crucial for the observed regioselectivity, explaining the difference with the permethylated analogue 7.

    2.2. Enzyme Models for Biochemical Processes

    Many synthetic models, including anionic porphyrins, have been proposed to mimic receptors of cytochrome c (cyt c), that is, cyt c reductase and oxidase. Cyt c is positively charged (pI = 10.4) and is known to associate with its receptors through electrostatic interactions. In the present example, an anionic host/guest system(32) mimicking cyt c reductase has been prepared based on the knowledge that TMβCD and 2,3-DMβCD (Figure 1) form exceedingly strong ternary 1:2 guest/host inclusion complexes(16,20) with meso-tetraarylporphyrins. Specifically, a water-soluble 1:2 complex is formed between the anionic heptakis(2,3,-di-O-methyl-6-carboxymethyl)-βCD (8) and 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-glucaminocarbonylphenyl)porphyrin (TGPP). The structure of the complex, with the two CD cavities capping trans-ends of TGPP and the primary βCD surfaces each exposing seven anionic carboxymethyl groups, has been determined by NMR spectroscopy and ITC measurements. Addition of cyt c to an aqueous solution of the TGPP/8 complex causes quenching of TGPP fluorescence suggesting proximity and electrostatic interaction of the cyt c heme with TGPP at the primary surface of the TGPP/8 complex. This is verified by using the neutral TMβCD to form the TGPP/TMβCD complex in place of 8, which does not exhibit fluorescence quenching of TGPP upon addition of cyt c. The latter suggests that the protein does not anchor onto the TGPP/TMβCD complex due to lack of electrostatic interaction. In addition, fluorescence quenching studies in aqueous solutions of the TGPP/8 complex demonstrate also that only two-thirds of the cyt c heme shows proximity to the TGPP. This is supported by inhibition studies. The cyclodextrin 8 inhibits the binding between cyt c and cyt c reductase, but inhibition is not complete although it is stronger at high excess of 8. Although the proposed TGPP/8 complex is not entirely successful as a model of cyt c reductase, it is susceptible to optimization due to its supramolecular design.
    Synthetic models have been developed for superoxide dismutase (SOD), an enzyme that protects the organism against oxidative stress damage by catalyzing the dismutation of superoxide radical anion O2•– to O2 and H2O2. Mn-porphyrins have been under clinical evaluation as drugs against oxidative stress, for example, AEOL-10150.(33) The Mn(II) or Mn(III) ions used in the proposed synthetic models mimic the SOD active site of the mitochondrial enzyme, because the Cu and Fe ions found in other SODs are more toxic for the organism.(34) Thus, the SOD activity of conjugate 9synthesized from Mn(III)-pTHPP (Figure 3) and βCD is 15 times higher than that of the free metalloporphyrin. This result has been attributed to the synergistic role of the hydroxyl groups of βCD participating in the catalysis, as well as of the βCD cavity that can enclose radical species and position them close to the Mn(III) catalytic center. Supramolecular porphyrin–CD interactions are used in the bifunctional models 10 and 11 mimicking the active sites of SOD and of glutathione peroxidase (GPx), the antioxidant enzyme that reduces harmful superoxides in the organism by glutathione oxidation. GPx involves the intermediate oxidation of a selenocysteine residue of the enzymatic active site by superoxides. In model 10,(35)the SOD center is a Mn(III)-meso-tetra[1-(1-adamantyl methylketone)-4-pyridyl]porphyrin, which forms inclusion complexes with four βCD derivatives through the adamantyl (ADA) moieties of the porphyrin, an established strong complexation process (K ca. 104 to 105 M–1). The four CD molecules are derivatized at their secondary side by telluric acid moieties functioning as active centers of GPx.(36) This model compares well with respect to other synthetic models exhibiting efficient SOD activity (2.56% of the native SOD) and noticeable GPx efficiency (rate enhancement v0 7.1 μM min–1), 27 times more efficient than the known GPx mimic ebselen. Model 11(37) is a more complex version of 10 differing in that the CD moieties and the 3-hydroxypropyl telluride GPx enzymatic centers are attached separately to the temperature-responsive polymer poly(N-isopropylacrylamide). The host/guest components of 11 self-assemble into a supramolecular “pseudo-block” copolymer in aqueous solution, whose SOD activity is improved and shows its highest GPx catalytic efficiency close to body’s physiological temperature, 35.6 °C.
    The Fe(III) coordination complex of the negatively charged 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin TPPS (Figure 3) has been used as an effector for inhibition of the catalytic activity of chymotrypsin (ChT). Specifically, TPPS shields the ChT active site by interacting electrostatically with the surrounding positively charged arginine and lysine residues and inhibits its action.(38) Addition of TMβCD (repairing agent) entraps Fe(III)-TPPS to form the 1:2 inclusion complex Fe(III)-TPPS/(TMβCD)2 with stronger binding constants (K1 = 1.26 × 106 M–1, K2 = 6.3 × 104 M–1) than the TPPS–ChT assemblies (K = 4.8 × 105 M–1), thus releasing the ChT active site and reestablishing the catalytic activity. However, when Fe(III)-TPPS is tested in the hydrolysis of an amide substrate by ChT only 60% inhibition of the reaction is observed. Furthermore, denaturation of ChT takes place upon incubation with Fe(III)-TPPS, and although TMβCD restores enzymatic function, it does not restore denaturation. If 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-(3,5-dicarboxyphenylmethoxy)phenyl)porphyrin (12) is used as an effector, no denaturation is observed and inhibition is enhanced to 85%. A further development(39) of the effector/repairing system involves diprotonated TPPS (H4TPPS2–) as an effector, which forms J-aggregates in acidic pH. The latter cover the active site of the enzyme and inhibit enzymatic function completely at neutral pH, at which the J-aggregates are stabilized for some time. However, they gradually monomerize, and the enzymatic function is restored completely. TMβCD in neutral solution does not have any effect on the J-aggregates, but it binds the H4TPPS2– monomers and prevents ChT–H4TPPS2– interactions. Nevertheless, this effector is not attractive, because the structure of the enzyme is affected by the aggregates.
    The inclusion complex Fe(III)-TPPS/TMβCD has been tested for improved treatment of soils contaminated by halogenated organic pollutants.(40) Fe(III)-TPPS has been regarded as a synthetic model of the catalytic center of oxidative enzymes (peroxidases, ligninases) in the soil activated by oxygen donors, such as peroxymonosulfuric acid (HSO5–) and H2O2, which function in acidic pHs (4–6). The role of TMβCD is to protect the Fe(III)-TPPS catalyst from destruction by the oxygen donors, much like the protein matrix in the native enzymes. The Fe(III)-TPPS/TMβCD complex has been tested for soil decontamination from tetrabromobisphenol A in the presence of an oxygen donor and humic acids, the main organic components of soil. The study has demonstrated that at pH values 4–5, the optimum range for the natural oxidative enzymes, self-degradation of the Fe(III)-TPPS/TMβCD catalyst is decreased (only 20% within 3 h), whereas the oxidase activity is enhanced and the turnover number is more than doubled compared to the use of free Fe(III)-TPPS. The results indicate that the complex is a suitable model for soil oxidative enzymes at pH 4–5. Cyclodextrin polymers have also been tested as hosts of Fe(III)-TPPS for degradation of the same pollutant.(41) The Fe(III)-TPPS/CD-polymers exhibit promising results as oxidative enzymes, with γCD polymers being superior to the α- or β-homologues in terms of reusability of the catalyst and improved function in the presence of humic acids.

    2.3. Hemoprotein Models

    Hemoglobin (Hb), the protein that transports molecular oxygen (O2) in aerobic organisms, and myoglobin (Mb) that stores O2 in muscle cells have been two of the earliest systems investigated regarding their structure and mechanism of function; thus many synthetic molecular or supramolecular systems able to imitate the performance of these proteins have been designed. Moreover, the interest extends to the real need for transfusion alternatives of blood or blood products in the clinic. Mb, a protein monomer carrying an Fe(II)-heme (protoporphyrin IX or PpIX Figure 10) is coordinated to Fe(II) in the fifth axial (proximal) position by the His93 residue of the protein and binds reversibly O2 at the sixth axial (distal) position close to the distal His64 residue (Figure 5). Hb, a tetramer of α and β Mb-like proteins (two αβ dimers) carrying four hemes with penta-coordinated Fe(II) binds allosterically (cooperatively) four molecules of O2. Allostericity means that the affinity of Hb for O2 depends on the concentration of O2 (measured as partial pressure of O2) and increases with the fraction of O2-bound Hb (oxy-Hb). In contrast, the affinity of Mb for O2 is concentration-independent (noncooperative). Consequently, the curve of the oxy-Hb/Hb ratio as a function of the O2 partial pressure (expressed in % saturation) is sigmoidal, whereas the corresponding curve of Mb is hyperbolic. The mechanism describing how the O2 binding of each Hb monomer influences the behavior and structure of the other monomers has been studied extensively ever since the structures of Hb and Mb became known.(42,43) The onset of events upon binding of O2 is the movement of the Fe(II) ion into the plane of the heme core that triggers the movement of residues at the distal side toward the heme center (Figure 5). This motion is transmitted to the other subunits through the protein matrix and transforms Hb from the high-spin T (tense) to the low-spin R (relax) allosteric state. The equilibrium of the allosteric function depends on how much the shift in the distal site contributes to the stabilization of the αβ dimer–dimer interface of the specific allosteric state.(44) Interactions between heme and the protein residues determine also the affinity of Hb and Mb for binding O2, for example, stabilization of O2 in O2-bound Mb (oxy-Mb) is due to the H-bonding between the side chain of distal His64 with the bound O2 as suggested initially by Pauling and Weiss.(45) Indeed, this early hypothesis has been confirmed directly by the neutron diffraction structure determination of oxy-Mb and oxy-Hb 17 years later.(46)
    The Fe(II)-heme complex in Hb and Mb binds O2, CO, NO, aryl nitroso compounds, and alkyl isocyanides. In contrast, the oxidized Fe(III)-heme (met-heme) of Hb and Mb (met-Hb, met-Mb) does not bind O2 and CO but binds NO and H2S, both considered as signaling molecules, as well as water molecules and the anions CN–, N3–, NO2–, SCN–, and F–. The Mb-bound and Hb-bound Fe(II)-heme has a higher affinity for O2 than for CO (affinity for O2 30–200-fold that for CO). In contrast, free imidazole-penta-coordinated Fe(II)-heme has a higher affinity for CO than for O2 (104- to 105-fold). Thus, the protein surroundings create an environment favoring O2 versus CO binding. This discrimination has been studied extensively, but the precise steric and electrostatic interactions have not been clarified completely.(49) Synthetic models have contributed toward this direction; for example, stabilization of O2 on Mb and Hb has been exhibited by heme models carrying bulky binaphthyl bridges and hydroxyl groups in the distal site forming H-bonds with O2.(50) Moreover, the protein matrix protects heme from autoxidation, that is, oxidation to Fe(III), cleavage of the Fe(III)–O2 bond, and release of superoxide radical anion (O2•–) a deleterious event that must be prevented due to the toxicity of O2•– and the inability of met-heme of met-Mb and met-Hb to bind O2. The autoxidation is slowest at pH 7.5 to 9 and much faster outside this range; however the mechanism is unclear. Hypotheses include nucleophilic attack by a water molecule; thus the protein matrix limits access of nucleophiles in order to retain Fe(II) ion in the reduced state. The fifth ligand is also very important for Hb and Mb stability. It is crucial that these requirements are met in all synthetic systems attempted for artificial blood substitutes. Initial promising models, mainly for Mb, have been penta-coordinated porphyrins called “picket-fence”,(49) in which bulky groups covalently attached to the macrocycle provide a protective environment at the free face that permits binding of O2 and prevents oxidation of Fe(II). Studies of the affinity of an enormous collection of such porphyrins have shown that reversible oxygenation takes place, provided that a hydrophobic hindered pocket is formed in the distal face of heme and the chemical nature of this pocket accounts for preference of O2 vs CO binding. A major disadvantage of these systems is that they function in anhydrous organic solvents, most of them suffering from autoxidation in aqueous solutions, except for some cases where they have been embedded in liposomal environments.(51,52) Further, although some of these synthetic systems achieve reproduction of the Mb function, they fail to reproduce the allosteric O2 binding of Hb.
    Supramolecular assemblies comprising porphyrinoid–CD assemblies have emerged as more promising systems. Such an interesting assembly (13) comprises the meso-tetrakis[o-(N-methyl)pyridinium]porphyrinato-Fe(II) coordinated in one axial site by 2-methyl-1-phenethylimidazole included in the cavity of αCD.(53) The assembly is soluble in a water/DMF (2/3, v/v) mixture and binds O2 reversibly on the second axial site depending on the partial pressure of O2, as detected by UV–vis spectroscopy. It is hypothesized that the four positive charges on the pyridinium substituents prevent attack to the O2 by nucleophiles or protons; however Fe(II) is oxidized slowly (half-life ∼40 min at 5 °C) to the Fe(III)OH complex. In the presence of CO, the Fe(II)–O2 complex is converted to the very stable Fe(II)–CO analogue as in the case of Hb and Mb. A more sophisticated model (14) demonstrates better characteristics.(54) It is formed by the negatively charged Fe(II)-TPPS and βCD derivatized by a single 2-pyridylmethyl group on the secondary side and by poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) in all remaining hydroxyl positions. Fe(II)-TPPS is enclosed in the secondary face of CD, where the methylpyridine group is located serving as its proximal ligand in the protective “binding pocket” created by the PEG environment. The assembly forms a ferrous Fe(II)–O2 adduct in phosphate buffer, which oxidizes slowly (several hours) to the ferric form. Upon flushing with CO, the Fe(II)–O2 adduct is converted to the corresponding Fe(II)–CO adduct, which autoxidizes even more slowly (stable for 2 days). Better results are obtained by host/guest βCD/Fe(III)-TPPS inclusion complexes (Figure 6) entrapped in the hydrophobic domains of the diblock copolymer PEG–poly(4-vinylpyridine-co-N-heptyl-4-vinylpyridine), which forms micelles in aqueous solutions.(55) Following reduction of Fe(III) to Fe(II), the βCD/Fe(II)-TPPS complexes bind O2 reversibly, as confirmed by several successive O2/N2 flashings. The Fe(II) ion in the complex is quite stable (half-life 8.3 h) at pH 7.4. The pyridine groups hanging from the polymer backbone serve as proximal ligands for Fe(II), and the polymer hydrophobic domains prevent nucleophilic attack thus protecting the distal position and assisting in the stability of the O2 adduct.
    The dimer of two TMβCD derivatives linked by a pyridyl (Figure 7) or imidazolyl moiety is a more robust CD system of high aqueous solubility that forms very stable inclusion complexes with aryl-substituted porphyrins (Ka ca. 106 to 108 M–1). Although the idea of dimers has been suggested earlier,(56) it has been developed further by Kano et al., who have synthesized numerous such dimers linking the TMβCDs mostly by pyridine in a variety of ways via positions 2 or 3 of the secondary hydroxyl groups.(57,58) Fe(II)-TPPS enclosed in such a dimer is a very effective hemoprotein model, the pyridyl or imidazolyl linker being the proximal fifth ligand to the central Fe(II) ion. The synthesized models have been tested for O2 reversible binding and their respective affinities are compared by measuring the partial pressure of O2 for acquiring 50% saturation (P1/2O2) in phosphate buffer at pH 7.0 and 25 °C. The synthesized complexes exhibit P1/2O2 values ranging from 1.5 to 176 Torr, values corresponding to high and low affinity toward O2, respectively.(59) Following extensive studies, the inclusion complexes, hemoCD1, hemoCD2, and hemoCD3 comprising Fe(II)-TPPS embedded in the cavity of the pyridine-linked CD dimers Py3SCD, Py2OCD, and Py3OCD, respectively (Figure 7) have the optimal characteristics as model systems for Mb and Hb.(57,58) The three hemoCDs bind reversibly O2, CO, and NO in their ferrous states and CN–, HS–, and N3– in their oxidized ferric states (met-hemoCDs).(59,61) Their binding affinities (P1/2O2 and P1/2CO values) and half-lifetimes (t1/2O2) are shown in Table 2. HemoCD3 has the optimum affinity for O2 binding, because the complex is very stable, its lifetime (t1/2O2 = 53 h at pH 7) being the closest to human Hb, although its affinity (P1/2O2 = 18 Torr) is not as high as that of hemoCD1 (P1/2O2 = 10 Torr). Hoping to improve further the O2 binding ability and stabilization, hemoCD1 has been covalently connected to poly(acrylic acid), and indeed the system binds O2, but it suffers quick autoxidation.(62) A more promising attempt that prolongs the circulation time of the hemoCD1 system in the bloodstream(63,64) is achieved via modification of the porphyrin core by covalent attachment of various PEG moieties of moderate sizes. The modification causes increased O2 binding at pH 7.4 and 25 °C and does not show enhanced autoxidation compared to the unmodified system. Furthermore, the circulation time of the modified hemoCD1 complex in the bloodstream of rats is possible to be controlled by varying the length of the PEG chain, since longer PEG chains are retained for a longer period of time.
    Table 2. Binding Affinities of HemoCD Models and Human Hb for O2 and CO and the Corresponding Half-Lives in Aqueous Phosphate Buffer at 25 °C
     P1/2O2 (Torr)P1/2CO (Torr)t1/2O2 (h)
    hemoCD1(65)100.01530
    hemoCD2(65)17616>100
    hemoCD3(65)180.5653
    R8-hemoCD1(66) (pH 7.4, 37 °C)210.0017.5
    human Hb (R state)0.221.4>60
    Since hemoCD3 has not been crystallized so far, the complex of Fe(III)-pTHPP included in the Py3OCD dimer has been determined by X-ray crystallography (Figure 8).(60) The structure justifies the proposed models as biomimetic of Mb and Hb. The two CDs create the crucial hydrophobic environment around the Fe(III) center. The pyridine linker coordinating Fe(III) (proximal pyridine) is aligned with respect to the porphyrin as the proximal ligand in Mb. The O2 location at the “distal” position is occupied by a water molecule in this case.
    The oxidized met-hemoCD3 can very quickly capture CN– (binding rate konCN– = 736 M–1 s–1).(67) Fast kinetics of CN– binding (kon) is very important for a compound in order to be used against acute poisoning by CN–. This synthetic system is quicker than Hb (konCN– = 320 M–1 s–1) and superior to hydroxocobalamin (konCN– = 81.5 M–1 s–1), which is used for depleting CN– in the blood. Moreover, unlike hydroxocobalamin, it does not interfere with serum proteins in the bloodstream. Met-hemoCD3 has been tested in vivo for its effectiveness as a cyanide antidote. Following infusion of a PBS solution of NaCN in male Wistar rats and termination of respiration (at about 12 min), the rats were revived upon injection of met-hemoCD3, whereas untreated rats died after respiration stopped. Therefore, a very efficient cyanide antidote can be made from an easily synthesized CD dimer and a commercially available anionic porphyrin.
    It has been found that human blood contains 1.2% ± 0.3% CO as a CO-bound Hb (CO-Hb). CO is generated endogenously in mammalian organisms by the degradation of aged hemoproteins.(68,69) As stated above, the three derivatives, hemoCD1–3 display affinity not only for O2 but also for CO, just as the Mb and Hb proteins. In contrast to the latter, CO binding values at half saturation (P1/2CO) of hemoCD1 and hemoCD3 are lower than those for O2 (P1/2O2) (Table 2) meaning that their affinities for CO are higher than for O2, especially hemoCD1 that has the highest affinity, much higher than that of Hb. The reason might be that the synthetic analogs have pyridine as proximal ligand, as opposed to the proximal His93 in Hb and Mb and that the pyridine plays a stabilizing role for the CO complex. Moreover, hemoCD1 has the additional advantage of not exhibiting any toxicity and not binding NO. Therefore, when hemoCD1 is introduced by vein injection in the blood of rats, it binds all endogenous CO generated in the organism during its 30 min circulation in the blood and before excretion in the urine as the CO-adduct.(65) The above properties could make hemoCD1 useful in removing high concentrations of CO in the blood of human organisms, if its concentration is high. CO toxicity is caused by the formation of the stable CO-Hb, which reduces the amount of Hb available to carry oxygen and generates hypoxia in the red blood cells. HemoCD1 has been used to develop a photometric assay for the determination of CO in cell lysates. Thus, it has been determined that the amount of CO produced endogenously in the blood of untreated mice is (2.2 ± 0.2) × 10–8 mol, almost half of which (42% ± 4%) is in the blood plasma ((9.2 ± 0.6) × 10–9 mol).(65) Furthermore, a refined model for CO depletion based on hemoCD1 has been synthesized in order to penetrate cells.(66) It is well-known that successive lysine or arginine moieties in peptides(70) or cyclodextrins(71) facilitate cell penetration. Thus, hemoCD1 has been doubly modified by attaching an arginine-octapeptide-Cys extension to one of the phenyl groups of TPPS to give R8-TPPS,(66) which has been included in the Py3SCD dimer to form a mixture of the 5,15- and 10,20-complexes (R8-hemoCD1). The latter mixture reversibly binds O2 and CO (P1/2O2 = 21 Torr and P1/2CO = 1.3 × 10–3 Torr at pH 7.4 and 37 °C, respectively) with affinities close to the parent hemoCD1 but with decreased stability (Table 2), since the half-life for auto-oxidation is 7.5 h versus 27 h for hemoCD1. The mixture of the R8-hemoCD1 complexes removes entirely the CO from the interior of HeLa cells.
    Depletion of CO from blood is presently studied in animals or cells with knockdown activity of heme oxygenase enzymes; however depletion has side effects, since it results in accumulation of heme in the organism. Therefore, use of the hemoCDs for CO depletion eliminates these side effects, as well as the need for genetic manipulation of cells or organisms. The approach based on hemoCD1 has been utilized to show that the physiological role of the endogenous CO in the organism is to maintain the steady state between Hb (Fe(II)) and met-Hb (Fe(III)), since depletion of CO from CO-Hb by hemoCD1 activates heme oxygenase that induces endogenous production of CO in mice.(65) The starting point is oxy-Hb, which is maintained in the reduced form inside the red blood cells but leaks to the blood plasma when the cells age. In plasma, oxy-Hb is oxidized readily to met-Hb by reactive oxygen species (ROS), it is further degraded to hemin (ferric chloride heme), then to apo-Hb, and subsequently it is metabolized by heme oxygenase enzymes to produce CO. In contrast, the above process is much slower for CO-Hb in the red blood cells, as well as in the plasma. Depletion of CO from CO-Hb in the plasma (by hemoCD1 that cannot enter the red blood cells) accelerates oxidation and degradation of Hb, thus causing increase in hemin concentration, which consequently induces activation of the oxygenases for subsequent metabolism and CO generation. The newly generated CO reacts with Fe(II) oxy-Hb to form the more stable Fe(II) CO-Hb that keeps the homeostatic balance between reduced/oxidized Hb.(65) Thus, the artificial CO-binding systems hemoCDs have facilitated the elucidation of the mechanism for the endogenous protective role of CO in cells; therefore they have the potential to be exploited for the study of other possible regulator functions. Indeed this system has been utilized already in biochemical research: administration of hemoCD1 in mice led to elucidation of the role of CO in the mammalian circadian clock mechanism.(72) Temporary reduction (3 h) of endogenous CO in mice by hemoCD1 affects the clock genes disrupting the circadian rhythm and inducing inflammatory side effects.

    2.4. A Cytochrome c Oxidase Model Based on the HemoCD System

    Cyt c oxidase (CcO) participates in aerobic respiration of many organisms from bacteria to humans catalyzing reduction of molecular O2 to water by coupling the four electrons of the oxygen reduction with proton transfer (4e–/4H+): O2 + 4e– + 4H+ = 2H2O. The enzyme contains two iron–copper centers: (i) the catalytic O2-reducing center (hemea3/CuB) and (ii) the low potential center (hemea/CuA). In both centers, the iron cation is coordinated by heme and the copper cation by side chains of the enzyme’s amino acids (Figure 9A).(73) The simplified catalytic mechanism is shown in (Figure 9B).(74,75) Molecular O2 binds to the fully reduced active site Fea3(II)/CuB(I) (R) to form the detectable intermediate A (Fea3(III)–O2–/Cu(I)). The distance between the two metal ions is close to 5 Å depending on the residues of the protein matrix coordinating the cuprous cation. It has been suggested that the O2 bound to Fea3(III) approaches closely CuB(I) (ca. 2 Å), which facilitates the three electron donation to O2 in the reduction process (vide infra). Species A decays rapidly to the intermediate P (Fe(IV)═O2–/Cu(II)OH–) by O–O bond cleavage and proton transfer from the neighboring Tyr244 residue. Thus, O2 has received four electrons (two from the ferrous ion, one from the copper ion, and one from Tyr244). Up to this stage, Fea3 is bound to O2– and CuB to an OH– group. Subsequently, four electron equivalents with concomitant pumping of four proton equivalents, one at a time, are transferred into the system by cyt c through the low potential hemea/CuA center, and by intermediates F, O, and E, the catalytic centers return to the initial state R.
    Extensive studies involving synthetic, computational, and spectroscopic/electrochemical approaches have been dedicated to develop heme/copper-ligand models for CcOs in order to elucidate structures, reactivity, and mechanisms of action.(76) The synthetic systems comprise a large variety of coordination complexes differing by the ligands of the Fe/Cu metal ions. These complexes have served the need for reproducibility because they function with steady-state catalytic turnover,(49,77) and they have enabled the elucidation of some aspects of the mechanism of action up to now, that is, the Cu tridentate complex in the Fea3/CuB center and the importance of Tyr244 hydroxyl group. However, many issues remain still unresolved. The models used so far are tetraarylporphyrinatoiron(II)-cuprous(I) coordination complexes with three or four nitrogen donating ligands (Ln) on copper (PFe(II)/Cu(I)Ln). These models function mainly in anhydrous organic solvents, and upon oxygenation of Fe(II) (R state), they form covalent μ-peroxo (PFe(III)–O2–Cu(II)Ln) structures instead of the superoxo A species (Figure 9B). Since localized water molecules identified in the enzymatic site of native structures have been implicated in the mechanism, it has been proposed that the absence of water molecules in the synthetic models is an important missing factor. However, the only synthetic models of CcO performing in aqueous solution have been constructed in the heme pocket of myoglobin.(78,79) Recently, Kano et al. have proposed a water-soluble supramolecular model (15) mimicking the CcO reducing center (Fea3(II)/CuB(I)),(80) which is similar to the hemoCD system used for Hb and Mb. It comprises Fe(III)-TPPS and two TMβCD molecules covalently associated by a terpyridine linker appropriate for coordination of the Cu(I) center. The oxidized bimetallic complex Fe(III)/Cu(I)-15 is reduced in O2-free aqueous solution (PBS, pH 7, 25 °C) to the Fe(II)/Cu(I)-15 complex corresponding to the R state (Figure 9B). The latter binds O2 and forms the superoxo complex Fe(III)–O2–/Cu(I)-15, a bimetallic water-soluble system that behaves as the intermediate A of the native CcO cycle, that is, O2 is exchanged by CO, if eluted with CO gas. However, the superoxo complex oxidizes eventually to the μ-hydroxo Fe(III)–(OH)/Cu(II)/15 complex, the oxidation rate depending on the pH as confirmed by EPR and Raman studies. The authors suggest that the assembly Fe(II)/Cu(I)/15 has the potential to contribute to the elucidation of the CcO reaction mechanism, because of its solubility in aqueous media.

    3. Porphyrinoid–Cyclodextrin Systems in Phototherapy Modalities

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. Photodynamic Therapy (PDT)

    The therapeutic role of light has been known for three thousand years, as ancient populations have used sun light to treat a variety of diseases mainly dermatologic and ophthalmic. Modern photodynamic therapy (PDT) was developed at the beginning of the 20th century, after the observation that combination of light with certain chemicals can be effective for medical treatment.(81) However, only in the 1980s and 1990s has photodynamic therapy gained momentum as a minimally invasive approach for the treatment of cancerous tumors and other diseases (psoriasis, microbial infections) after the first clinical trials. Today, PDT is approved by the FDA for the treatment of early malignant or premalignant cases including the skin, oral cavity, stomach, bladder, and breast cancers, as well as in endobronchial and endoesophageal cancer.(82) Cornerstones for the method are photosensitizers (PSs), compounds (including porphyrinoid macrocycles, Figures 2 and 10) that generate singlet oxygen or other radicals when illuminated by light of certain wavelength (λ). When ideally designed PSs reach affected and compromised tissues and subsequently are subjected to illumination restricted in the tumor area, damage is conferred by the toxic radicals, while the nonirradiated surrounding tissues are left unharmed. The destruction of the tissues starts by the irradiation-triggered excitation of the PS(82) from its ground state (singlet) to the short-lived (nanoseconds) excited singlet state, which loses its energy by light emission (fluorescence) or by conversion to heat. Alternatively, the excited singlet state can be converted to the long-lived (microseconds to milliseconds) excited triplet state by intersystem crossing. Thereon, the process continues mainly by two mechanisms, that occur simultaneously, depending on the nature of the PS, and produce ROS. In the type I mechanism, the excited triplet state of the PS abstracts an electron from an organic molecule of the cellular microenvironment to form a radical anion (PS•–), which in turn interacts with endogenous molecular oxygen (O2) to produce the mildly oxidizing superoxide radical anion (O2•–). The latter generates the stronger oxidizing species hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and O2 by a self-redox reaction. H2O2 finally gives the highly drastic hydroxyl radical HO•. Alternatively, O2•– may react with nitric oxide (NO) to give the peroxynitrite anion (OONO–), also a highly reactive species (NROS). In the type II mechanism, energy transfer takes place between the excited triplet state of the PS to the ground state of O2 (a triplet state), generating the excited singlet state of molecular oxygen (1O2) or “singlet oxygen”, a highly deleterious species.(83) In the absence of O2, a type III mechanism may occur by the reaction of the PS’s excited triplet state with a biomolecule in the cell environment resulting in their mutual destruction. The characterization of ROS and their reactivity is extremely important in PDT. For this purpose, molecules called primary acceptors are used, which react selectively with the specific ROS generated upon illumination. The spectroscopic characteristics exhibited by the resulting products reveal the identity of the ROS.(84,85) Very recently it has been demonstrated that singlet oxygen generation can be achieved by subjecting PSs in cells and gels to the energy of accelerated protons, paving the way for a combined proton beam therapy and PDT.(86)
    An ideal photosensitizer for PDT should (i) have a high, but generally not excessive, quantum yield for generation of a long-lived triplet state, (ii) absorb preferably in the red to far-red (600–800 nm) region of the spectrum in order to be excited by radiation that penetrates tissues in depth and avoids absorption by oxy-Hb, (iii) have high tissue selectivity for minimal side effects in surrounding tissues, and if this requirement is met, it is preferable to be administered intravenously. PSs should also possess all the characteristics of a drug, that is, aqueous solubility, lack of toxicity if not exposed to light (dark toxicity), good pharmacokinetic profile, and rapid and complete elimination from the body. Moreover, the PS should be of a stable and pure composition in order to have reproducible dose–response results and should be delivered by a biocompatible carrier.(87) Porphyrinoid compounds or their metal coordinated complexes have been the first to be used for PDT, because they meet many of the above characteristics, for example, porfimer sodium (Photofrin), an oligomeric hematoporphyrin derivative, and the chlorin mTHPC (temoporphin, Foscan) are clinically approved in several countries. Porphyrinoids are characterized by a large absorption band (Soret band) around 400 nm and several bands at longer wavelengths (Q-bands). For porphyrins the Q-band at the longest λ lies at ca. 650 nm and it is of low intensity, but for chlorins and bacteriochlorins (Figure 2), this Q-band shifts to longer λ (650–690 and 750–800 nm, respectively) and its intensity increases considerably. Thus, chlorins, bacteriochlorins, and phthalocyanines absorbing light in the deep red spectral region that allows higher penetration in tissues are used more and more for the development of photosensitizers. PS selection depends also on their preference to be localized in specific cell compartment(s). Hydrophobic porphyrinoids tend to be localized in the mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum and function via type I and II mechanisms generating mainly HO• radicals, whereas hydrophilic PSs are localized in the lysosomes acting by the type II mechanism generating 1O2.(82) It is believed that damage in mitochondria results in apoptosis and cell death, in contrast to the localization in endoplasmic reticulum and the lysosomes, where cell death depends on additional factors as well, such as the amount of PS taken up by the cells. Since 1O2 has a very short lifetime (<40 ns),(82) it does not diffuse considerably in the cell; therefore it is crucial in which organelle the PS is located in order to maximize damage. Finally, the fluorescence emitted when the PS is in the excited singlet state is very important, since it can be used to locate its position in cells, tissues, and animals by fluorescence imaging but also to measure its pharmacokinetics.

    3.2. Photoantimicrobial Treatment (aPDT)

    In addition to using PDT for cancer therapy, photodynamic treatment can be used for microbial infections, a problem becoming more and more serious due to the spreading of antibiotic-resistant microbial strains.(88) Photoantimicrobial treatment (aPDT) has been applied 100 years ago. Available studies suggest that aPDT is as effective in resistant as in wild-type bacterial strains and that bacteria do not develop resistance because photodamage is caused by membrane destruction and mutagenic processes; consequently, generation of photoresistant strains is minimal.(89) This kind of therapy can be applied in bacterial biofilm formations or toxins and it does not discriminate between Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, although it has been demonstrated that when the PS is localized in the outer membrane of the Gram-negative bacteria aPDT treatment is not effective.(90) Moreover, aPDT can be applied to viruses, fungi, and protozoa. However, although the beneficial effects of aPDT have been demonstrated within the research community during the last 25 years, clinical trials are still limited.(88) As in the case of PDT, aPDT is particularly suited for localized infections (e.g., oral candidiasis, periodontitis, or chronic wounds) because the surrounding tissues are protected by the topical application of the PS and the short duration of the treatment (incubation and illumination) that does not favor spread or penetration in the surrounding tissues. Nevertheless, infections in other organs, such as nose, lungs, gastrointestinal tract, or ears, can be treated presently given the advancement in fiber optics and the possibility of endoscopic co-delivery of photosensitizer and illumination. Further, the aPDT approach can be applied in many other cases, such as implants, infection control in hospitals, veterinary treatment, food safety(91) (fish and plant farming, contamination management in food processing), and in many more cases.(92) Clinically approved porphyrinoids already evaluated for PDT to combat cancer have been proposed as aPDT photosensitizers, among others.(93)

    3.3. Cyclodextrins in PDT

    Besides enhancing greatly the porphyrinoid aqueous solubility, biocompatibility, and efficiency, the CD–PS association offers additional beneficial characteristics: (i) CDs can be adorned with moieties targeting either receptors for specific tumors(87,94) or specific organelles; (ii) CDs can be functionalized with labels for imaging applications; (iii) in cases of CD–PS covalent conjugates and various CD–PS nanomaterials, the CD cavity is left available for entrapment of drug molecules for transfer inside cells and tissues rendering them multimodal carriers for PDT treatment, that is, chemo- or photodynamic therapy and imaging.(95) Furthermore, the latter characteristic makes conjugates appropriate vehicles for photochemical internalization (PCI) treatment, a novel photodelivery mechanism surpassing PDT that has entered into clinical trials.(96) In this modality, internalized amphiphilic PSs are lodged in lysosome and endosome membranes together with entrapped endocytosed drugs. By localized illumination, rupture of the organelle membranes takes place followed by release of both ROS and the enclosed drugs into the cytosol free to be directed to the appropriate target. PCI is applicable to macromolecular cytotoxic agents; however it can be applied to small molecular chemotherapeutics (Figure 11) carried by PS–CD conjugates (vide infra).

    3.4. Photothermal Therapy (PTT) and Nanoparticles (NPs)

    Recent therapeutic modes utilize nanoassemblies for photothermal therapy (PTT), in which photoabsorbing agents produce hyperthermia for cell death. PTT is not very effective alone but functions synergistically, since it increases oxygen supply by accelerating blood flow and fights hypoxia associated with PDT. Moreover PTT enhances vascular permeability in tumors resulting in more efficient transfer of the PS or anticancer drugs. Appropriate platforms for PTT are NPs able to efficiently generate heat (increase in temperature to 41–48 °C) upon laser irradiation at near-IR (NIR) wavelengths, free of the absorption by biological fluids and tissue scattering. Two NIR transparent “biological windows” exist: (a) 700–980 nm between the absorption bands of hemoglobin and water at 980 nm and (b) 1000–1400 nm, both wavelength limits corresponding to water absorption. There are several types of NPs absorbing in the above ranges, such as carbon-based, organic and metal NPs, as well as semiconductor nanocrystals; their cellular uptake process is influenced by factors such as morphology and surface roughness. A special group of NPs is upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs). Photon upconversion (UC) is a nonlinear optical process characterizing optically transparent nanocrystals of inorganic host lattices doped by trivalent rare-earth ions, lanthanides, and actinides.(97) UCNPs absorb sequentially two or more low energy photons in the NIR (780–2500 nm) region of the light spectrum, they are activated by electron transfer and emit a higher energy photon at a lower wavelength range (UV to IR), where many photosensitizers absorb and can be excited. Prerequisite for the latter is the proximity between PS molecules and UCNPs.(98) The importance of UCNPs for PDT is apparent since illumination with NIR light causes less photodamage and penetrates tissues deeply.

    3.5. Porphyrin Precursors Attached on Cyclodextrins

    Besides the traditional implementation of PDT, there exists the alternative in vivo approach for generation of photosensitizers through the mechanism for cellular biosynthesis of heme, which involves δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA, Figure 12A) as the precursor in its penultimate step. When ALA is supplied to the organism, it triggers the production of protoporphyrin IX (PpIX, Figure 10), a precursor of heme b. In clinical practice, ALA esters are used for PDT treatment, as well as for imaging, for example, hexyl levulinate for bladder cancer imaging (Hexvix). Recently, a conjugate of βCD with amino-terminated δ-aminolevulinic acid (16) introduced into breast cancer MCF7 cells(99) has produced PpIX using the cells’ mechanisms (Figure 12B). It has been hypothesized that ALA is liberated from 16, based on the anticipated intracellular hydrolysis of its ester bond, which explains the cytosolic red fluorescence. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that 16 can transport into the cells a guest molecule included inside the βCD cavity; therefore it may act as a bimodal agent, as it generates a PS and has the potential to carry an encapsulated drug.
    The related conjugate 17 of αCD bonded to ALA via an acid-labile hydrazone linker and threaded by PEG bonded covalently to the cell penetrating peptide R6H4 (six Arg and four His residues) forms micelles (Figure 12C).(100) This system exhibits higher penetrating ability toward cancer cells (pH 6.5) as compared to normal cells (pH 7.4), because of the histidine’s buffering effect due to protonation of its imidazole ring. Furthermore, in the more acidic environment of cells, hydrolysis of the hydrazone linker takes place releasing ALA. The micellar assembly has been tested in human hepatocellular carcinoma cells, HepG2, in PBS at different pH values. The red fluorescence of PpIX, upon irradiation at 635 nm, is significantly higher when incubated at pH 6.5 than at pH 7.4, which is attributed to the higher uptake of micelles, as well as higher release of ALA in the more acidic medium. ROS generation and cell death are both higher upon incubation at pH 6.5 than at pH 7.4, whereas the dark toxicity of 17 is negligible.

    3.6. Cyclodextrin–Porphyrinoid Inclusion Complexes

    3.6.1. Inclusion Complexes of Commercially Available CDs and Porphyrinoids

    Commercially available cyclodextrins have been used in the first attempts to solubilize porphyrinoid PSs by inclusion complexation. The latter has also been used to develop methods for detection and quantitative determination of the PS concentration in biological media during biodistribution and pharmacokinetic studies in order to optimize PDT treatment, as well as determination methods for serum proteins as shown below. Thus, the chlorin mTHPC, a clinically used PS,(101) forms very stable inclusion complexes with γCD and derivatives 2,6-DMβCD and HPβCD of PS/CD stoichiometry 1:2, which are suitable for use in PDT. Further, fluorimetric quantification of the PS in human plasma of patients has been developed(102) that is characterized by high sensitivity and does not require sample pretreatment due to absence of metabolism, in contrast to the usual more complex methods. Fluorimetric determination (detection limit 8.3 × 10–10 mol L–1) has been also developed for 5-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-10,15,20-tris(4-chlorophenyl)porphyrin in aqueous solutions of βCD and several of its derivatives based on fluorescence enhancement by inclusion in βCD.(103)
    Similar studies show that HPβCD solubilizes chlorophyll a (Chla)(104,105) and chlorin e6 (Ce6)(106) (Figure 10) more efficiently than HPγCD by inclusion complex formation generating monomeric PS species in cell culture medium. This is important since it is known that the proteins in the latter medium compete with CDs for complexation with porphyrinoids.(107)In vitro studies(104) on human colorectal adenocarcinoma HT29 cells have shown that the Chla/HPβCD complex does not exhibit dark toxicity, facilitates internalization of Chla into the lysosomes, and exhibits high phototoxicity and cell death (cell survival ca. 20%) by necrotic mechanisms. Related studies demonstrate that HPβCD and randomly methylated βCD (rMeβCD) solubilize mTHPC in serum solutions and accelerate its delivery to cellular cultures and HT29 tumor bearing mice.(108) The CD concentrations for maximum amounts of the mTHPC/CD complexes have been optimized in the presence of serum due to the above-mentioned tendency of serum proteins to form complexes with mTHPC. The affinity of rMeβCD for mTHPC is higher than that for HPβCD; thus the amount needed to internalize the PS into HT29 cells is much smaller (10 μM for rMeβCD compared to 200 μM of HPβCD under the same conditions). This study demonstrates also that the uptake of the PS in various tissues is not the same but depends on the nature of the CD used. The tumor/muscle ratio of the uptake is higher in the case of mTHPC/rMeβCD complex compared to the uptake of free mTHPC, an observation that can help the optimization of the system during PDT. Furthermore, absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy studies(109) with mTHPC and βCD, TMβCD, and rMeβCD in solutions of serum proteins at various concentrations and in lipid membranes provide very interesting information about the interactions of mTHPC with the surrounding environment. Specifically, the intensity ratio between the two Soret peaks depends on whether the PS is included in CD cavities, binds to serum proteins, or interacts with cell membranes. Thus, a noninvasive method for the determination of the amount of mTHPC interacting with biological and cyclodextrin molecules in aqueous solutions has been designed. This method has been used further to determine the location of mTHPC in inclusion complexes of HPβCD, rMeβCD, and TMβCD formulated in liposomes and has shown that most of the PS is retained in the CD cavities in the aqueous solution of the inner compartment of the liposomes.(110) Of the three CDs used, TMβCD exhibits the optimum behavior because it retains almost all the mTHPC amount and it is stable for three months. Moreover, when the formulations are delivered in spheroids of human colon adenocarcinoma cells HT29, TMβCD has a homogeneous accumulation of mTHPC suggesting similar distribution in tumor tissues.
    Recent studies of TMβCD complexes with four meso-tetraarylporphyrins, TPP, pTHPP, TNPP, and TCPP (Figure 3), compare their photodynamic activity and their effect on the viability of HeLa cells after irradiation.(111) It is demonstrated that although the photogeneration of 1O2 is similar among the complexes, upon evaluation on HeLa cells after 24 h incubation and irradiation with red light (610–740 nm), only pTHPP and TNPP exhibit high phototoxicity (0.15 and 0.08 μM, respectively), 14 and 26 times higher than porfimer sodium (2.1 μM) a clinically used PS, while the dark toxicity of all complexes is very low. This difference is attributed to higher uptake of the pTHPP and TNPP complexes, shown to take place by endocytosis, due to interaction of the hydroxyl and amino groups with the cell membranes, whereas the anionic carboxyl group of TCPP is repelled by the anionic surface of the cells. The detailed study was meant to contribute toward optimization of the design of the tetraarylporphyrin derivatives for PDT by the appropriate selection of the substituents on the phenyl group.

    3.6.2. Inclusion Complexes of Designed CDs and Porphyrinoids

    Similar studies(112) as before with complexes of TMβCD and the three 5,15-diazaporphyrin derivatives 18a–c are not in accord with the results of the previous study. Specifically, the 18b/TMβCD complex with hydroxyl substituents exhibits lower 1O2 generation ability, as well as less intracellular uptake compared to the 18a/TMβCD and 18c/ TMβCD ones, although the OH substituents are expected to interact with the cell membranes as in the pTHPP/TMβCD complex.(111) The discrepancy has been explained by the hypothesis that the hydroxyl groups of 18b do not protrude from the βCD rim as in the latter complex. The study further shows that 18a/TMβCD and 18c/TMβCD complexes have higher photodynamic activity (IC50, 0.047 and 0.022 μM, respectively) toward HeLa cells than the pTHPP/TMβCD (0.15 μM) complex and porfimer sodium (2.1 μM). The present case indicates that PDT ability of various PSs in CD inclusion complexes cannot be compared based only on chemical details, for example, phenyl substituents, if the structure or the binding constants are not known.
    Several inventive porphyrinoid–cyclodextrin inclusion complexes have been proposed as appropriate PSs for cell membrane penetration. Such an example is the porphyrinoid 19, which involves the previously mentioned octaarginine peptide R8(66) (vide supra) attached to the neutral TPP and forms a single water-soluble inclusion complex with TMβCD at a guest/host ratio of 1:2.(113) Experiments in HeLa cells have shown that TMβCD competes with serum proteins in both solubilizing and internalizing 19 in cells. In the presence of serum, 19 enters the cells via endocytosis, presumably via preferential binding to serum proteins, and it is localized mainly in endosomes, whereas in the absence of serum, 19/TMβCD is dispersed in the cytosol. The efficiency of TMβCD to internalize 19 in the cell is twice as high as that of serum proteins. The phototoxicity of the cytosolic 19/TMβCD complex is higher than the endosomal protein-bound 19 after 2 h incubation; therefore TMβCD may play a role as PDT modulator. An analogous study involves TPPS modified in one of the meso-positions with an anionic peptide (tetraglutaminylglutaramido moiety),(114) which forms a 1:2 inclusion complex with TMβCD and interacts strongly with a dodecaarginine peptide in aqueous solution by Coulombic interactions. The resulting ternary complex is taken up efficiently by HeLa cells in serum medium. On the other hand, when the arginine octamer R8 is covalently attached on the primary side of TMβCD, it does not interfere with the ability of the product R8-TMβCD (20) to form also a 1:2 inclusion complex with the anionic TPPS of the same stability as the corresponding complex with TMβCD.(115) The affinity of TPPS for 20 is higher than for serum proteins; thus the latter do not inhibit the cellular uptake of TPPS in HeLa cells, as shown by internalization experiments. If the cells are incubated in serum-free medium, TPPS enters the cell by direct transmembrane mechanism and is dispersed and sustained in the cytosol, whereas if the incubation takes place in serum-containing medium, TPPS is contained predominantly in endosomes, because the endocytosis mechanism prevails. The complex TPPS/20 exhibits very high photoinduced cytotoxicity irrespective of serum incubation, while it does not exhibit dark toxicity. Since the TPPS/20 complex operates in the presence of serum proteins, the R8-modified TMβCD 20 has much potential as a carrier for cell internalization. Documentation that the complex TPPS/TMβCD is sustained in blood, serum, and urine is provided in recent NMR studies.(116)
    The following case presents a self-assembled supramolecular CD polymer serving as a PS carrier for cell internalization: CD derivative 21 is TMβCD functionalized at its primary side by 4-amino-N-(2-methylquinolin-8-yl)benzenesulfonamide (MQSA), a coordinating group for metal ions.(117) Two molecules of 21 form a strong Zn(II)/21, 1:2 coordination complex (log K = 13.1), two molecules of which subsequently self-assemble to include a Zn(II)-TPPS molecule. The resulting inclusion-coordination complex Zn(II)/21/Zn(II)-TPPS (log K ca. 9) organizes into water-soluble supramolecular polymers as depicted in Figure 13. When yeast cells are incubated with these assemblies (3 h), disruption of the supramolecular polymers takes place in the hydrophobic environment of the cell membrane followed by release of Zn(II)-TPPS into the cytoplasm, as demonstrated by fluorescence microscopy. Therefore, this environment-sensitive “Lego” system is interesting for cell internalization of anionic porphyrins.
    Similarly, supramolecular polymers have been designed in order to protect the high spin Mn(II) ions of Mn(II)-TPP from oxidation in MRI applications.(118) TMβCD dimers 22 formed by thiourea linkers have been used to encapsulate derivative 23 of Mn(III)-TPP functionalized with PEG to form the 1:1 inclusion complex 23/22 (Figure 14). Mn(III) of 23 inside the supramolecular polymers can be reduced in situ to Mn(II) by ascorbic acid, in contrast to free 23, which cannot be reduced under the same conditions. The high association constant (K = 6.46 × 105 M–1) of the complex and its strong tendency to form supramolecular polymers enhance the stability of Mn(II), while the PEG moieties prolong circulation in the blood. Mn(II)-23 is found in monomeric form inside the polymers, autoxidizing to Mn(III)-23 within 24 min, which however is sufficient for its use as contrast agent in MRI experiments. The characteristics of the system are very promising; for example, the relaxivity (r1) in vitro is better (16.72 mM–1 s–1) than the Gd(III) contrast agents used in the clinic (r1 ca. 4 mM–1 s–1) and its toxicity is negligible. In vivo experiments on female athymic BALB/c nude mice at a dose of 0.03 mmol of Mn(II) per kilogram demonstrate positive contrast enhancement in the blood, kidney, and urinary bladder for at least 25 min, indicating excretion by renal filtration, but very low signal in the liver, suggesting no liver toxicity.
    A different supramolecular nanoassembly has been designed to ameliorate the side effects of cisplatin (Figure 11), a very potent anticancer drug for solid tumors.(119) By incorporation of cisplatin in a NP, it can be internalized via endocytosis, thus bypassing recognition by the efflux pumps of the cell membranes. Cisplatin is formulated as a prodrug with Pt(IV), which is more stable in biological fluids and can be reduced in situ to the active Pt(II) form. The designed system (Figure 15) aims at bimodal action combining chemo- and photodynamic therapy. It comprises a CD dimer (24) formed from two βCD molecules covalently bound to the axial positions of c,c,t-[Pt(NH3)2Cl2(HO2CCH2CH2CO2H)2] complex, and it is linked to the PS, the ADA-modified TPyP (25), by inclusion of the ADA groups in the cavities of 24. The fluorescence intensity of 25 in aqueous solution increases as the concentration of 24 increases until the 25/24 ratio is 1:2. The increase in fluorescence demonstrates that strong 1:2 inclusion complexes are formed [Ka = (4.39 ± 0.4) × 107 M–2] resulting in elimination of the porphyrin aggregates in the medium. Further, the inclusion complexes self-assemble into NPs (ca. 100 nm), which are internalized very efficiently into cisplatin-resistant human lung adenocarcinoma epithelial cells A549R by endocytosis. The cellular uptake of the complex 25/24 is 12-fold higher than that of the free cisplatin. It is interesting to note that the cytotoxicity of free 24 on the resistant cells is quite low both in the dark and upon visible light irradiation (430 nm) probably due to low cellular uptake. Moreover, free 25 shows very low dark cytotoxicity and moderate phototoxicity after visible light irradiation due to aggregation. In contrast, the complex 25/24 is quite cytotoxic even in the dark. However, its cytotoxicity is enhanced remarkably compared to free cisplatin upon irradiation as above, due to increased cell uptake and ROS generation with concomitant destruction of the NPs and the synergistic chemotherapy effect. Thus, the combined chemotherapeutic and photodynamic effect of the supramolecular 25/24 system overcomes cisplatin resistance.

    3.7. Cyclodextrin Conjugates

    In addition to the CD inclusion complexes presented above, PS–CD conjugates have been designed, synthesized, and assessed for their potential in photodynamic therapy. Prerequisite is that conjugation does not compromise the photodynamic efficiency of the resulting molecule as is the case of a corrole/βCD conjugate.(120) Toward this end, spectroscopic studies of the photodynamic characteristics of tri- and tetra-glucoconjugated analogues of mTHPP and the corresponding chlorin mTHPC show that the triplet lifetimes (τT) of the chlorin derivatives were about four times higher than those of porphyrins, whereas the quantum yields (ΦT) and rate constants (kq) for the reaction with O2 were similar.(121) Therefore, attachment of water-soluble carbohydrate molecules modulates the amphiphilicity of mTHPP and mTHPC but does not impede their photophysical properties. The conjugates have the advantage that they are pure and well characterized PSs, better suited to the requirement of reproducible dose-response results. Moreover, the conjugates may display favorable properties for biomedical applications, compared to their individual components, even without the need for photoaction: in vitro studies for Alzheimer’s disease(7) show that the interaction of the pTHPP−βCD and Zn(II)-pTHPP−βCD conjugates with fibrillar amyloid β peptide (Aβ) aggregates inhibit the formation of the toxic Aβ42 aggregates by interacting with the extended part of the Aβ42 peptide encompassing the Leu-Val-Phe-Phe motif. Confocal image analysis of the cells suggest that Zn(II)-pTHPP−βCD localizes in lysosomes; therefore the lack of toxicity of the associated Aβ42 is attributed to the ability of the conjugate to direct it into its place of destruction.
    One of the first examples of covalently bound PS–CD conjugates synthesized so far to combine PDT therapy and cancer chemotherapy(122) comprises bis-βCD (26) and bis-γCD (27) derivatives of meso-tetrakis(pentafluorophenyl)porphyrin and the cytostatic drugs (Figure 11) paclitaxel (PTX) and doxorubicin (DOX) in complex with 26 and 27, respectively. Tests on mouse mammary carcinoma cells 4T1 in vitro have shown that upon incubation in the presence of fetal calf serum (FCS), the conjugates are internalized in the lysosomes and have limited dark toxicities; however after irradiation their toxicities become 3–4-fold higher compared to separate treatments. Although not discussed, this effect could be a synergy of chemo- and phototoxicity due to PCI effect (vide supra). In vivo experiments using a BALB/c mouse cancer model (mammary carcinoma 4T1 cells growing subcutaneously) have shown that 26 and 27 combined with PTX and DOX, respectively, are very effective in reducing tumor volume (tumor volume ratios 24% and 32% for treated versus control animals 25 days after one-shot treatment). However, if multiple dose treatment is applied, the corresponding treated versus control ratios are improved to 7% and 9% 30 days after repeated therapy. Further, the Zn complexes Zn(II)-26 and Zn(II)-27 have been used for PDT and chemotherapy, with the addition of a protein for three-mode therapy.(123) The role of the protein is to improve the transport of the drug–PS in the tumor cells from passive internalization in the case of 26 and 27 carriers to active in the presence of a selected protein. The interaction of the protein with the conjugate is achieved through coordination of the Zn metal ion by histidine or tryptophan residues. Application of the Zn(II)-26 and Zn(II)-27 carrying PTX and DOX, respectively, and endoglobulin on a nude mouse model (human amelanotic melanoma C32) at a single dose demonstrates that the three-mode therapy is more effective for the reduction of tumor volume (11% and 12% for treated versus control animals after 30 days for 26 and 27, respectively) compared to the two-mode (55% and 35% for treated versus control) after 30 days of one-shot treatment.
    Another design of PS–CD conjugate is Si(IV)-phthalocyanine (Si-Pc) coordinated at both axial positions of silicon by CD or other moieties. In the first group of conjugates, 28a–d,(124) four derivatives of TMβCD with different linkers coordinate symmetrically the axial positions (Figure 16). The second group 29a–d(125) includes a symmetric TMβCD derivative, 29a, and three unsymmetric ones, all of which have a TMβCD in one axial position and a different appendage in the other (Figure 16). All conjugates have adequate solubility in water (with traces of THF) and ability to generate singlet oxygen. In vitro PDT trials with conjugates 28a–d using human hepatocarcinoma HepG2 and adenocarcinoma HT29 cell lines demonstrate lack of dark toxicities and good phototoxicities upon illumination with red light (675 nm), improved (IC50 = 0.04–1.32 μM) compared to the use of porfimer sodium (IC50 = 4.6 μM) under the same conditions. Compound 28a exhibiting the optimum PS characteristics (IC50 = 0.04–0.05 μM) is localized in lysosomes upon incubation in the presence of FCS as determined by confocal laser microscopy and shows cytotoxicity resulting in apoptotic action as determined by flow cytometry assays. It was found that 80% of HT29 cells incubated in the presence of 28a are in the early apoptotic state after illumination by red light, whereas without illumination more than 90% of the cells are in a viable state. In vivo experiments using 28a on nude mice models with HT29 tumor show that upon injection of the PS and subsequent illumination with 675 nm laser light, the rate of tumor growth during the following 15 days is substantially decreased in contrast to the control that continues to grow.
