In vitro tests conducted as above show that 29a–d are also internalized in HT29 and HepG2 cells in the presence of traces of Cremophor EL, their cellular location varying; for example, compounds 29a and 29d exhibit preference for lysosomes, in contrast to 29b and 29c. Although only 29a–c exhibit generation of 1O2 extracellularly, all compounds cause high phototoxicity to the HT29 and HepG2 cells (29b > 29c > 29d > 29a), whereas they lack dark toxicity. Overall, the nonsymmetrical PSs are more photocytotoxic to the two cell lines (IC50 = 0.21–0.94 nM) compared to the symmetric ones, their toxicities being higher than that of Zn-Pc formulated into liposomes. Their photocytotoxicity is attributed to enhanced amphiphilicity resulting in enhanced cell uptake and generation of more ROS intracellularly. In vivo experiments on nude mice models bearing HT29 tumor treated with a dose of the best compound 29b (1 μmol kg–1) intravenously followed by illumination with red light (675 nm) after 12 h demonstrate that the rate of the tumor growth during the following 15 days is decreased (2-fold) compared to untreated animals and that cell death is induced by apoptosis.
    Another approach devised to reinforce the cytotoxicity of PS-CD conjugates for PDT is to involve in the assembly nitric oxide, a radical (NO•) that generates additional ROS on light excitation.(126) It is recognized that NO plays a key role in physiological and pathological bioregulatory processes;(127) for example, NO reacts readily with O2 to produce nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and acts as an anticancer agent arresting the growth of tumor cells. NO reacts with O2•– to produce OONO– (NROS, vide supra). Being a gas, NO has to be introduced in the PS system by a NO-donor molecule. The following example uses the NO-donor 30 carrying an ADA moiety that fits perfectly in the βCD cavity of the mono-mTHPP-βCD derivative 31 (Figure 17). The NO-donor 30 has been used before and exhibits the appropriate properties for PDT application.(128) Conjugate 31 is soluble in PBS with addition of 0.5% DMSO, where limited nanoaggregation (13 nm diameter particles) is observed as indicated by dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements. Compound 30, insoluble in water, becomes soluble in the buffer solution by forming a strong 1:1 inclusion complex with the βCD moiety of 31 as indicated by the differences in UV–vis absorption spectra and resonance light scattering measurements. The spectroscopic properties of the porphyrin core of 31 are not affected either by the covalent attachment of βCD moiety or by the inclusion of 30, indicating that the two photocenters do not communicate. Upon inclusion of 30 in 31, nanoaggregates with almost unchanged particle diameter (16 nm) are maintained. Photogeneration of both ROS and NROS has been demonstrated in vitro. The nanoassemblies are internalized into the cytoplasm of human amelanotic melanoma A375 cells after incubation in the presence of both 31 and 30. Subsequent irradiation with visible light results in high cytotoxicity, whereas dark toxicity is very small.
    The biodistribution of PS 31 in human skin and human squamous carcinoma cells A431 has been compared to that of the parent porphyrin mTHPP using steady state fluorescence spectra, as well as fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM).(129) Uptake of 31 in monomeric form by the cells, which is very important for PDT, has been demonstrated. The distribution of 31 in excised human skin has been studied ex vivo after topical delivery using two-photon fluorescence microscopy, which shows improved biodistribution in the skin compared to the free mTHPP. Therefore, the study proves that the higher solubility of 31, provided by the CD component, renders the PS a better vehicle for PDT application for the skin. An additional advantage of the CD moiety is that it can be combined with chemotherapy via the CD cavity that allows for bimodal action.
    Further studies with 31 have been focused on its application in photochemical internalization (PCI, vide supra) experiments.(96,130) Connection of mTHPP to βCD to form the amphiphilic conjugate 31 modifies the molecular weight and the hydrophobic profile of mTHPP; hence using a suitable cell culture medium with fetal bovine serum (FBS), 31 is directed into endosomes or lysosomes.(131) The carrier system 31 includes in the CD cavity the anticancer drugs N-desmethyltamoxifen (NDMTAM) or 4-hydroxytamoxifen (4-OHTAM), both primary active metabolites of tamoxifen (TAM) (Figure 11), a nonsteroidal selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). The solubility of NDMTAM is enhanced by a factor of 4 due to inclusion (complex 32) as confirmed by 2-D ROESY NMR spectra in PBS buffer, as well as by FRET experiments using the fluorescein-labeled drug NDMTAM-FITC. This is supported by the sufficiently strong 1:1 binding between NDMTAM and the parent βCD(132) as found by NMR titrations (K ca. 0.7 × 104 M–1). The drug loaded conjugate 31 has been incubated with two breast carcinoma cell lines, namely, estrogen-receptor β-positive (Erβ+) MCF7 and estrogen-receptor β-negative (Erβ−) MDA-MB-231. Confocal microscopy shows that when the two cell lines are incubated with the assembly 31/NDMTAM-FITC, red punctate fluorescence is observed indicating accumulation and confinement of 31 in endosomes, while the green fluorescence of NDMTAM-FITC is quenched. Upon irradiation, rupture of the endosomal membranes presumably takes place liberating the contents of endocytosed species into the cytosol. Liberation of NDMTAM-FITC is indicated by emergence of green fluorescence and relocation (as it can cross cellular membranes freely) in subcellular organelles, likely mitochondria. Phototoxicity experiments show that only Erβ+ cells exhibit high percentage of cell death (ca. 80%) and suspension of growth even at 72 h after irradiation, a manifestation of PCI. The dark toxicity is limited. Although 4-OHTAM penetrates cell membranes freely, utilization of carrier 31 diverts it into endosomes, where it is accumulated until it is co-released with ROS to exert its cytotoxicity in a controlled mode upon irradiation.
    Covalent linking of βCD and protoporphyrin IX (PpIX) produced a PS that can be effective for cancerous cells as above.(132) The synthesis afforded a mixture of a major (90%) component (33) and a minor (10%) component (34) after size-exclusion chromatography. The mixture is soluble in aqueous solution and exhibits some residual nanoaggregation (6.5 nm particles) corresponding to a few molecules. Using human prostate carcinoma DU145 and human breast adenocarcinoma MCF7 cell lines, it has been shown that the conjugates can be internalized in the cells. The dark toxicity of the 33 + 34 cocktail is similar to that of free PpIX, and the cocktail exhibits satisfactory phototoxicity, comparable also to PpIX. Incubation (3 h) of MCF7 cells in an aqueous solution mixture of 33 + 34 in the presence of the anticancer agent NDMTAM, followed by irradiation with red light shows that phototoxicity is 70%, whereas without the presence of NDMTAM phototoxicity is 30% under the same conditions; therefore in this case a synergistic photo- and chemoaction is observed.
    Conjugates 35a–c of similar structure as 33 have been synthesized(133) from α-, β-, and γ-cyclodextrins with Zn(II) perfluorinated phthalocyanine (Zn(II)-FPc). The conjugates are formed by two ether bonds linking the Zn(II)-FPc to two glucopyranose units of a single CD. It should be stressed that determination of the exact structure of the conjugates is hard due to the possible presence of several regioisomers; however after tedious purification, the conjugates have been characterized by TOF and MALDI MS/MS tandem mass spectrometry and NMR spectroscopy. Although the conjugates are soluble in water at experimentally useful concentrations (35c = 35a, 50 μM; 35b, 10 μM), they exhibit tendency for self-aggregation in PBS. The conjugates are photostable and have the ability to generate 1O2 similar to free Zn(II)-FPc demonstrating that its photodynamic ability is not compromised by attachment to the CD molecule. The in vitro toxicities of all the conjugates, tested in human bladder carcinoma UM-UC-3 cells are very low in the dark, whereas 35a and 35c show satisfactory toxicities (IC50 = 26–87 nM) after illumination by red light (620–750 nm), that is, similar to that exhibited by the Si(IV)-Pc conjugates 29 (vide supra) against human colorectal carcinoma and human hepatocarcinoma cells.(125)

    3.8. Porphyrinoid–Cyclodextrin Nanomaterials for PDT, aPDT, and PTT

    CD–porphyrinoid nanoassemblies of nonexplicitly specified stoichiometry and structure have been designed for photodynamic processes. Over the past decade various nanomaterials including micelles, vesicles, nanoparticles, and gold nanostructures, as well as carbon nanotubes, 2-D materials, and nanoplatforms, have been developed for drug delivery in PDT and PTT applications. A category of promising biocompatible and biodegradable biomaterials are hydrogels formed by the fine-tuning of the hydrophobic and hydrophilic domains of their components.(134) Injectable hydrogels, where gelation is taking place after injection into tissues, are particularly interesting, because they can function as drug delivery depots. They can be loaded appropriately with drugs and fluorescent labels to serve as drug delivery carriers with imaging capacity to follow in vivo the fate of the hydrogel carrier in the body.(135)
    The following examples show how, depending on the environment, the affinity of porphyrinoids for the cavity of CDs leads to nanoscale organization. It is well documented(136) that when a tetraarylporphyrin derivative (e.g., TPP) is covalently bound to the primary side of TMβCD, self-inclusion of the phenyl moiety takes place quantitatively, due to the high stability of the resulting multi-self-inclusion complexes. These are formed by a 360° rotation of each glucopyranose unit covalently bound to the TPP derivative, which brings the wide secondary side of the cavity facing the porphyrin core. Thus, TPP flanked by two (36a) or four TMβCD units (36b)(137) linked to the meso-phenyl groups by triazole moieties (Figure 18A) do not aggregate in aqueous solutions due to the intramolecular inclusion complexes formed by double (or quadruple self-inclusion of the phenyl moieties of TPP that segregate completely the PS molecules. Further, in the presence of an agglomeration inhibitor, PPGN [poly(propylene glycol) bis(2-aminopropyl ether)], 36a and 36b form nanospheres (88 and 110 nm, respectively) soluble in water, which show improved 1O2 generation ability compared to similarly prepared nanospheres of porphyrins that lack the ability to form CD inclusion complexes. If one of the triazole-TMβCD moieties is replaced by the hydrophobic dodecyl group, the modified system organizes differently. Specifically, the Zn(II)-5-(4′-dodecyloxyphenyl)-10,15,20-tri(TMβCD) conjugate 37 forms self-inclusion complexes as before involving only the three TMβCD cavities.(138) Upon mixing with the hydrophilic porphyrinoid TPPS at 1:0.5 molar ratio of 37/TPPS in aqueous solution, one of the TMβCD moieties unfolds liberating its cavity to form the very strong inclusion complex 37/TPPS. The latter is an amphiphilic system that initially forms bilayers, with the aliphatic chains in the interior of the bilayer and the hydrophilic TPPS in the exterior. Subsequently the bilayers develop into hollow vesicles with TPPS in the interior and exterior surface of the vesicles (Figure 18B). When TPPS is in excess (i.e., molar ratio 1:1.5 of 37/TPPS) the vesicles are transformed into fibers. This transformation is explained by the unfolding of all TMβCD moieties to form the much stronger inclusion complexes with TPPS, favored versus self-inclusion. The result is formation of linear polymers by inclusion of the aliphatic groups inside available TMβCD cavities, which are organized into fibers. Both vesicle and fiber morphologies show controlled delivery of DOX, but with different delivery rates.
    Extended organization is also achieved by the known property of alkylated cyclodextrins to form vesicles and nanoassemblies, as well as by the tendency of the ADA moiety to form strong inclusion complexes, especially with βCD and its derivatives. The latter strategy has been applied in numerous studies already presented and others that will follow next. In addition to the above, π–π interactions among porphyrinoids or between the porphyrinoid core and drugs contribute also to their organization by π–π interactions; for example, conjugates of PpIX similar to 35 form inclusion complexes with two dendrimers, one with hydrophilic surface and the other with hydrophobic, whose amphiphilic nature, along with the π–π interactions among the PpIX aromatic core lead to hollow spherical vesicles exhibiting good singlet oxygen production.(139) The designed porphyrinoid–CD nanoassemblies below employ the above organization modes. Moreover, they also pursue the requirement of a stable composition and dispersion in aqueous solutions without disintegration, as well as a size smaller than 100 nm for extended circulation in the bloodstream and more efficient internalization into cells.(140)
    Supramolecular PS–CD self-assembled vesicles have been developed using the amphiphilic βCD 38 (Figure 19), with hydrophobic (hexylthio) groups on the primary side and positively charged groups on the secondary side as a carrier system for drug and PS molecules for PDT.(141) Modification with positively charged groups on the primary side and hydrophobic ones on the secondary side of βCD(142) produce also stable nanoassemblies for use as drug carriers for PDT. The positively charged nanoassemblies of 38 attract through electrostatic interactions and entrap the anionic and water-soluble TPPS. Further, the nanoassemblies can be labeled with dansyl groups covalently bound, but randomly distributed on the secondary side of the βCD allowing simultaneous detection of the host (green fluorescence of the dansyl groups) and the PS (red fluorescence of TPPS) inside the cell. The TPPS/38 system (300 nm)(143) is able to include in the CD cavities the NROS photodonor guest 30. The spectral characteristics of the two photoactive species are not altered demonstrating absence of interactions; therefore localization in different compartments of the nanoassembly and preservation of their individual photodynamic ability. The assemblies can be internalized into HeLa cells as shown by the TPPS fluorescence, and upon irradiation with visible light, NROS and ROS species are generated simultaneously and effectively as shown by real-time monitoring. Irradiation leads to very high cell death (ca. 98%) due to the dual action of the NO and 1O2 species, whereas the nanoassemblies exhibit no dark toxicity.
    Further, the TPPS/38 nanoassembly mixed with gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) generates NPs for combined use in PDT and PTT modes (Figure 19).(144) The nanoassemblies form homogeneous dispersions in PBS solutions (pH 7.4), they are capable of generating 1O2, and they are internalized in the cytoplasm of HeLa cancer cells, as determined by the colocalization of AuNPs and TPPS. The ternary AuNP/TPPS/38 system demonstrates indeed combined PTT and PDT action on HeLa cells upon overnight incubation followed by laser irradiation at 532 nm (PTT) and subsequently by visible light for 30 min (cell death ca. 45%). PTT treatment alone, effective only on the ternary system, causes also reduced cell death (cell death ca. 30%) suggesting that the AuNPs play an important synergistic role in phototoxicity.
    The amphiphilic but uncharged βCD 39 with hexylthio groups on the primary side and oligo(ethylene glycol) (n = 3–4) moieties in the secondary side self-organizes into nanoassemblies that remain stable for 2 weeks and have been used for targeted delivery of a PS to cancer cells followed by PDT.(145) Similar assemblies, used earlier for inclusion of the poorly soluble organotin(IV)-porphyrin derivative (Bu3Sn)4TPPS, exhibit higher cytotoxicity than the free porphyrin and prevention of proliferation after delivery into highly metastatic human melanoma cancer cells A375 at lower concentrations.(146) The targeting group is folic acid (FA) covalently linked through an oligo(ethylene glycol) linker to an ADA moiety that forms a strong inclusion complex with βCD. The FA moiety is located on the secondary side of βCD, its pteridin group protruding from the CD rim. The PS is pheophorbide-A (Pheo, Figure 10) entrapped in monomeric form in the nanoassembly. The ternary system ADA-FA/Pheo/39 forms vesicles exposing FA moieties and containing Pheo well embedded within them (release about 20% in 1 week). Moreover the oligo(ethylene glycol) groups assist in the stability of the system in the presence of serum proteins. The vesicles have been tested in two cancer cell lines, human breast cancer cells MCF7 expressing a high level of folate receptors (Fr-a(+)) and human prostate cancer cells PC3 expressing a low level of folate receptors (Fr-a(−)). It has been demonstrated that the vesicles deliver Pheo within 24 h due to interaction of the FA moieties with the Fr-a. The phototoxicity after 3 h incubation and subsequent irradiation of the ternary system with red light has been found to be higher for the Fr-a(+) MCF7 cells (IC50 = 27 nM) as compared to Fr-a(−) PC3 cells (IC50 = 700 nM) confirming a targeting effect.
    Further modification of βCD with longer (hexadecylthio) tails on its primary side and bis(ethylene glycol) moieties on the secondary leads to the amphiphilic βCD derivative 40 (Figure 19), which also self-organizes into stable nanoassemblies (mean diameter, 200 nm)(147) presenting high colloidal stability in water. The nanoassemblies encapsulate efficiently the very lipophilic photosensitizer Zn(II)-Pc as a monomer. The Zn(II)-Pc/40 system is able to enter HeLa cells by endocytosis and upon irradiation generates 1O2 species, its phototoxicity being the same as that of free Zn(II)-Pc in DMSO. The Zn(II)-Pc loaded nanovescicles can be further loaded with the lipophilic anticancer drug docetaxel (DTX)(148) (entrapped in the lipophilic alkylthio region of βCD) and internalized into HeLa cancer cells. The dark toxicity of the nanoassembly (loaded with 5% of DTX and 0.2% Zn(II)-Pc) in HeLa cells is negligible, but after irradiation with visible light, cells treated with Zn(II)-Pc/DTX/40 exhibit enhanced toxicity compared to cells either treated with Zn(II)-Pc alone followed by irradiation or treated with free DTX. It is suggested that the photodynamic action caused by Zn(II)-Pc exhibits comparable PDT effect on HeLa cells to that of the free anticancer drug in DMSO, but use of carrier 40 functioning in aqueous media permits PDT in vivo. Nanoassemblies formed from the βCD derivative 41, the cationic analog of 40, had been tested previously for aPDT(149) loaded with meso-5-[4-(1-dodecanoylpyridinium)]-10,15,20-triphenyl-porphyrin (42) and proved very efficient in photokilling of Gram-positive methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteria and also active against the Gram-negative bacteria Escherichia coli.
    A different kind of NP for multimodal treatment of cancer has been developed(150) from PS 43 comprising TPP covalently bound to the anticancer drug PTX via an ester bond (Figure 20) and TMβCD linked randomly to a hydrophilic polymer of hyaluronic acid (HA). The strong complex formed by inclusion of 43 in TMβCD and the amphiphilicity of this complex results in organization of the system into NPs with a hydrophobic core occupied by 43 and an exterior shell occupied by HA moieties that can target HA receptors in cancer cells. The NPs (30–40 nm) are stable, biocompatible, and biodegradable. The presence of PTX and TPP moieties in 43 allows for evaluation for chemotherapy and PDT, respectively, the fluorescence of 43 being used also for visualization of the nanoparticles by fluorescence microscopy. The NPs are internalized in human ovarian cancer cells SKOV-3 by endocytosis via targeting of HA receptors. The in vitro experiments demonstrate that the NPs exhibit similar anticancer characteristics as the free PTX, but their toxicity toward normal cells (mouse embryonic fibroblasts NIH3T3) is very small (relative cellular viability 84% versus viability of 10% exhibited by free PTX).
    Nanoparticles comprising PpIX monoderivatized by PEG(151) and αCD have been formed by inclusion of the PEG chain into αCD. The tendency of PEG to thread in series of αCD macrocycles forming pseudo-polyrotaxanes is well-known. The rotaxanated PpIX-PEG/αCD (44) system is amphiphilic and produces NPs, which can be loaded with DOX. The core of the NPs made by PpIX moieties interacting by π–π contacts involves also DOX molecules as suggested by previous studies.(152,153) Thorough characterization of the NPs has demonstrated that the amount of αCD is proportional to the NP size, as well as to the drug’s release rate. NPs with higher content of αCD exhibit better in vitro anticancer efficacy, because the presence of more αCD molecules relaxes the π–π interactions between PpIX and DOX molecules in the core thus inducing swelling of the NP and helping the release of DOX molecules. In contrast, maximum loading of the drug is achieved in NPs with low αCD content. Using normal cells (fibroblasts L929), a satisfactory (80%) viability is maintained (up to 0.5 mg mL–1 after 48 h). DOX-loaded NPs tested on HepG2 cells show high cytotoxicity, which increases with their content in αCD.
    Modified βCD polymers can also form NPs if they are modified by appropriate substituents. An example is polyβCD 45 synthesized by attaching covalently and randomly the hydrophobic cholesteryl and chlorin Ce6 groups via CO2-forming linkers.(154) The resulting polymer (degree of substitution 6.6 with respect to cholesterol and 2.3 with respect to Ce6) is amphiphilic and self-assembles into NPs that upon irradiation at 670 nm generate 1O2. Cholesterol and Ce6 are localized in the hydrophobic core of the NPs, whose average size is 61 nm at pH 7.4 but increases at more acidic pH values; for example, between pH 6.5 and pH 5.5 (the pH of the endosomes), the NP sizes vary from 100 to 900 nm but subsequently decrease upon incubation. The size reduction is due to hydrolysis of the carbonate linkages at the acidic pH and degradation of conjugates 45. The NPs are internalized into KB tumor cells accumulating in the nucleus, the optimum uptake being at pH 6.5. Cell death upon irradiation at 670 nm at pH 6.5 is higher compared to cell death at pH 7.4 and much higher than that of free Ce6.
    βCD polymers of higher molecular weight than the previous ones discussed generate NPs in water (ca. 25 nm) spontaneously.(155) These can be loaded with Zn(II)-tetrakis(sulfatophthalocyanine) (46a) that forms inclusion complexes with βCD (46a/βCD) (Figure 21). The already loaded NPs can absorb the custom-made NO photodonor 30 (Figure 17) inducing increase of their mean diameter. It has been determined by spectroscopic studies that the two photoreactive molecules 46a and 30 are included mostly in the CD cavities not interacting within the poly-βCD matrix; therefore they function independently generating ROS (1O2) and NROS (NO), respectively, when irradiated. Moreover, Pc 46a is a red-absorbing fluorophore capable for two-photon excitation upon irradiation at 633 nm (by ultrafast laser pulses) and emits in the visible spectrum. This property has been used in two-photon fluorescence microscopy allowing imaging of the location of the NPs in human epidermal A431 cancer cells after incubation (24 h) ex vivo. The nanoparticles penetrate the upper epidermal layers up to 15 μm and are located at the cells’ surface. However, the larger part of the fluorescence emanates from the cytoplasm, which indicates that the embedded 46a has been freed from the NPs and entered the cytoplasm. The photodynamic ability of the NPs tested in human squamous carcinoma cells A431 after incubation (1 h) and irradiation simultaneously by 405 and 633 nm light shows that the cell viability is very low (10%) compared to the effect of NPs loaded separately either with the NO-photodonor 30 (20%) or with 46a (70%), thus demonstrating a cooperative PDT effect. When the same βCD polymer is mixed with laurate-modified dextran, it forms a hydrogel due to inclusion of the hydrophobic lauryl moieties in the βCD cavities.(156) The system has enough unoccupied cavities to host two photoactive guests as in the previous study. Thus, Pc 46a and the NO photodonor 47 (Figure 21), both remaining intact inside the polymer matrix, upon visible light irradiation generate ROS and NROS, respectively. Moreover when illuminated by 470 and 650 nm light, they emit simultaneously green and red fluorescence. Therefore, this supramolecular system can function by a cooperative PDT mode, and it has also the potential for image-guided bimodal PDT treatment.
    Various polymers have been tested as drug carriers for PDT, especially copolymers forming hydrophobic domains that can host hydrophobic drugs. Such a vehicle is the polymer constructed from ethylcellulose-graft-poly(ε-caprolactone) (EC-g-PLC) and αCD hosts. PLC moieties thread in αCD molecules (Figure 22) generating hydrophilic pseudorotaxanes.(157) Due to its amphiphilic nature, the supramolecular polymer forms micelles (mean diameter 90 nm), with a rather rigid EC core and a hydrophilic exterior comprising the pseudorotaxanes, able to entrap efficiently pTHPP, a photosensitizer of low aqueous solubility. This vehicle exhibits controlled release of pTHPP, triggered by the addition of the amino acid l-phenylalanine (Phe). Thus, in 1.5 h more than 50% of pTHPP is released (>85% in 6 h) in the presence of Phe in aqueous solution, in contrast to less than 26% during 300 h in its absence. It is proposed that release of the PS from the micelles’ core proceeds by diffusion in the absence of Phe, whereas in its presence, Phe competes with PLC for inclusion in the αCD cavity and destroys the pseudorotaxanes by abstracting αCD molecules; thus it makes the outer shell of the micelles more hydrophobic and easier for pTHPP to diffuse out. In vitro studies on breast tumor cells MCF7 demonstrate that the system can be internalized and it does not exhibit dark toxicity. However, upon UV irradiation (400 nm), it shows high toxicity depending on the amount of pTHPP in the micelles. The observed cell death can be modulated by the triggering effect of Phe, being higher by increasing the release of pTHPP.
    Drug release of the load is achieved by a supramolecular nanoassembly based on αCD and the diblock copolymers of PLC and methoxy poly(ethylene glycol) (mPEG) covalently bound to the four hydroxyethyloxyphenyl groups of THEPP (Figure 3), which transforms THEPP to the star-shaped amphiphilic porphyrin derivative 48 that organizes into micelles.(158) Similar micelles result if the anticancer drug DOX is added during the preparation of the micelles (Figure 23). The micelles’ core is organized by π–π stacking interactions among porphyrin moieties and DOX molecules. By mixing aqueous solutions of the micelles with αCD, threading of the mPEG region of the copolymer to the αCD molecules takes place inducing formation of pseudopolyrotaxanes, which prompt transformation of the micelles to a supramolecular hydrogel. The stability of the hydrogel depends on the molar ratio of the copolymer/αCD. In vitro studies demonstrate overall sustained release of DOX, attributed to slow disassembly of the hydrogel, as compared to a higher release from the micelles. The DOX-loaded hydrogel 48/αCD system shows efficient generation of 1O2 via the embedded porphyrin; thus it can be used for a bimodal function, PDT upon irradiation at 650 nm and chemotherapy by the DOX release, which can be sustained for up to a month.
    Controlled release of the load is achieved also by a nanoassembly based on the polyamidoamine dendrimer PAMAM,(159) if it is modified by replacing part of its amine end-groups by βCD moieties in order to reduce its toxicity and enhance its encapsulation ability. Indeed the resulting nanoassembly can encapsulate the poorly soluble PS hematoporphyrin (HP), as well as indocyanine green (ICG) (Figure 10), a photothermal agent approved by FDA. ICG upon irradiation with 808 nm laser light converts its energy to heat and causes local hyperthermia killing tumor cells (PTT), while it gradually degrades. Coexistence of HP and ICG in the same carrier causes quenching of HP fluorescence, depending on the relative ratio HP/ICG. At a ratio 1/10, the HP fluorescence is almost completely quenched (87.3%), probably due to energy transfer between HP and ICG. However, upon irradiation with 808 nm laser light, ICG causes hyperthermia and degrades, while the HP fluorescence recovers, along with its photodynamic activity by irradiation at 660 nm. In vitro studies on the human breast cancer cell line MCF7 demonstrate that the system exhibits low dark toxicity, but if the hyperthermia-controlled PDT mode is applied, that is, irradiation first at 808 nm and then at 660 nm, its phototoxicity is much higher than the individual PTT or PDT modes, its effect induced by cell apoptosis. The approach is similar to a previous use of βCD modified PAMAM, which encapsulates ICG and DOX, whose release is triggered by local hyperthermia and ICG degradation.(160) Therefore, ICG can be used as PTT agent for PDT and chemotherapy activation.
    A thermosensitive hydrogel has been prepared as in the previous case using a different photosensitizer, TCPP modified into the star-shaped porphyrin 49 by linking to PEG moieties, as in the case of 48 (Figure 23). By mixing 49 with multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) and subsequently with αCD, a nanocomposite is prepared(161) that shows appropriate characteristics for in situ monitoring in biomedical applications.(162,163) The PEG moieties thread in αCD macrocycles rendering the 49/αCD/MWNT composite water-soluble and transforming it into a thermosensitive injectable hydrogel. In vivo experiments on nude mice demonstrate that the location of the hydrogel can be tracked in real time, due to the TCPP fluorescence. The MWNTs on the other hand can be used for encapsulation and controlled release of a drug. Irradiation of the loaded nanocomposite with a NIR laser (808 nm) induces a photothermal effect from the carbon nanotubes, which results in disintegration of the hydrogel and release of the load subsequently. Thus, the combination of MWNTs and TCPP in the hydrogel allow for photothermal delivery of load at will and simultaneous tracking of the PS location in vivo.
    Biocompatible hydrogels are generated from alginates, polysaccharide polymers(164) produced from brown algae, which form hydrogels by ionic cross-linking in the presence of divalent cations. Dry foams of alginates have been evaluated as carriers for delivery of photosensitizers for aPDT on infected wounds using THPP as a model PS.(165) Cross-linked alginates are mixed with THPP, along with poloxamer PF127 (a micelle forming triblock copolymer of propylene and ethylene oxides acting both as foaming agent and THPP solubilizer). The cyclodextrin derivatives rMeβCD, HPβCD, and 2,6-DMβCD have been tested in the quadruple alginate/THPP/PF127/CD assemblies in various well-defined ratios, either in addition to or instead of PF127 in order to alleviate aggregation of the THPP through inclusion complex formation. CDs and poloxamer maintain their integrity in the foam. The three βCD derivatives have the same influence on the release properties and photostability of THPP; thus they are suitable for topical photoantimicrobial treatment in wounds. The foams are suitable for carrying hydrophobic drugs and disintegrate quickly in water and PBS. The release rate of the PS can be controlled by the degree of cross-linking of the alginates and the amount of CD in the foam, according to the need.
    Chitosan (CH) is another inexpensive nontoxic biodegradable polymer (glucosamine polysaccharide) produced from crustacean shells that has been used as a carrier for Chla for aPDT. However, CH is soluble in acidic media, where Chla degrades. Treatment of CH with HPβCD results in their cross-linking and formation of films enriched in HPβCD cavities, which entrap Chla from an ethanolic solution without destroying its chemical and photosensitizing properties.(166) The end result is formation of photosensitizing films containing Chla stable at pH 6. The films are meant as active antimicrobial packaging material. Their extensive characterization demonstrates that Chla is distributed uniformly in the film and associates with the amino groups of chitosan. Moreover, irradiation of the films by 355 nm visible light generates 1O2;(167) therefore it has the potential to be used for aPDT. It has also been demonstrated that the biodegradable films are efficient in keeping food on the shelf safely, because the ROS generated by Chla diffuse out of the films and react with dangerous substances present in aqueous solutions, for example, with anthracene used as a model of a toxic compound.
    Different approaches(168) intend to develop aPDT for topical infections, such as on medical devices, by bacteria, such as the Gram-positive S. aureus and the Gram-negative Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Treatment of a nonwoven polypropylene fabric with HPβCD and citric acid produces a citric acid–HPβCD polymer cross-linked to the fabric, which can be loaded with TPPS located mostly inside the HPβCD cavities. Although the TPPS-loaded fabric releases 50% of its content in PBS solution within 1 h, TPPS release is sustained over the next 2 days. Incubation of bacterial suspensions with the loaded fabric and subsequent irradiation by visible light shows that 99.98% of the S. aureus cells are dead and that no live bacteria are detected on the fabric after 30 min of irradiation. This suggests that the fabric is suitable for controlling S. aureus bacteria. In contrast, the fabric is not effective for P. aeruginosa cells, since they are not affected under the same conditions and the number of live cells adhered on the fabric is the same as before the irradiation. This result is in accord to previous observation that the Gram-negative bacteria are more tolerant to aPDT.(90)
    The following 2-D and 3-D nanoarchitectures are examples of stimuli responsive nanoplatforms of various degrees of complexity utilizing CD and porphyrinoid PSs designed for photodynamic processes.
    The continuous advance in the synthesis of nanographenes and their water-soluble derivatives explains their potential for use in nanomedicine. Graphene oxide (GO), a single-atomic-layered oxidized form of graphene with extended π-conjugation and dispersible in water has been developed into a multimodal carrier for PDT(169) (Figure 24). TPP monomodified by an ADA moiety (50) forms an inclusion complex with a modified βCD (51) linked to FA on the primary side. PS molecules 50 adhere on the surface of GO by π–π interactions. By the same interactions, GO can also carry the anticancer drug DOX. The βCD host 51 is attached on the 50/DOX/GO carrier by inclusion of ADA endowing the nanocarrier with FA targeting groups for FA-(+) HeLa tumor cells, into which the nanostructured carrier is internalized. Subsequently, DOX is released in the acidic environment of the cells. Upon irradiation with visible light, the nanosystem shows the same anticancer activity as free DOX, but it exhibits lower toxicity. Incubation of FA-(−) malignant cells (mouse osteoblasts cell lines OCT-1) with 51/50/DOX/GO for 24 h demonstrates that it is not toxic, which suggests the same behavior toward normal cells under the same conditions. Moreover, in vivo tests on BALB/c nude mice containing HeLa tumor cells have shown that the tumor-growth inhibition of the system is 71% on the 20th day (46% for the free DOX treatment) with no death of mice after 4 weeks and good physical appearance of the animals, whereas in the free DOX treatment only 30% of mice have survived after 27 days, albeit with severe weight loss.
    A related 2-D assembly is based on hexa-cata-hexabenzocoronene considered a molecular nanographene. TMβCD covalently bound to hexa-cata-hexabenzocoronene results in derivative 52, which forms stable inclusion complexes with TPPS in aqueous solution.(170) The assembly exhibits high DNA photocleavage and has potential for PDT use due to extensive energy transfer from nanographene to TPPS.
    Cyclodextrin inclusion complexes have been used to modify the surface of gadolinium upconversion NPs (UCNPs, vide supra) in order to render them suitable for biomedical use, that is, to make them soluble in aqueous media and diminish their toxicity and immunogenicity.(98) Thus, the UCNPs’ surface has been directly conjugated to the carboxyl groups of CarβCD (Figure 1) macrocycles, which form stable and strong inclusion complexes with the ADA-modified Zn(II)-Pc photosensitizer 53 in order to position the PS very close to the UCNP core. This is a very crucial requirement given the short half-life of 1O2 in aqueous solutions, during which the ROS diffuse over very short distance (<100 nm). The [email protected]βCD/53 NPs (85 nm) form a homogeneous dispersion in aqueous solutions and exhibit a strong PDT activity triggered by NIR light (980 nm) as demonstrated by 1O2 generation. The nanoparticles are internalized in HeLa cells and localized in the cytosol, causing very high cell death. The [email protected]βCD nanoplatform can be used not only for photodynamic treatment triggered by NIR irradiation but also as drug carrier due to the CD cavities.
    Mesoporous silica (MS) provides a matrix of controlled pore size where molecules of various sizes can be enclosed, and therefore it can be used as a drug carrier. MS structure offers high potential and flexibility to design and prepare sophisticated platforms for tackling various diseases preferentially by combining several modalities acting in a synergistic fashion. In the following example, MS is used to coat gold nanorods (AuNRs), which have been proven very effective for PTT.(171) The resulting [email protected] NPs are less toxic than free AuNRs, and they constitute a nanoplatform for PTT, PDT, and chemotherapy for tumor treatment. The MS pores enclose the PS, Al(III)-phthalocyanine chloride tetrasulfonic acid (46b, Figure 25). The MS surface is bound to the prodrug 54, cisplatin coordinated at one axial position by a redox-cleavable linker bound to Si atoms on the MS surface, while the second axial ligand contains the same linker bound to TMβCD. In addition, the TMβCD cavities host two different polymers anchored by their end-attached ADA moieties. The PEG polymer (ADA-PEG) endows the loaded [email protected] with ability for long circulation in the organism, and the lactobionic acid (LA) polymer (ADA-LA) provides tumor targeting ability. The fully loaded assembly is stable, not releasing 46b, whereas under reducing conditions, as inside tumor cells, the redox-cleavable linkers break and trigger release of cisplatin, TMβCD, and the entrapped PS 46b. The release proves that the TMβCD molecules act as “gate keepers” of the pores retaining the PS inside them. The MS nanopores, where the PS is entrapped, can serve for entrapping anticancer drugs simultaneously. In vitro trials of fully loaded [email protected] show that they selectively target hepatoma cells, HepG2, via the ADA-LA moieties. Upon single laser irradiation either at NIR 808 nm (PTT effect) or at 660 nm (PDT effect), cell death is similar, whereas by dual irradiation at 808 and 660 nm simultaneously, the synergistic PTT and PDT effect is much enhanced (cell survival 8%). In vivo experiments on HepG2 tumor-bearing nude mice demonstrate that fully loaded [email protected] accumulate significantly in the tumor as opposed to the main organs, and after dual laser irradiation as above, tumor growth is severely reduced. Moreover, it has been determined that the mechanism of enhanced tumor suppression is by apoptosis and the treatment does not have adverse effects on the major organs. This study is based on a smart design of synergistic phototreatment enriched with targeting and controlled release function that has been concluded with animal experiments.
    The following nanoplatform is the inverse of the previous one.(172) It is constructed using MS nanorods (MSNRs) covered by a shell of gold nanoparticles ([email protected]) for PTT/PDT bimodal cancer therapy and quadmodal imaging, that is, near-infrared fluorescence (NIRF)/multispectral optoacoustic tomography (MSOT)/computed tomography (CT)/magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), in order to accurately guide the therapy. Gd(III)-TPPS is used as PS, as well as for MR imaging. Mono(6-mercapto-6-deoxy)-βCD (55) molecules attached on the surface of gold by Au–S bonds serve as hosts for Gd(III)-TPPS (Figure 26). In vitro testing on 4T1 cancer cells demonstrates that cell death is enhanced (cell survival 33%) upon dual laser irradiation at 808 nm (PTT) and 660 nm (PDT) simultaneously compared to the single PTT or PDT effects. In vivo experiments on 4T1 tumor-bearing nude mice under quadmodal, imaging-guided monitoring in real time demonstrate that the nanoassemblies accumulate significantly on the tumor. After dual laser irradiation as above and the end of treatment (21 days), the tumor volume was severely reduced, weight of the mice increased normally, and the survival rate was 80%. Moreover, no adverse effects on the major organs have been observed after the above bimodal treatment with the optimal formulation.
    Mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs) have been used in another nanoplatform (100 nm) for multimodal function (Figure 27).(173) Azobenzene (AZO) was covalently attached on the surface of MSNPs via a cis-S–C═C–S- linker cleavable by 1O2. Ce6 was absorbed by the AZO decorated NPs and was able to generate 1O2 upon irradiation. When βCD was introduced into the platform, it formed inclusion complexes with the AZO moieties, thus blocking the MSNP nanopores acting as “gate keeper”. The nanoplatform design has the advantage of loading the nanopores (ca. 2.7 nm) before blocking (e.g., with an anticancer drug). Indeed, if a model cargo such as rhodamine B (RhB) is loaded in the pores, it is not released in the dark. However, upon irradiation of the platform with 660 nm laser light, Ce6 is excited producing 1O2 that breaks the bond between AZO and the MSNP surface opening the pores and subsequently releasing RhB (43% in 4 h to 62.5% in 24 h). The FA-βCD derivative (51, Figure 24) has been used as “gate-keeper” for in vitro trials on HeLa cells overexpressing FA receptors. In this case, the pores have been loaded with calcein as a model cargo. Calcein has been used because of its strong fluorescence, by which the MSNPs’ position can be located in the cell. The 1O2 generated by irradiation at 660 nm releases calcein due to breaking of the AZO linkers, as above. The viability of HeLa cells is ca. 20% after a 3 min irradiation with a very small laser dose in the red part of the spectrum, which is very encouraging for further optimization of this system.
    Another multimodal nanoplatform involves also MSNPs (ca. 50 nm), in the pores of which the anticancer prodrug tirapazamine (TPZ, Figure 11) can be hosted ([email protected]).(174) TPZ generates deleterious radicals in a hypoxic environment. The photosensitizer TPPS is entrapped into TMβCD hosts (Figure 28), which are grafted on the negatively charged HA polymer (TPPS/TMβCD-HA). Before loading TPZ inside the nanopores, the surface of the MSNPs is functionalized with NH2 groups and after TPZ loading, the MSNPs are covered by multiple layers of the anionic polymer TPPS/TMβCD-HA that are electrostatically adhered. The coverage results in blocking TPZ release. The [email protected] platform is further built up for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) by use of Gd(III)-TPPS ([email protected]–Gd(III)-TPPS/TMβCD-HA). The latter enriched with the MRI modality has been used to target human breast adenocarcinoma cells MCF7 overexpressing the CD44 receptor and upregulating hyaluronidase (HAase), as well as squamous-cell carcinoma cells SCC7. Indeed the NPs are preferentially internalized by both cell lines in endo- or lysosomes. The HAase degrades HA and consequently the Gd(III)-TPPS/TMβCD-HA layers liberating both TPZ and the Gd(III)-TPPS/TMβCD complex. In vitro trials on both cell lines show that upon laser irradiation (660 nm) the loaded [email protected] produce ROS, which induce endo- and lysosome disruption and a hypoxic microenvironment in the cell cytoplasm, thus activating the TPZ molecules for additional ROS production (bioreductive chemotherapy). The cells are severely damaged, in contrast to normal cells. Cell survival is 12.4% at 21% partial pressure of O2 (pO2) and 6.5% at pO2 3% demonstrating that PDT has limited effect in the higher hypoxic environment, but the bioreductive effect acts synergistically resulting in higher cytotoxic effect. In vivo trials on SCC7 tumor-bearing nude mice have exhibited the highest antitumor effect due to the synergistic effect of PDT and bioreductive chemotherapy, that is, lack of tumor growth in mice that underwent irradiation at 660 nm (PDT) followed by induction of hypoxia and activation of TPZ. The above treatment causes the highest percentage of apoptotic cell death compared to other treatment modes. Furthermore, it can take place under dual imaging, MRI and NIR fluorescence (650–750 nm), simultaneously.

    4. Conclusions and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The ability of CDs to encapsulate pharmaceutical and therapeutic agents is the driving force for the development of porphyrinoid–CD assemblies. The CDs provide the appropriate hydrophobic environment that protects the tetrapyrrole core of porphyrinoids and their metal complexes from oxidation and prevents porphyrin–porphyrin interactions while simultaneously rendering them soluble in aqueous media. In the biomimetic systems, the CD environment mimics the protein part of porphyrinoid-containing proteins. The literature demonstrates that carefully designed porphyrinoid–CD biomimetic systems are required for catalyzing specific chemical reactions. The task entails tedious synthetic and purification steps, and each system applies only to specific suitable substrates. In spite of the imaginative designs, not all the proposed systems have been successful. Moreover, their design probably did not allow for further optimization and development, since no follow up studies have been found in the literature. However, niche applications could occasionally emerge that would offer alternatives to specific problems, for example, decontamination of soils. On the other hand, the hemoprotein models developed by Kano et al., based exclusively on easily synthesized TMβCD dimers in complex with iron coordinated TPPS, have produced very promising results (e.g., antidotes for cyanide poisoning and carbon monoxide intoxication) that could lead to their use in the clinic. The advantage of the proposed hemoprotein models is that they are single isomer compounds with good aqueous solubility and medium molecular weight, likely to possess satisfactory ADMET (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion and toxicity) characteristics; thus one could anticipate a translational step for these systems in the future.
    CDs are also appropriate vehicles for third generation porphyrinoid PSs, especially in phototherapy for cancer. In addition to alleviating the porphyrinoids’ aggregation in aqueous solutions and enhancing their photophysical properties, CDs can combine a palette of properties: they can be modified with targeting moieties to direct the PS selectively to the tumors; they can carry fluorescent labels and anticancer drugs, either enclosed in their cavities or covalently bound; they can also carry appropriate groups that enhance internalization into cells. Such PS–CD combination systems are also shown to influence the mechanism of uptake as well as that of intracellular localization and fate. The latter can inspire improvements in drug delivery (e.g., to implement PCI applications) or in combinatory implementation of light wavelengths (for PDT and PTT). Among the PS–CD systems, conjugates have the advantage of well determined composition and purity and the disadvantage that optimization of their structure and properties requires new design and synthesis. The supramolecular systems are the most promising, because they can be manipulated and optimized easily in order to achieve release of the PS and drug in specific place and time (spatiotemporal control). Research with the simplest and less expensive such systems, inclusion complexes of CD derivatives with high aqueous solubility (HPβCD, TMβCD, rMeβCD), attracts interest even recently and has produced some methods for quantitative determination of the PS in serum; however their potential is limited. On the other hand, amphiphilic CD derivatives, as well as CD polymers or CDs grafted onto polymers that can bind porphyrinoids either covalently or supramolecularly form interesting assemblies, usually nanoparticles. These are internalized readily into cells and subsequently release their cargo triggered by a stimulus, such as irradiation, the acidic pH in the interior of tumor cells, or increase of temperature. The idea of suitable linear chains in the supramolecular system in order to thread into αCD molecules leads to generation of hydrogels, where noticeably, the release of the cargo is proportional to the amount of the αCD present, because this affects the amphiphilicity and therefore the robustness of the whole system. The most sophisticated porphyrinoid–CD assemblies for therapeutic and diagnostic use in photomedicine are the nanoplatforms, 2-D and 3-D nanoarchitectures designed to be stimuli responsive. Their development is based a great deal on MSNPs and their property to be loaded with drugs that are kept locked in the pores by “door keepers” until a specific stimulus removes the latter. These biocompatible smart nanomaterials and nanoplatforms are designed to enable controlled release of their therapeutic load(s) at a specific location in the cell in order to have the maximum effect. Further, they are able to carry systems for synergistic actions, that is, PDT, PTT, and chemotherapeutics and imaging. Many of the above systems have been proven successful, but they are still in the proof-of-concept stage. Indeed, the vast majority of the reviewed systems have been tested on 2-D cell cultures. As a closer alternative to tumor tissues, the use of 3-D cultures (spheroids) is proposed in order to take the in vitro evaluation of the PS-CD systems a step closer to in vivo experiments. For some of the discussed systems, animal studies are also reported, a necessary step toward preclinical studies. For successful translation of the porphyrinoid–CD systems, especially the multicomponent assemblies, there are two requirements of paramount importance, to be constitutionally stable, with preparation processes repeatable and efficient regardless of the sophistication and complexity of their design, and to be produced in large scale. Except for all the above criteria, more research is needed in order to answer several questions for the promising systems: Do they survive without disintegration in biological fluids? Are they internalized also by normal cells, for example, in a coculture? Which route of administration is targeted? In addition, the future developments for phototreatment of tumors require more selective PS uptake and faster accumulation in the tumors combined with faster clearance from the body to reduce photosensitivity. Some porphyrinoid–CD systems may contribute toward these goals.
    Summarizing, the porphyrinoid–CD systems presented in this Perspective illustrate many innovative approaches, a wide spectrum of methods, and a multidisciplinary research effort for drug delivery development. Translation from the laboratory to the clinic is a challenge requiring additional assessment of chemical and photochemical stability, of systemic biocompatibility and toxicity, and of immunological tolerance among others. These requirements follow the premise for repeatability of preparations, precise physicochemical characterization of the proposed molecules, supramolecular compounds, assemblies, and platforms, and reproducibility of dose–response results. The research has matured enough, and one or two examples can translate from the proof of concept phase into the development of new pharmaceutical products.

    Author Information

      1. 1
        Crini, G. G. Review: A History of cyclodextrins. Chem. Rev. 2014, 114, 10940– 10975,  DOI: 10.1021/cr500081p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Review: A History of Cyclodextrins
        Crini, Gregorio
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 114 (21), 10940-10975CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A discussion of the history of cyclodextrins is presented, describing the 120 years from discovery to development to the process of application.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFyrsLnP&md5=eefa7d9c4e06e877eb846a5857423ddb
      2. 2
        Makedonopoulou, S.; Mavridis, I. M. Structure of the inclusion complex of β-cyclodextrin with 1,12-dodecanedioic acid using synchrotron radiation data; a detailed dimeric β-cyclodextrin structure. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B: Struct. Sci. 2000, B56, 322– 331,  DOI: 10.1107/S0108768199014494
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Structure of the inclusion complex of β-cyclodextrin with 1,12-dodecanedioic acid using synchrotron radiation data; a detailed dimeric β-cyclodextrin structure
        Makedonopoulou, Stella; Mavridis, Irene M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section B: Structural Science (2000), B56 (2), 322-331CODEN: ASBSDK; ISSN:0108-7681. (Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.)
        A detailed crystal structure study of the dimeric inclusion complex of β-cyclodextrin (βCD) with 1,12-dodecanedioic acid (2:1) is presented. The structure was solved with synchrotron high-resoln. data (0.65 Å) at 100 K [crystal data: space group P1, Z = 1, a 18.153(7), b 15.456(8), c 15.251(4) Å, α 102.81(2), β 113.13(2), γ 99.90(3)°, R = 0.0474 for 25,134 reflections]. Also, the room-temp. structure was used for comparison [crystal data: space group P1, Z = 1, a 18.220(3), b 15.488(3), c 15.409(3) Å, α 102.903(6), β 113.122(5), γ 99.708(5)°, R = 0.0828 for 8235 reflections]. Combining the high-resoln. data and the low-temp. made possible the location of the disordered guest mol., 1,12-dodecanedioic acid, inside the wide cavity of the macrocycle formed by two βCD monomers. Also, almost all the H atoms of the βCD macrocycle and many of the H2O mols. were located in the low-temp. structure. Thus, for the 1st time, it was possible to show in detail only given by neutron diffraction data, that two βCD monomers self-assemble through O3...O3 intermol. H bonds to form the βCD dimer, as well as describe the H-bonding scheme between the dimer's hydroxyl groups among themselves and with H2O mols. in the lattice. The long guest threads through two host mols. forming a [3]pseudo-rotaxane. Its polar carboxyl groups, fully hydrated at the primary faces of the βCD dimers, influence their packing so that those faces are exposed to the solvent. This is in contrast to the packing of the β-cyclodextrin complexes of the corresponding aliph. monoacids, where the dimeric complexes form channels to isolate the terminal Me group from the H2O environment of the lattice.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXivVejt7k%253D&md5=da1d7bc020b383ef39c6c7d332934329
      3. 3
        Jansook, P.; Ogawa, N.; Loftsson, T. Cyclodextrins: structure, physicochemical properties and pharmaceutical applications. Int. J. Pharm. 2018, 535, 272– 284,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijpharm.2017.11.018
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Cyclodextrins: structure, physicochemical properties and pharmaceutical applications
        Jansook, Phatsawee; Ogawa, Noriko; Loftsson, Thorsteinn
        International Journal of Pharmaceutics (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2018), 535 (1-2), 272-284CODEN: IJPHDE; ISSN:0378-5173. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Since their discovery over 100 years ago cyclodextrins (CDs) have been the subject of numerous scientific publications. In 2016 alone CDs were the subject of over 2200 research articles published in peer-reviewed journals and mentioned in over 2300 patents and patent applications, many of which were on pharmaceutical applications. Natural CDs and their derivs. are used as enabling pharmaceutical excipients that enhance aq. soly. of poorly sol. drugs, increase drug permeability through biol. membranes and improve drug bioavailability. Unlike conventional penetration enhancers, their hydrophilic structure and high mol. wt. prevents them from penetrate into lipophilic membranes leaving biol. membranes intact. The natural CDs and some of their derivs. have monographs in pharmacopeias and are also commonly used as food additives and in toiletry products. CDs form inclusion complexes with lipophilic moieties of hydrophobic drugs. Furthermore, CDs are able to form non-inclusion complexes and self-assembled aggregates; small and large complex aggregates with micellar-like structures that can enhance drug soly. Excipients commonly used in pharmaceutical formulations may have additive or inhibiting effect on the CD solubilization. Here various methods used to investigate CD aggregate formation are reviewed as well as techniques that are used to increase the solubilizing effects of CDs; methods that enhance the apparent intrinsic soly. of drugs and/or the complexation efficacy and decrease the amt. of CD needed to develop CD-contg. pharmaceutical formulations. It will be explained how too much or too little CD can hamper drug bioavailability, and the role of CDs in solid dosage forms and parenteral formulations, and examples given on how CDs can enhance drug delivery after ocular, nasal and pulmonary administration.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvVajtrzP&md5=0d39c113d6aa80d9f77eae2bd81d4734
      4. 4
        Adam, J. M.; Bennett, D. J.; Bom, A.; Clark, J. K.; Feilden, H.; Hutchinson, E. J.; Palin, R.; Prosser, A.; Rees, D. C.; Rosair, G. M.; Stevenson, D.; Tarver, G. J.; Zhang, M.-Q. Cyclodextrin-derived host molecules as reversal agents for the neuromuscular blocker rocuronium bromide: synthesis and structure-activity relationships. J. Med. Chem. 2002, 45, 1806– 1816,  DOI: 10.1021/jm011107f
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Cyclodextrin-Derived Host Molecules as Reversal Agents for the Neuromuscular Blocker Rocuronium Bromide: Synthesis and Structure-Activity Relationships
        Adam, Julia M.; Bennett, D. Jonathan; Bom, Anton; Clark, John K.; Feilden, Helen; Hutchinson, Edward J.; Palin, Ronald; Prosser, Alan; Rees, David C.; Rosair, Georgina M.; Stevenson, Donald; Tarver, Gary J.; Zhang, Ming-Qiang
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2002), 45 (9), 1806-1816CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of mono- and per-6-substituted cyclodextrin derivs. were synthesized as synthetic receptors (or host mols.) of rocuronium bromide, the most widely used neuromuscular blocker in anesthesia. By forming host-guest complexes with rocuronium, these cyclodextrin derivs. reverse the muscle relaxation induced by rocuronium in vitro and in vivo and therefore can be used as reversal agents of the neuromuscular blocker to assist rapid recovery of patients after surgery. Because this supramol. mechanism of action does not involve direct interaction with the cholinergic system, the reversal by these compds. is not accompanied by cardiovascular side effects usually attendant with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as neostigmine. The structure-activity relationships are consistent with this supramol. mechanism of action and are discussed herein. These include the effects of binding cavity size and hydrophobic and electrostatic interaction on the reversal activities of these compds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XitFahs78%253D&md5=4f120b5717a6e876c7859b0ff6f5ab26
      5. 5
        Stella, V. J.; He, Q. Cyclodextrins. Toxicol. Pathol. 2008, 36, 30– 42,  DOI: 10.1177/0192623307310945
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Cyclodextrins
        Stella, Valentino J.; He, Quanren
        Toxicologic Pathology (2008), 36 (1), 30-42CODEN: TOPADD; ISSN:0192-6233. (Sage Publications)
        A review. β-Cyclodextrin (β-CD) and other cyclodextrins (CDs) have utility for solubilizing and stabilizing drugs; however, some are nephrotoxic when administered parenterally. A no. of workers have attempted to identify, prep., and evaluate various CD derivs. with superior inclusion complexation and maximal in vivo safety for various biomedical uses. A systematic study led to SBE-β-CD (Captisol), a polyanionic variably substituted sulfobutyl ether of β-CD, as a non-nephrotoxic deriv. and HP-β-CD, a modified CD developed by Janssen. SBE-β-CD and HP-β-CD have undergone extensive safety studies and are currently used in six products approved by the Food and Drug Administration (four for Captisol and two for HP-β-CD). They are also in use in numerous clin. and preclin. studies. This article will focus on the issues that led to the development of these two CDs, their safety, characterization, and applications, and esp. their ability to improve drug delivery. SBE-β-CD interacts very well with neutral drugs to facilitate soly. and chem. stability, and because of its polyanionic nature, it interacts particularly well with cationic drugs. Complexes between SBE-β-CD and HP-β-CD and various drugs have been shown to rapidly dissoc. after parenteral drug administration, to have no tissue-irritating effects after i.m. dosing, and to result in superior oral bioavailability of poorly water-sol. drugs. The pharmacokinetics, tissue distribution, and cellular effects of some representative CDs, including SBE-β-CD and HP-β-CD, are reviewed. The safety profiles of CDs are discussed, with emphasis on the biol. effects of some CDs on the gastrointestinal tract, kidney, and reprodn. and development and the carcinogenic potential of CDs. In addn., human experience with CD derivs., specifically SBE-β-CD and HP-β-CD, indicates that these two CDs are well tolerated in humans and have no adverse effects on the kidneys or other organs following either oral or i.v. administration.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXkslKgsL4%253D&md5=3f36b5a2606ec5dff3f16befe30d37b6
      6. 6
        Davis, M. E.; Brewster, M. E. Cyclodextrin-based pharmaceutics: past, present and future. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2004, 3, 1023– 1035,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd1576
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Cyclodextrin-based pharmaceutics: past, present and future
        Davis, Mark E.; Brewster, Marcus E.
        Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2004), 3 (12), 1023-1035CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Cyclodextrins are cyclic oligomers of glucose that can form water-sol. inclusion complexes with small mols. and portions of large compds. These biocompatible, cyclic oligosaccharides do not elicit immune responses and have low toxicities in animals and humans. Cyclodextrins are used in pharmaceutical applications for numerous purposes, including improving the bioavailability of drugs. Current cyclodextrin-based therapeutics are described and possible future applications discussed. Cyclodextrin-contg. polymers are reviewed and their use in drug delivery presented. Of specific interest is the use of cyclodextrin-contg. polymers to provide unique capabilities for the delivery of nucleic acids.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVarsL3P&md5=fdfaacc5a49ac2ca23b81b4d0459e97c
      7. 7
        Oliveri, V.; Zimbone, S.; Giuffrida, M. L.; Bellia, F.; Tomasello, M. F.; Vecchio, G. Porphyrin Cyclodextrin conjugates modulate amyloid beta peptide aggregation and cytotoxicity. Chem. - Eur. J. 2018, 24, 6349– 6353,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201800807
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Porphyrin Cyclodextrin Conjugates Modulate Amyloid Beta Peptide Aggregation and Cytotoxicity
        Oliveri, Valentina; Zimbone, Stefania; Giuffrida, Maria Laura; Bellia, Francesco; Tomasello, Marianna Flora; Vecchio, Graziella
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2018), 24 (24), 6349-6353CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Although fibrillar amyloid beta peptide (Aβ) aggregates are one of the major hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease, increasing evidence suggests that sol. Aβ oligomers are the primary toxic species. Targeting the oligomeric species could represent an effective strategy to interfere with Aβ toxicity. The biol. properties of 5[4-(6-O-β-cyclodextrin)-phenyl],10,15,20-tri(4-hydroxyphenyl)-porphyrin and its zinc complex were tested, as new mols. that interact with Aβ and effectively prevent its cytotoxicity. The authors found that these systems can cross the cell membrane to deliver Aβ intracellularly and promote its clearance. The authors' results provide evidence for the use of cyclodextrin-porphyrin derivs. as a promising strategy to target amyloid aggregation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXnt1aqurk%253D&md5=346fc0674c20d85d0340b570cdbe0654
      8. 8
        Adeoye, O.; Cabral-Marques, H. Cyclodextrin nanosystems in oral drug delivery: A mini review. Int. J. Pharm. 2017, 531, 521– 531,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijpharm.2017.04.050
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Cyclodextrin nanosystems in oral drug delivery: A mini review
        Adeoye, Oluwatomide; Cabral-Marques, Helena
        International Journal of Pharmaceutics (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2017), 531 (2), 521-531CODEN: IJPHDE; ISSN:0378-5173. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Oral delivery of many therapeutic agents remains challenging due to gastric insoly./poor dissoln., inefficient intestinal permeability and pre-systemic inactivation. These problems limit the advantages of convenience and increased compliance they provide in the therapy of many chronic diseases. Cyclodextrin nanosystems have emerged as promising platforms for drug-specific construction of the oral delivery nanosystems able to optimize the desired physicochem. properties and pharmacokinetic parameters; without a compromise on safety. This review focuses on some recent and encouraging advances in the application of cyclodextrin nanosystems for oral drug delivery. A general overview of cyclodextrins and pharmaceutical nanotechnol. in oral delivery systems is provided. Some of the strategies being exploited for the synthesis of these nanosystems, and their potential for the intelligent navigation of the gastrointestinal tract for optimal bioavailability and biodistribution are then illustrated. Perspectives for translating these nanosystems from lab. efficient formulations to clin. useful medicines are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXnvFKitLw%253D&md5=efe9ade6c96d2377622acffdf76168e6
      9. 9
        Arima, H.; Motoyama, K.; Higashi, T. Potential use of cyclodextrins as drug carriers and active pharmaceutical ingredients. Chem. Pharm. Bull. 2017, 65, 341– 348,  DOI: 10.1248/cpb.c16-00779
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Potential use of cyclodextrins as drug carriers and active pharmaceutical ingredients
        Arima, Hidetoshi; Motoyama, Keiichi; Higashi, Taishi
        Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin (2017), 65 (4), 341-348CODEN: CPBTAL; ISSN:0009-2363. (Pharmaceutical Society of Japan)
        Cyclodextrins (CyDs) are extensively used in various fields, and esp. have been widely utilized as pharmaceutical excipients and drug carriers in the pharmaceutical field. Owing to the multi-functional and biocnmpatible characteristics, CyDs can improve the undesirable properties of drug mols. This review outlines the current application of CyDs in pharmaceutical formulations, focusing on their use as CyD-based drug carriers for several kinds of drugs. Addnl., CyDs have great potential as active pharmaceutical ingredients against various diseases with few side effects.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsVGgt7bL&md5=1ebef69686f2dca19d6cda6f4334cfef
      10. 10
        Zafar, N.; Fessi, H.; Elaissari, A. Cyclodextrin containing biodegradable particles: From preparation to drug delivery applications. Int. J. Pharm. 2014, 461, 351– 366,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijpharm.2013.12.004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Cyclodextrin containing biodegradable particles: From preparation to drug delivery applications
        Zafar, Nadiah; Fessi, Hatem; Elaissari, Abdelhamid
        International Journal of Pharmaceutics (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2014), 461 (1-2), 351-366CODEN: IJPHDE; ISSN:0378-5173. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Cyclodextrins (CDs) offer a very broad spectrum of applications in diverse fields of drug delivery. They are a family of cyclic α-(1-4)-linked oligosaccharides of α-D-glucopyranose subunits forming a more hydrophobic central cavity and a hydrophilic outer shell. CDs bear cage like supramol. structures, similar to calixarenes, cyclophanes and crown ethers. No covalent bonds are required to host a guest mol. in the central cavity. The aim of this review is to throw light on some of the applications and formulation techniques for the novel multifunctional CD based nanocarriers used in diverse areas of drug delivery. Furthermore, this article highlights the mol. structure, chem., complexation properties and the use of CDs in nanosystems like liposomes, magnetic nanoparticles, biodegradable polymers, micro and nanospheres and capsules.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVyis7s%253D&md5=3a94a39574a5cc6932e6f26070fb32bd
      11. 11
        Szejtli, J. Past, present, and future of cyclodextrin research. Pure Appl. Chem. 2004, 76, 1825– 1845,  DOI: 10.1351/pac200476101825
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Past, present, and future of cyclodextrin research
        Szejtli, Jozsef
        Pure and Applied Chemistry (2004), 76 (10), 1825-1845CODEN: PACHAS; ISSN:0033-4545. (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry)
        A review. The macrocyclic cyclodextrins (enzymic conversion products of starch) were discovered in 1891, and the structures were elucidated in the mid-1930s. Their industrial significance become obvious in the 1970s, and by now thousand of tons of the three cyclodextrins (α-, β-, and γCD) and of their chem. derivs. and inclusion complexes are produced industrially. The outer surface of these doughnut-shaped mols. is hydrophilic, but they possess an axial open cavity, which is of hydrophobic character and capable of including other apolar mols. (or their moiety) in case of geometric compatibility. This is the essence of mol. encapsulation by inclusion complex formation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVSntr3P&md5=23d5f270661d8055fe6153157a59a1d2
      12. 12
        Yannakopoulou, K.; Mentzafos, D.; Mavridis, I. M.; Dandika, K. Chiral recognition of (R)-(−)-1,7-dioxaspiro-[5.5]undecane by hexakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-α-cyclodextrin. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl. 1996, 35, 2480– 2482,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.199624801
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
