        Selective sepn. of (R)-(-)-1,7-dioxaspiro[5.5]undecane from its (S) enantiomer by inclusion complex formation with (2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-α-cyclodextrin, is reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XntFensbw%253D&md5=a197e17dc239784ca1afaa746d6153ec
      13. 13
        Badruddoza, A. Z. M.; Tay, A. S. H.; Tan, P. Y.; Hidajat, K.; Uddin, M. S. Carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin conjugated magnetic nanoparticles as nano-adsorbents for removal of copper ions: Synthesis and adsorption studies. J. Hazard. Mater. 2011, 185, 1177– 1186,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2010.10.029
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin conjugated magnetic nanoparticles as nano-adsorbents for removal of copper ions: Synthesis and adsorption studies
        Badruddoza, A. Z. M.; Tay, A. S. H.; Tan, P. Y.; Hidajat, K.; Uddin, M. S.
        Journal of Hazardous Materials (2011), 185 (2-3), 1177-1186CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A novel nano-adsorbent, carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles (CMCD-MNPs) is fabricated for removal of Cu from aq. solns. by grafting CM-β-CD onto the magnetite surface via carbodiimide method. The characteristics results of FTIR, TEM, TGA and XPS show that CM-β-CD is grafted onto Fe3O4 nanoparticles. The grafted CM-β-CD on the Fe3O4 nanoparticles contributes to an enhancement of the adsorption capacity because of the strong abilities of the multiple hydroxyl and carboxyl groups in CM-β-CD to adsorb metal ions. The adsorption of Cu2+ onto CMCD-MNPs is found to be dependent on pH and temp. Adsorption equil. is achieved in 30 min and the adsorption kinetics of Cu2+ followed a pseudo-2nd-order kinetic model. Equil. data for Cu2+ adsorption are fitted well by Langmuir isotherm model. The max. adsorption capacity for Cu2+ is estd. to be 47.2 mg/g at 25°. Thermodn. parameters reveal the feasibility, spontaneity and exothermic nature of the adsorption process. FTIR and XPS reveal that Cu2+ adsorption onto CMCD-MNPs mainly involves the oxygen atoms in CM-β-CD to form surface-complexes. The Cu can be desorbed from CMCD-MNPs by citric acid soln. with 96.2% desorption efficiency and the CMCD-MNPs exhibit good recyclability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsFCks7%252FF&md5=1e7e8801fcad56a6430c4d6c82413fa9
      14. 14
        Zhang, D.; Lv, P.; Zhou, C.; Zhao, Y.; Liao, X.; Yang, B. Cyclodextrin-based delivery systems for cancer treatment. Mater. Sci. Eng., C 2019, 96, 872– 886,  DOI: 10.1016/j.msec.2018.11.031
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Cyclodextrin-based delivery systems for cancer treatment
        Zhang, Dongjing; Lv, Pin; Zhou, Cheng; Zhao, Yulin; Liao, Xiali; Yang, Bo
        Materials Science & Engineering, C: Materials for Biological Applications (2019), 96 (), 872-886CODEN: MSCEEE; ISSN:0928-4931. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Cyclodextrins, one of safe excipients, are able to form host-guest complexes with fitted mols. given the unique nature imparted by their structure in result of a no. of pharmaceutical applications. On the other hand, targeted or responsive materials are appealing therapeutic platforms for the development of next-generation precision medications. Meanwhile, cyclodextrin-based polymers or assemblies can condense DNA and RNA in result to be used as genetic therapeutic agents. Armed with a better understanding of various pharmaceutical mechanisms, esp. for cancer treatment, researchers have made lots of works about cyclodextrin-based drug delivery systems in materials chem. and pharmaceutical science. This Review highlights recent advances in cyclodextrin-based delivery systems for cancer treatment capable of targeting or responding to the physiol. environment. Key design principles, challenges and future directions, including clin. translation, of cyclodextrin-based delivery systems are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitlOktrzP&md5=55e0be4b175e040d846cb966188911b9
      15. 15
        Dąbrowski, J. M.; Pucelik, B.; Regiel-Futyra, A.; Brindell, M.; Mazuryk, O.; Kyzioł, A.; Stochel, G.; Macyk, W.; Arnaut, L. G. Engineering of relevant photodynamic processes through structural modifications of metallotetrapyrrolic photosensitizers. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2016, 325, 67– 101,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ccr.2016.06.007
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Engineering of relevant photodynamic processes through structural modifications of metallotetrapyrrolic photosensitizers
        Dabrowski, Janusz M.; Pucelik, Barbara; Regiel-Futyra, Anna; Brindell, Malgorzata; Mazuryk, Olga; Kyziol, Agnieszka; Stochel, Grazyna; Macyk, Wojciech; Arnaut, Luis G.
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2016), 325 (), 67-101CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Applications of metalloporphyrins and related mols. have been extensively pursued in the context of photodynamic therapy of cancer (PDT) and other biomedical applications. This review discusses photophys. and photochem. properties of metalloporphyrins and their analogs, such as metallochlorins, metallobacteriochlorins and metallophthalocyanines that are relevant for photodynamic processes. We specially emphasize the search for sensitizers strongly absorbing in phototherapeutic window (650-850 nm), the most penetrating and least harmful radiation to human tissues. Mol. engineering is guided by the understanding of the influence of the central metal ion and substituents on the electronic structure and photophys. properties of these compds. The effects of the structural modifications are elucidated via studies of the electronic absorption and emission spectra, fluorescence and triplet state lifetimes and quantum yields, as well as quantum yields of singlet oxygen generation. The interaction between electronically excited (metallo)porphyrin derivs. and mol. oxygen is specially highlighted, because it leads to the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the major players in photomedicine and photocatalysis. The parameters analyzed and correlated encompass photophys. and electrochem. properties, cellular uptake and localization of the photosensitizer, as well as the mechanism of photodynamically induced cell death. The factors that det. the efficacy of PDT (drug and light doses, drug to light interval, oxygen concn. and tumor margin) are also emphasized. This review explores the most recent research performed on metalloporphyrin-based materials in photodynamic therapy, photodynamic inactivation of microorganisms, photodiagnosis and drug delivery, demonstrating their perspectives for biomedical applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVSgsrjM&md5=8a5e1abab69f79ba2a5019a4b88b0c05

        Kano, K.; Nishiyabu, R.; Asada, T.; Kuroda, Y. Static and dynamic behavior of 2:1 inclusion complexes of cyclodextrins and charged porphyrins in aqueous organic media. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2002, 124, 9937– 9944,  DOI: 10.1021/ja020253n
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Static and Dynamic Behavior of 2:1 Inclusion Complexes of Cyclodextrins and Charged Porphyrins in Aqueous Organic Media
        Kano, Koji; Nishiyabu, Ryuhei; Asada, Takuji; Kuroda, Yasuhisa
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (33), 9937-9944CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TMe-β-CD) mols. strongly include the peripheral substituents at the 5- and 15-positions of the charged meso-tetrasubstituted porphyrins, PorSub4 [TPPS4 (Sub = p-C6H4-SO3-), TPPOC3PS (p-C6H4-O-(CH2)3-p-C6H4-SO3-), TCPP (Sub = p-C6H4-CO2-), and TPPOC3Py (p-C6H4-O-(CH2)3-Py+Br-), where Py+ = N-alkylpyridinium] in aq. ethylene glycol. The binding consts. (K1 and K2) and the rate consts. (k1 and k2) for formation of the 1:1 and 2:1 complexes of TMe-β-CD and PorSub4 were detd. Both the binding consts. and the rate consts. for anionic TPPS4, TCPP, and TPPOC3PS were much larger than those for cationic TPPOC3Py. The smaller k1 and k2 values for TPPOC3Py indicate a higher barrier for penetration of a cationic guest into the TMe-β-CD cavity. The Me groups at the rims and the cavity wall of the host are pos. polarized due to the inductive effect of the ethereal oxygens. The pos. polarized rims and interior of the host cavity should prevent the penetration of the cationic substituent of TPPOC3Py into the TMe-β-CD cavity. The 2:1 TMe-β-CD-PorSub4 complexes are extraordinary stable in aq. solns., even in the case of cationic TPPOC3Py. Formation of both 1:1 and 2:1 complexes is promoted by neg. and large enthalpy changes, suggesting a strong van der Waals interaction as the main binding force.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlsFygtLw%253D&md5=092f63800caceded13d7a1721b416445

        Manka, J. S.; Lawrence, D. S. Template-driven self-assembly of a porphyrin-containing supramolecular complex. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1990, 112, 2440– 2442,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00162a066
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Template-driven self-assembly of a porphyrin-containing supramolecular complex
        Manka, John S.; Lawrence, David S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1990), 112 (6), 2440-2CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The template-driven self-assembly of a highly organized supramol. complex of meso-tetrakis[4-(3-aminopropoxy)phenyl]porphyrin with heptakis(2,6-di-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin is described. The multicomponent entity is composed of eleven sep. subunits and is synthesized in aq. soln. The porphyrin moiety is encased within a protective barrier that is circumscribed by a hydrophobic groove. The self-assembly process is not only efficient (85% yield) but offers unusual flexibility in the construction of a range of heme-dependent protein mimics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXhtlyrsrs%253D&md5=dd0e52b1502ed1100368b6ed7f71913b

        18
        Very strong binding and mode of complexation of water-soluble porphyrins with a permethylated β-cyclodextrin
        Carofiglio, Tommaso; Fornasier, Roberto; Lucchini, Vittorio; Rosso, Cristiana; Tonellato, Umberto
        Tetrahedron Letters (1996), 37 (44), 8019-8022CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier)
        Heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin in a pH=7.0 soln. binds meso-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin and its zinc complex to yield 2:1 complexes with exceptionally high binding consts. The mode of binding, involving the inclusion of two opposite aryl groups in the cyclodextrin cavity, is clearly defined by a detailed NMR anal.

        Dick, D. L.; Rao, T. V. S.; Sukumaran, D.; Lawrence, D. S. Molecular encapsulation: cyclodextrin-based analogues of heme-containing proteins. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992, 114, 2664– 2669,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00033a046
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Molecular encapsulation: cyclodextrin-based analogs of heme-containing proteins
        Dick, Diane L.; Rao, Tata Venkata S.; Sukumaran, Dinesh; Lawrence, David S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1992), 114 (7), 2664-9CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The active site heme prosthetic group of such species as Hb, the cytochrome P 450s, and the peroxidases is enveloped within a protective hydrophobic environment located adjacent to a binding site for exogenous compds. In addn. to providing these phys. attributes, the protein component also acts as a carrier, transporting the heme to the appropriate cellular environment. This proteinoid appendage was replaced with a cyclodextrin-based protective sheath to create artificial analogs of heme-contg. proteins. Encapsulated within this saccharide-coated barrier, the heme moiety exhibits many of the characteristics typically reserved for its naturally occurring protein-based counterparts.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xhs12msLY%253D&md5=35e757129ea522a94112809b877324b4

        Kano, K.; Nishiyabu, R.; Doi, R. Novel behavior of O-methylated β-cyclodextrins in inclusion of meso-tetraarylporphyrins. J. Org. Chem. 2005, 70, 3667– 3673,  DOI: 10.1021/jo0500535
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Novel Behavior of O-Methylated β-Cyclodextrins in Inclusion of meso-Tetra-Arylporphyrins
        Kano, Koji; Nishiyabu, Ryuhei; Doi, Ryoji
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70 (9), 3667-3673CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        The mechanism for formation of extremely stable 1:2 inclusion complexes of water-sol. meso-tetra-arylporphyrins with heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TMe-β-CD) in aq. solns. has been studied by means of NMR spectroscopy and iso-thermal titrn. calorimetry. To simplify the system, 5,10,15-tris(3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl)-20-phenylporphyrin (I) was used as a guest porphyrin, because I forms only a 1:1 inclusion complex with cyclodextrin (CD). As host compds., native β-CD and the O-methylated-β-CDs such as heptakis(2,3-di-O-methyl)- (2,3-DMe-β-CD), heptakis(2,6-di-O-methyl)- (2,6-DMe-β-CD), and TMe-β-CDs were used. The thermodn. parameters for complexation such as binding consts. (K) and enthalpy (ΔH°) and entropy changes (ΔS°) were detd. by means of isothermal titrn. calorimetry. The K value for complexation of I with CD increases in the order β-CD (K = (1.2 ± 0.1) × 103 M-1) < 2,6-DMe-β-CD ((1.2 ± 0.1) × 104 M-1) « TMe-β-CD ((6.9 ± 0.4) × 106 M-1) < 2,3-DMe-β-CD ((8.5 ± 0.5) × 106 M-1), indicating participation of the secondary OCH3 groups in extremely strong complexation of I with CD. Complex formation of I with β-CD and 2,6-DMe-β-CD is an enthalpically and entropically favorable process, while that with TMe-β-CD and 2,3-DMe-β-CD is an enthalpically much more favorable but an entropically less favorable process. The thermodn. parameters suggest that inclusion of I into the cavities of TMe-β-CD and 2,3-DMe-β-CD is promoted by van der Waals interactions, which are stronger than those in the cases of β-CD and 2,6-DMe-β-CD. 13C NMR spectra show that the conformations of both TMe-β-CD and 2,3-DMe-β-CD are altered upon inclusion of I, while those of β-CD and 2,6-DMe-β-CD are mostly retained. On the basis of these results, it can be concluded that induced-fit type complexation of I with TMe-β-CD and 2,3-DMe-β-CD causes extremely strong binding of the host to the guest.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXis1OjsL0%253D&md5=0f97cc993e31ea532368ebe865ff8459

        Tsuchiya, Y.; Yamano, A.; Shiraki, T.; Sada, K.; Shinkai, S. Single-crystal structure of porphyrin bicapped with trimethyl-β-cyclodextrins: a novel dye-oriented material. Chem. Lett. 2011, 40, 99– 101,  DOI: 10.1246/cl.2011.99
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Single-crystal structure of porphyrin bicapped with trimethyl-β-cyclodextrins: a novel dye-oriented material
        Tsuchiya, Youichi; Yamano, Akihito; Shiraki, Tomohiro; Sada, Kazuki; Shinkai, Seiji
        Chemistry Letters (2011), 40 (1), 99-101CODEN: CMLTAG; ISSN:0366-7022. (Chemical Society of Japan)
        Complexes formed between porphyrins and cyclodextrins are among the most fascinating targets of host-guest complexes. So far, the structural details have been discussed on the basis of the soln. properties. However, the real complex structure detd. from single-crystal anal. is not known up to the present. In this paper, we report the first successful example for formation of a single crystal and its X-ray anal. We believe that the resultant dye-oriented cryst. material would lead to novel host-guest chem. applicable to new photo and electronic devices.

      22. 22
        Tsuchiya, Y.; Shiraki, T.; Matsumoto, T.; Sugikawa, K.; Sada, K.; Yamano, A.; Shinkai, S. Supramolecular dye inclusion single crystals created from 2,3,6-trimethyl-β-cyclodextrin and porphyrins. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 456– 465,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201102075
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        Supramolecular Dye Inclusion Single Crystals Created from 2,3,6-Trimethyl-β-cyclodextrin and Porphyrins
        Tsuchiya, Youichi; Shiraki, Tomohiro; Matsumoto, Takashi; Sugikawa, Kouta; Sada, Kazuki; Yamano, Akihito; Shinkai, Seiji
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (2), 456-465, S456/1-S456/4CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        In Nature, chromophoric groups play various roles, such as oxygen carriers, electron donors, light sensitizers, which are achieved in many cases by control of their aggregation modes in proteins. Host-guest chem. between cyclodextrins and porphyrins has attracted great interest from supramol. chemists because of their unique structures and functions that mimic those of proteins with chromophoric prosthetic groups. To mimic Nature's contrivances, the host-guest systems between cyclodextrins and porphyrins have frequently been studied. It is really surprising, however, that to date no detailed structural information of these complexes has been obtained from single-crystal anal. In 2011, we reported the first successful isolation of a dye inclusion single crystal (DISC) between 2,3,6-trimethyl-β-cyclodextrin (TMβCD) and 5,10,15,20-tetrapyridylporphyrin (TPyP), and analyzed its X-ray crystal structure. The crystal structure revealed not only the real complex mode but also the attractive orientation of TPyP in the DISC. Herein, we present new strategies to prep. DISC's of TMβCD for several porphyrins and provide crystal structures, details of the complex modes, and optical properties. We believe that the present study has various important implications not only for the basic crystal anal. of inclusion complexes but also for potential applications that use these single crystals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1ertLvK&md5=c118fb8ee82908eee28c12e6cd0b7ace
      23. 23
        Makedonopoulou, S.; Yannakopoulou, K.; Mentzafos, D.; Lamzin, V.; Popov, A.; Mavridis, I. M. Non-covalent interactions in the crystallization of the enantiomers of 1,7-dioxaspiro[5.5]undecane (olive fly sex pheromone) by enantiospecific cyclodextrin hosts, hexakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-α-cyclodextrin and heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B: Struct. Sci. 2001, B57, 399– 409,  DOI: 10.1107/S0108768101001963
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Non-covalent interactions in the crystallization of the enantiomers of 1,7-dioxaspiro[5.5]undecane (olive fly sex pheromone) by enantiospecific cyclodextrin hosts, hexakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-α-cyclodextrin and heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin
        Makedonopoulou, Stella; Yannakopoulou, Konstantina; Mentzafos, Demetrios; Lamzin, Victor; Popov, Alexander; Mavridis, Irene M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section B: Structural Science (2001), B57 (3), 399-409CODEN: ASBSDK; ISSN:0108-7681. (Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.)
        The enantiomers of racemic olive fly sex pheromone 1,7-dioxaspiro[5.5]undecane [(±)-I] have been isolated by crystn. with enantiospecific cyclodextrin hosts: (S)-(I) crystallizes with heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TMβCD) and (R)-(II) with hexakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-α-cyclodextrin (TMαCD). The crystal structure of TMβCD/(S)-(I) from synchrotron radiation data at 100 K, detd. for the first time, proves that TMβCD crystallizes with only the (S)-enantiomer from the racemic mixt. Comparison with the 100 K structure of TMαCD/(R)-(II) redetd. with synchrotron data has provided insight into the interactions between each of the hosts with the corresponding enantiomeric guests. Owing to the high resoln. of the data and the unusually high quality of the crystals, localization of the H atoms has been achieved, a rare accomplishment for cyclodextrin X-ray structures. This made possible, apart from the geometry of the complexes, the detailed description of a five-membered-ring water cluster with very well ordered hydrogen bonding. The enantiospecificity exhibited by the described systems reveals the subtle differences of the weak intermol. forces involved in the selective binding of the two optical antipodes by the two hosts. The binding geometry in the two complexes is different, but it is effected in both by numerous host-guest C-H...O interactions, resulting from induced fit of the hosts toward each of the enantiomeric guests. In TMαCD/(R)-(II) two of these H...O host-guest distances, directed toward the acetal O atoms defining the chirality of the guest, are much shorter than the rest and also shorter than all the H...O distances in TMβCD/(S)-(I). Moreover, (R)-(II) interacts not only with the enclosing host, but with other hosts in the crystal lattice, in contrast to (S)-(I) in the TMβCD/(S)-(I) complex which is isolated inside channels formed by the host mols. The above differences are reflected in the much higher binding const. of TMαCD/(R)-(II) compared with that of TMβCD/(S)-(I) (∼6800 and ∼935 M-1, resp.), detd. by NMR in aq. soln., and the ability of TMαCD to selectively ppt. (R)-(II) from racemic-I in much higher yield than TMβCD ppts. (S)-(I).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjvVOrtbk%253D&md5=2283d92ada5875163aa92e176a89671d

        DeLano, W. L. PyMOL Molecular Graphics System; Delano Scientific LLC, San Carlos, CA, USA, 2002, http://www.pymol.org.

      25. 25
        Kryjewski, M.; Goslinski, T.; Mielcarek, J. Functionality stored in the structures of cyclodextrin–porphyrinoid systems. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2015, 300, 101– 120,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ccr.2015.04.009
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Functionality stored in the structures of cyclodextrin-porphyrinoid systems
        Kryjewski, Michal; Goslinski, Tomasz; Mielcarek, Jadwiga
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2015), 300 (), 101-120CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The binding of cyclodextrins and porphyrinoids (including porphyrins, phthalocyanines and chlorins) is carried out by both covalent linking or inclusion complexation. Many of the resulting structures possess intrinsic biomimetic functionality. Therefore, they have been investigated as biomimetics, which imitate some biochem. processes occurring in nature, such as carotene cleavage, cytochrome P 450-mediated hydroxylation, oxygen binding by Hb, or as components of multichromophoric arrays in light harvesting antenna systems. Interestingly enough, cyclodextrins improve porphyrinoids photosensitizing properties by increasing the values of singlet oxygen generation quantum yield which is of immense value for applications in photodynamic therapy. Noteworthy is the great potential for medical applications, revealed recently in the construction of sophisticated systems consisting of covalently linked cyclodextrins and photosensitizers that were considered as carriers for multimodal anticancer therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXotlWlur8%253D&md5=e9a2fc17837f1900cbb11932998b36ed

        [Crossref], Google Scholar

      27. 27
        Breslow, R.; Duggan, P. J.; Light, J. P. Cyclodextrin-B12, a potential enzyme-coenzyme mimic. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992, 114, 3982– 3983,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00036a059
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Cyclodextrin-B12, a potential enzyme-coenzyme mimic.
        Breslow, Ronald; Duggan, Peter J.; Light, James P.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1992), 114 (10), 3982-3CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Reaction of β-cyclodextrin-6-bromide with cobalamin produces cyclodextrinylcobalamin. In the base off form this can be isolated and characterized by MS and other spectroscopy, but at neutral pH and 25° it is quite labile, dissocg. to the cyclodextrinyl radical and B12(r). The cyclodextrinyl radical can abstr. an iodine or bromine atom or a selenophenyl group from substrates that can bind in the cavity. It can also initiate a free radical cyclization process. However, it has not yet been possible to confine radical reactions and intermediates in the cyclodextrin cavity, as a true enzyme-coenzyme mimic must. Even so, the much greater reactivity of cyclodextrinylcobalamin than of the coenzyme adenosylcobalamin makes this an interesting potential mimic.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38XitFCrsro%253D&md5=df064d0281da88c27d04a0aefecca05e

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Tetrahedron Letters (1997), 38 (33), 5763-5766CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier)
        Cobalamin covalently tethered to β-cyclodextrin was synthesized as a methylmalonyl-CoA mutase mimic. The artificial enzyme is capable of discriminating between these substrates contg. different binding groups.

        Yang, J.; Gabriele, B.; Belvedere, S.; Huang, Y.; Breslow, R. Catalytic oxidations of steroid substrates by artificial cytochrome P-450 enzymes. J. Org. Chem. 2002, 67, 5057– 5067,  DOI: 10.1021/jo020174u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Catalytic Oxidations of Steroid Substrates by Artificial Cytochrome P-450 Enzymes
        Yang, Jerry; Gabriele, Bartolo; Belvedere, Sandro; Huang, Ying; Breslow, Ronald
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2002), 67 (15), 5057-5067CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Catalysts comprising manganese-porphyrins carrying cyclodextrin binding groups are able to perform hydroxylations with substrate selectivity and regio- and stereoselectivity and high catalytic turnovers. The geometries of the catalyst/substrate complexes override intrinsic substrate reactivities, permitting attack on geometrically accessible satd. carbons of steroids in the presence of secondary carbinol groups and carbon-carbon double bonds, as in enzymic reactions. Selective hydroxylations of steroid carbon 9 positions are of particular practical interest.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xkt1Clt7w%253D&md5=83cd8eddc7b3292c5e22d9e5324c810e

        A manganese porphyrin-α-cyclodextrin conjugate as an artificial enzyme for the catalytic epoxidation of polybutadiene
        Zhang, Qi-Wei; Elemans, Johannes A. A. W.; White, Paul B.; Nolte, Roeland J. M.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2018), 54 (44), 5586-5589CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        We describe a manganese porphyrin-α-cyclodextrin conjugate as a catalyst for the epoxidn. of cis-polybutadiene with trans-epoxide preference, which is a reverse stereoselectivity as compared to normal porphyrin catalysts. A clamp-like mechanism is proposed based on a combination of CD anal., mol. modeling, and a series of epoxidn. expts.

        Supramolecular complex of cytochrome c with a polyanionic β-cyclodextrin
        Kano, Koji; Ishida, Yoshiyuki
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (5), 727-730, S727/1-S727/10CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A threesome: An anionic cyclodextrin binds electrostatically with cationic cytochrome c (K = 2.3 x 104 M-1, ΔH = 9.3 kJ mol-1, ΔS = 115 J mol-1 K-1). The cyclodextrin covers the hemin pockets of about two-thirds of the cyt c mols. This assocn. complex further complexes with a nonionic porphyrin to form a ternary complex in which static fluorescence quenching of the porphyrin by cyt c takes place.

        Zhang, X.-r.; Zhou, W.-x.; Zhang, Y.-x. Improvements in SOD mimic AEOL-10150, a potent broad-spectrum antioxidant. Mil. Med. Res. 2018, 5, 30,  DOI: 10.1186/s40779-018-0176-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Improvements in SOD mimic AEOL-10150, a potent broad-spectrum antioxidant
        Zhang Xiao-Rui; Zhou Wen-Xia; Zhang Yong-Xiang
        Military Medical Research (2018), 5 (1), 30 ISSN:.
        AEOL-10150 is a broad-spectrum metalloporphyrin superoxidase dismutase (SOD) mimic specifically designed to neutralize reactive oxygen and nitrogen species. Research has shown that AEOL-10150 is a potent medical countermeasure against national security threats including sulfur mustard (SM), nerve agent exposure and radiation pneumonitis following a radiological/nuclear incident sufficient to cause acute radiation syndrome (ARS). AEOL-10150 performed well in animal safety studies, and two completed phase 1 safety studies in patients demonstrated that the drug was safe and well tolerated, indicating that AEOL-10150 has potential as a new catalytic antioxidant drug. In this article, we review improvements in AEOL-10150 in preclinical pharmacodynamic studies, especially regarding anti-SM, chlorine gas and radiation exposure studies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3c3lvVagtA%253D%253D&md5=5ee39cd4af1509bd7787ee3674954bc1

        Oliveri, V.; Puglisi, A.; Vecchio, G. New conjugates of β-cyclodextrin with manganese(III) salophen and porphyrin complexes as antioxidant systems. Dalton Trans. 2011, 40, 2913– 2919,  DOI: 10.1039/c0dt01480j
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        New conjugates of β-cyclodextrin with manganese(III) salophen and porphyrin complexes as antioxidant systems
        Oliveri, Valentina; Puglisi, Antonino; Vecchio, Graziella
        Dalton Transactions (2011), 40 (12), 2913-2919CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Oxidative stress is the hallmark of several pathologies like arthritis, hypertension and many neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases. In this scenario, antioxidant compds. can play a pivotal role in treating these severe pathologies. The synthesis of mols. able to mimic physiol.-relevant proteins is nowadays of particular interest. Several transition metal complexes, esp. manganese(iii) complexes with porphyrin and salen-type ligands, have been reported to be superoxide scavengers. Here we report the synthesis and spectroscopic characterization of manganese(III) complexes of 5[4-(6-O-β-cyclodextrin)-phenyl],10,15,20-tri(4-hydroxyphenyl)-porphyrin and of 6A-deoxy-6A[(S-cysteamidobenzoyl(3,4-diamino)-N,N'-bis(salicylidene))]-β-cyclodextrin. The superoxide dismutase activity of the metal complexes was investigated by indirect methods. The catalase and peroxidase activities were tested using ABTS assays.

        Yu, S.; Huang, X.; Miao, L.; Zhu, J.; Yin, Y.; Luo, Q.; Xu, J.; Shen, J.; Liu, J. A supramolecular bifunctional artificial enzyme with superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase activities. Bioorg. Chem. 2010, 38, 159– 164,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioorg.2010.03.001

        35
        A supramolecular bifunctional artificial enzyme with superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase activities
        Yu, Shuangjiang; Huang, Xin; Miao, Lu; Zhu, Junyan; Yin, Yanzhen; Luo, Quan; Xu, Jiayu; Shen, Jiacong; Liu, Junqiu
        Bioorganic Chemistry (2010), 38 (4), 159-164CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier Inc.)
        For constructing a bifunctional antioxidative enzyme with both superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activities, a supramol. artificial enzyme was successfully constructed by the self-assembly of the Mn(III)meso-tetra[1-(1-adamantyl Me ketone)-4-pyridyl] porphyrin (MnTPyP-M-Ad) and cyclodextrin-based telluronic acid (2-CD-TeO3H) through host-guest interaction in aq. soln. The self-assembly of the adamantyl moieties of Mn(III) porphyrin and the β-CD cavities of 2-CD-TeO3H was demonstrated by the NMR spectra. In this supramol. enzyme model, the Mn(III) porphyrin center acted as an efficient active site of SOD and tellurol moiety endowed GPx activity. The SOD-like activity (IC50) of the new catalyst was found to be 0.116 μM and equals to 2.56% of the activity of the native SOD. Besides this, supramol. enzyme model also showed a high GPx activity, and a remarkable rate enhancement of 27-fold compared to the well-known GPx mimic ebselen was obsd. More importantly, the supramol. artificial enzyme showed good thermal stability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXntVekt70%253D&md5=4deb26e3b9b961d7801823aaca11cb12
      36. 36
        McNaughton, M.; Engman, L.; Birmingham, A.; Powis, G.; Cotgreave, I. A. Cyclodextrin-derived diorganyl tellurides as glutathione peroxidase mimics and inhibitors of thioredoxin reductase and cancer cell growth. J. Med. Chem. 2004, 47, 233– 239,  DOI: 10.1021/jm030916r
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Cyclodextrin-Derived Diorganyl Tellurides as Glutathione Peroxidase Mimics and Inhibitors of Thioredoxin Reductase and Cancer Cell Growth
        McNaughton, Michael; Engman, Lars; Birmingham, Anne; Powis, Garth; Cotgreave, Ian A.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2004), 47 (1), 233-239CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        Water-sol. diorganyl tellurides of the alkyl aryl or dialkyl type were prepd. by treatment of mono-6-tosyl-β-cyclodextrin with sodium alkanetellurolates or arenetellurolates or sodium telluride. The novel cyclodextrin-derived organotelluriums were evaluated for their capacity to catalyze the redn. of hydrogen peroxide, tert-Bu hydroperoxide, and cumene hydroperoxide in the presence of glutathione, NADPH, and GSSG-reductase (coupled reductase assay). Cyclodextrins carrying 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)phenyltelluro and n-butyltelluro groups, resp., were the most efficient glutathione peroxidase mimics. Redn. of lipophilic cumene hydroperoxide often proceeded 10-20 times faster than redn. of the more hydrophilic hydroperoxides, which cannot bind into the hydrophobic interior of the cyclodextrin. Thus, it seems that the carbohydrate moiety acts as a binding site for the hydroperoxide substrate. The cyclodextrin derivs. were also evaluated for their capacity to inhibit thioredoxin reductase/thioredoxin and cancer cell growth in culture. IC50 values for inhibition of thioredoxin or thioredoxin/thioredoxin reductase were in the submicromolar range for the best inhibitors. Two of the compds. were found to inhibit the growth of MCF-7 cells in culture with IC50 values in the low micromolar range.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        A modulatory bifunctional artificial enzyme with both SOD and GPx activities based on a smart star-shaped pseudo-block copolymer
        Yu, Shuangjiang; Yin, Yanzhen; Zhu, Junyan; Huang, Xin; Luo, Quan; Xu, Jiayun; Shen, Jiacong; Liu, Junqiu
        Soft Matter (2010), 6 (21), 5342-5350CODEN: SMOABF; ISSN:1744-683X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        An artificial smart bifunctional enzyme with both superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activities was successfully constructed by the self-assembly of a porphyrin core with four suspensory adamantyl moieties and β-cyclodextrin-terminated temp.-sensitive copolymer through host-guest interaction in aq. soln. The Mn(III) porphyrin, Mn(III)meso-tetra[1-(1-adamantyl Me ketone)-4-pyridyl] porphyrin (MnTPyP-M-Ad), was designed as both a "supramol. linker" and an efficient active site of SOD and the temp.-responsive block copolymer (β-CD-PEG-b-PNIPAAm-Te) with incorporated tellurium moieties in the PNIPAAm chain as GPx active sites was synthesized by ATRP. As a new type of artificial bifunctional enzymes, it exhibited stable SOD-like activity of 0.137 μM (IC50) at 37 °C, and high GPx catalytic efficiency with temp.-responsive dependence characteristic, and the new artificial enzyme was found to exhibit the highest GPx catalytic efficiency (v0 = 8.11 μM min-1) in close to phys. temp.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht12ltb3N&md5=9d107f87aeb4c102037d5b0ad564e36f
      38. 38
        Kano, K.; Ishida, Y. Regulation of α-chymotrypsin catalysis by ferric porphyrins and cyclodextrins. Chem. - Asian J. 2008, 3, 678– 686,  DOI: 10.1002/asia.200700383
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Regulation of α-chymotrypsin catalysis by ferric porphyrins and cyclodextrins
        Kano, Koji; Ishida, Yoshiyuki
        Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2008), 3 (4), 678-686CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Pos. charged α-chymotrypsin (ChT) formed a 1:1 complex with neg. charged 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinato iron(III) (FeTPPS) in phosphate buffer at pH 7.4 through electrostatic interaction. In spite of the large binding const. (K = 4.8 × 105 M-1), FeTPPS could not completely inhibit the catalysis of ChT in the hydrolysis of the model substrate, N-succinyl-L-phenylalanine p-nitroanilide (SPNA). The degree of inhibition (60%) was satd. at 1.6 equiv of FeTPPS, which indicates that covering of the active site of ChT by FeTPPS was insufficient. The enzymic activity lowered by FeTPPS was entirely recovered for the freshly prepd. sample when the porphyrin on the protein surface was detached by per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin (TMe-β-CD), which formed a stable 1:2 inclusion complex with FeTPPS (K1 = 1.26 × 106 M-1, K2 = 6.3 × 104 M-1). FeTPPS gradually induced irreversible denaturation of ChT, and the denatured ChT further lost its catalytic ability. No repairing effect of TMe-β-CD was obsd. with irreversibly denatured ChT. A new reversible inhibitor, 5,10,15,20-tetrakis[4-(3,5-dicarboxyphenylmethoxy)phenyl]porphyrinato iron(III) (FeP8M), was then designed, and its inhibitory behavior was examd. FeP8M formed very stable 1:1 and 1:2 FeP8M/ChT complexes with ChT, the K1 and K2 values being 2.0 × 108 and 1.0 × 106 M-1, resp. FeP8M effectively inhibited the ChT-catalyzed hydrolysis of SPNA (max. degree of inhibition = 85%), and the activity of ChT was recovered by per-O-methylated γ-cyclodextrin. No irreversible denaturation of ChT occurred upon binding with FeP8M. The kinetic data support the observation that, for non-incubated samples, both inhibitors did not cause significant conformational change in ChT and inhibited the ChT activity by covering the active site of the enzyme.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlsVWisLo%253D&md5=495463312b5e2417b3b959df81291927

        Watanabe, K.; Kano, K. Time-dependent enzyme activity dominated by dissociation of J-aggregates bound to protein surface. Bioconjugate Chem. 2010, 21, 2332– 2338,  DOI: 10.1021/bc100355v
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Time-Dependent Enzyme Activity Dominated by Dissociation of J-Aggregates Bound to Protein Surface
        Watanabe, Kenji; Kano, Koji
        Bioconjugate Chemistry (2010), 21 (12), 2332-2338CODEN: BCCHES; ISSN:1043-1802. (American Chemical Society)
        J-Aggregates of diprotonated 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatopheny)porphyrin (H4TPPS2-) were stabilized even in a neutral aq. soln. (pH 7.0) contg. per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin by binding to the surface of α-chymotrypsin (ChT). The large J-aggregates covered the active site of ChT and completely inhibited the hydrolysis of the peptides. However, enzyme activity was gradually restored with the dissocn. of the J-aggregates attached to the protein surface to monomers. After the completion of dissocn. of the aggregates, the enzyme activity was almost completely restored, though the structure of ChT significantly changed. CD spectroscopy suggested that the microscopic structure at the active site of ChT was scarcely affected by the J-aggregates, but the binding of J-aggregates to ChT increased the content of the random coils in the enzyme. The present study showed a new type of effector for controlling the function of ChT.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVWhtr3O&md5=066a63cb5de8d4326cf97bf5eda7c543

        Miyamoto, T.; Maeno, S.; Zhu, Q.; Fukushima, M. Inclusion complex of iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin with 2,3,6-tri-O-methyl-β-cyclodextrin as a biomimetic model of oxidative enzymes: Catalytic oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A with peroxomonosulfate. J. Mol. Catal. B: Enzym. 2014, 110, 147– 153,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molcatb.2014.10.003

        40
        Inclusion complex of iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin with 2,3,6-tri-O-methyl-β-cyclodextrin as a biomimetic model of oxidative enzymes: Catalytic oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A with peroxomonosulfate
        Miyamoto, Takafumi; Maeno, Shohei; Zhu, Qianqian; Fukushima, Masami
        Journal of Molecular Catalysis B: Enzymatic (2014), 110 (), 147-153CODEN: JMCEF8; ISSN:1381-1177. (Elsevier B.V.)
        An inclusion complex composed of iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin (FeTPPS) with 2,3,6-tri-O-methyl-β-CD (TM-β-CD), regarded as biomimetic models for oxidative enzymes, catalyzed the degrdn. of a tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) deriv. that is found in soil. The inclusion complex was characterized by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy and the efficiency of degrdn. of TBBPA by this inclusion complex was evaluated in the presence of humic acid (HA), a major component of soil org. matter. At pH 4, the formation of the 1:1 inclusion complex of FeTPPS with TM-β-CD (FeTPPS·TM-β-CD) was confirmed and the resulting complexation enhanced the degrdn. efficiency of TBBPA by suppressing the self-degrdn. of the catalyst. In the presence of HA, the catalytic activity for TBBPA oxidn. with the FeTPPS·TM-β-CD complex was optimal in the range of pH 4-5, which is comparable to the optimal pH values for oxidative enzymes. Thus, the FeTPPS·TM-β-CD complex can be regarded as a suitable model for the enzymic oxidn. of TBBPA.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsl2ksLbP&md5=85bc524613eceb1c74338b79b3d94e78

        Miyamoto, T.; Zhu, Q.; Igrashi, M.; Kodama, R.; Maeno, S.; Fukushima, M. Catalytic oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A by iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin catalyst supported on cyclodextrin polymers with potassium monopersulfate. J. Mol. Catal. B: Enzym. 2015, 119, 64– 70,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molcatb.2015.06.002
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        Catalytic oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A by iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin catalyst supported on cyclodextrin polymers with potassium monopersulfate
        Miyamoto, Takafumi; Zhu, Qianqian; Igrashi, Mami; Kodama, Ritsu; Maeno, Shohei; Fukushima, Masami
        Journal of Molecular Catalysis B: Enzymatic (2015), 119 (), 64-70CODEN: JMCEF8; ISSN:1381-1177. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A water-sol. iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin (FeTPPS) complex was loaded on cyclodextrin polymers (CDPs) by forming inclusion complexes. The amt. of the loaded FeTPPS for γ-CDP was much larger than the corresponding values for α- and β-CDPs. All of the prepd. FeTPPS/CDPs showed catalytic activities for the oxidative degrdn. of TBBPA at pH 8. Although the turnover frequency (TOF) value for the FeTPPS/α-CDP catalyst was the largest among all the catalysts tested, the FeTPPS/γ-CDP catalyst was inhibited less in the presence of humic acid, which is a major component of landfill leachates. During a 4-h incubation period, 4-8% of the loaded FeTPPS was eluted from the FeTPPS/CDP catalysts, and their efficiencies for the degrdn. of TBBPA and debromination decreased with increasing recycle times for FeTPPS/α-CDP and FeTPPS/β-CDP. However, the decreases in efficiency for the oxidn. of TBBPA were smaller in the case of the FeTPPS/γ-CDP catalyst. In conclusion, the FeTPPS/γ-CDP catalyst performed at a much higher level compared to the FeTPPS/α-CDP and FeTPPS/β-CDP catalysts, in terms of inhibition by coexisting substances and reusability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1GqsrvP&md5=665f915d993f1241ccb2b60d0790b6d6

        Kendrew, J. C.; Dickerson, R. E.; Strandberg, B. E.; Hart, R. G.; Davies, D. R.; Phillips, D. C.; Shore, V. C. Structure of myoglobin. Nature 1960, 185, 422– 427,  DOI: 10.1038/185422a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42
        Structure of myoglobin. Three-dimensional Fourier synthesis at 2 A. resolution
        Kendrew, J. C.; Dickerson, R. E.; Strandberg, B. E.; Hart, R. G.; Davies, D. R.; Phillips, D. C.; Shore, V. C.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1960), 185 (), 422-7CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        New details of the structure of sperm-whale myoglobin (Kendrew, et al., CA 52, 12949b) were obtained by increasing the resolution in the Fourier synthesis from 6 to 2 A. The 1st direct proof was obtained that the polypeptide chain is a right-handed α-helix. The position of a few amino acid residues has been deduced from steric considerations. The structure of the hem group corresponded with theoretical expectation and its direction of tilt was now found to be the opposite of that shown in the 6 A. model. It is confirmed that the hem is attached to protein by bonding from Fe to the N of a histidine residue and that the sixth co.ovrddot.ordination position of the Fe in metmyoglobin is occupied by H2O.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3cXotVyntw%253D%253D&md5=9e72326f3059146741f5c6aa0474d192
      43. 43
        Muirhead, H.; Perutz, M. F. Structure of haemoglobin. A three-dimensional Fourier synthesis of reduced human haemoglobin at 5.5 Å resolution. Nature 1963, 199, 633– 638,  DOI: 10.1038/199633a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43
        Structure of hemoglobin--three-dimensional fourier synthesis of reduced human hemoglobin at 5.5-A. resolution
        Muirhead, Hilary; Perutz, M. F.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1963), 199 (4894), 633-8CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        Reduced hemoglobin(Hb) of man crystallizes in 3 forms of which one is suitable for x-ray analysis. This analysis revealed a 3-D electron d. map at 5.5-A. resolution. As in horse oxy-hemoglobin(I), the mol. is divided into 4 subunits which correspond to the pairs of α- and β-chains of the chem. sequence. No difference between the globin chains in horse I and human reduced Hb was detected. However, the 2 β-chains in human reduced Hb move apart, increasing the distance by 7 A. compared with that in horse I. Indirect x-ray evidence suggests that the structural changes observed are due to the oxygenation reaction, rather than to species differences. X-ray pictures were taken of crystals grown from solns. contg. 2.6M (NH4)2SO4 and 0.01M ferrous citrate, buffered to pH 6.5; the crystals were mounted in an atm. of N. The crystals belong to the monoclinic space group P21. The sequence of β-chain of equine Hb is very similar to that of the corresponding chain of the human form, which indicates a similar mol. structure. The structural rearrangement cannot be caused by interaction between the 2 β-chains by themselves, since in the reduced form these are not in contact. It seems likely that rearrangement is brought about by interaction between the α- and β-chains. 26 references.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3sXks1ems7s%253D&md5=a21c59439345f8d43e6aeabd9ebc48cf

        Safo, M. K.; Ahmed, M. H.; Ghatge, M. S.; Boyiri, T. Hemoglobin-ligand binding: Understanding Hb function and allostery on atomic level. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Proteins Proteomics 2011, 1814, 797– 809,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bbapap.2011.02.013
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44
        Hemoglobin-ligand binding: Understanding Hb function and allostery on atomic level
        Safo, Martin K.; Ahmed, Mostafa H.; Ghatge, Mohini S.; Boyiri, Telih
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Proteins and Proteomics (2011), 1814 (6), 797-809CODEN: BBAPBW; ISSN:1570-9639. (Elsevier B. V.)
        A review. The major physiol. function of Hb is to bind O2 in the lungs and deliver it to the tissues. This function is regulated and/or made efficient by endogenous heterotropic effectors. A no. of synthetic mols. also bind to Hb to alter its allosteric activity. Here, the authors review the current state of Hb structure and function that involves ensembles of tense and relaxed Hb states and the dynamic equil. of the multistate due to the binding of endogenous heterotropic or synthetic allosteric effectors. The authors also discuss the at. interactions of synthetic ligands with the function or altered allosteric function of Hb that could be potentially harnessed for the treatment of diseases.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXlvVCisrw%253D&md5=6b89fc3e1a867f2e8edfd64a1d641301
      45. 45
        Pauling, L.; Weiss, J. J. Nature of the iron-oxygen bond in oxyhæmoglobin. Nature 1964, 203, 182,  DOI: 10.1038/203182b0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Nature of the iron-oxygen bond in oxyhemoglobin
        Pauling, Linus
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1964), 203 (4941), 182-3CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        cf. following abstrs. It is concluded that oxyHb (I) and related Hb (II) compds. are properly described as contg. Fe++, rather than Fe+++, and that their electronic structures involve essentially the formation of a double bond between the Fe atom and the nearby O atom in I (with the Fe-O-O bond angle about 120°) and formation of a triple bond to the C atom in carbon monoxide Hb and the II alkylisocyanides (with Fe-C-O or N bond angle 180°). The Fe-O and Fe-C interat. distances in these compds. are predicted to have the values corresponding to these multiple bonds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2cXkslOmtbc%253D&md5=98113e49b725fd537ff64adc2fe44b7f

        Phillips, S. E. V.; Schoenborn, B. P. Neutron diffraction reveals oxygen-histidine hydrogen bond in oxymyoglobin. Nature 1981, 292, 81– 82,  DOI: 10.1038/292081a0

        Neutron diffraction reveals oxygen-histidine hydrogen bond in oxymyoglobin
        Phillips, Simon E. V.; Schoenborn, Benno P.

        Neutron diffraction anal. indicated that, in oxymyoglobin, the imidazole group of the distal histidine (E7) stabilized bound O2 with a H bond.

      47. 47
        Krzywda, S.; Murshudov, G. N.; Brzozowski, A. M.; Jaskolski, M.; Klizas, S. A.; Gibson, Q. H.; Olson, J. S.; Wilkinson, A. J. Stabilizing bound O2 in myoglobin by valine68 (E11) to asparagine substitution. Biochemistry 1998, 37, 15896– 15907,  DOI: 10.1021/bi9812470
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        47
        Stabilizing Bound O2 in Myoglobin by Valine68 (E11) to Asparagine Substitution
        Krzywda, Szymon; Murshudov, Garib N.; Brzozowski, Andrzej M.; Jaskolski, Mariusz; Scott, Emily E.; Klizas, Sarah A.; Gibson, Quentin H.; Olson, John S.; Wilkinson, Anthony J.
        Biochemistry (1998), 37 (45), 15896-15907CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
        The iso-Pr side chain of valine68 in myoglobin has been replaced by the acetamide side chain of asparagine in an attempt to engineer higher oxygen affinity. The asparagine replacement introduces a second hydrogen bond donor group into the distal heme pocket which could further stabilize bound oxygen. The Val68 to Asn substitution leads to ∼3-fold increases in oxygen affinity and 4-6-fold decreases in CO affinity. As a result, the M-value (KCO/KO2) is lowered 15-20-fold to a value close to unity. An even larger enhancement of O2 affinity is seen when asparagine68 is inserted into H64L sperm whale myoglobin which lacks a distal histidine. The overall rate consts. for oxygen and carbon monoxide binding to the single V68N myoglobin mutants are uniformly lower than those for the wild-type protein. In contrast, the overall rate const. for NO assocn. is unchanged. Analyses of time courses monitoring the geminate recombination of ligands following nanosecond and picosecond flash photolysis of MbNO and MbO2 indicate that the barrier to ligand binding from within the heme pocket has been raised with little effect on the barrier to diffusion of the ligand into the pocket from the solvent. The crystal structures of the aquomet, deoxy, oxy, and carbon monoxy forms of the V68N mutant have been detd. to resolns. ranging from 1.75 to 2.2 Å at 150 K. The overall structures are very similar to those of the wild-type protein with the principal alterations taking place within and around the distal heme pocket. In all four structures the asparagine68 side chain lies almost parallel to the plane of the heme with its amide group directed toward the back of the distal heme pocket. The coordinated water mol. in the aquomet form and the bound oxygen in the oxy form can form hydrogen-bonding interactions with both the Asn68 amide group and the imidazole side chain of His64. Surprisingly, in the carbon monoxy form of the V68N mutant, the histidine64 side chain has swung completely out the distal pocket, its place being taken by two ordered water mols. Overall, these functional and structural results show that the asparagine68 side chain (i) forms a strong hydrogen bond with bound oxygen through its -NH2 group but (ii) sterically hinders the approach of ligands to the iron from within the distal heme pocket.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXmsleitLs%253D&md5=b0db71e6309073efe60885058b21c19f
      48. 48
        Phillips, S. E. Structure and refinement of oxymyoglobin at 1. 6 Å resolution. J. Mol. Biol. 1980, 142, 531– 554,  DOI: 10.1016/0022-2836(80)90262-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Structure and refinement of oxymyoglobin at 1.6 Å resolution
        Phillips, Simon E. V.
        Journal of Molecular Biology (1980), 142 (4), 531-54CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836.
        The structure of oxymyoglobin was refined at 1.6 Å resoln., using diffractometer data collected at -12°. The crystallog. R factor is 0.159, and the at. positions are known to 0.1 Å accuracy in internal segments of the mol. The Fe atom was 0.22(3) Å from the plane of the porphyrin, 0.25 Å closer than in deoxymyoglobin, and the F helix was moved by a similar amt. O bound to the Fe in a bent, end-on arrangement, with Fe-O-O of 115(5)° and Fe-O of 1.83(6) Å. The mean Fe-N (porphyrin) bond length was 1.95(6) Å. Fe-Nε(His 8F) was 2.07(6) Å, the same as in model compds. Movements of heme Fe, F helix, and FG corner on oxygenation were similar to those found in the T-R state transition in Hb, but were smaller in magnitude.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Collman, J. P.; Boulatov, R.; Sunderland, C. J.; Fu, L. Functional analogues of cytochrome c oxidase, myoglobin, and hemoglobin. Chem. Rev. 2004, 104, 561– 588,  DOI: 10.1021/cr0206059
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Functional Analogues of Cytochrome c Oxidase, Myoglobin, and Hemoglobin
        Collman, James P.; Boulatov, Roman; Sunderland, Christopher J.; Fu, Lei
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 104 (2), 561-588CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review of functional synthetic analogs of the hemoproteins cytochrome oxidase, myoglobin and Hb. Topics discussed include synthetic Fe-porphyrins as well as analogs for the heme/CuB site of cytochrome oxidase.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpvVKntLs%253D&md5=cdf0a079bcd3fa8a8fffdd6eae92873e
      50. 50
        Tani, F.; Matsu-ura, M.; Ariyama, K.; Setoyama, T.; Shimada, T.; Kobayashi, S.; Hayashi, T.; Matsuo, T.; Hisaeda, Y.; Naruta, Y. Iron twin-coronet porphyrins as models of myoglobin and hemoglobin: amphibious electrostatic effects of overhanging hydroxyl groups for successful CO/O2 discrimination. Chem. - Eur. J. 2003, 9, 862– 870,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200390096
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        Iron twin-coronet porphyrins as models of myoglobin and hemoglobin: Amphibious electrostatic effects of overhanging hydroxyl groups for successful CO/O2 discrimination
        Tani, Fumito; Matsu-ura, Mikiya; Ariyama, Kiyoko; Setoyama, Toshikazu; Shimada, Takayuki; Kobayashi, Shinjiro; Hayashi, Takashi; Matsuo, Takashi; Hisaeda, Yoshio; Naruta, Yoshinori
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2003), 9 (4), 862-870CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Inspired by the observation of polar interactions between CO and O2 ligands and the peptide residues at the active site of Hb and myoglobin, we synthesized two kinds of superstructured porphyrins: TCP-IM, which contains a linked imidazole ligand, and TCP-PY, which contains a linked pyridine ligand, and examd. the thermodn., kinetic, and spectroscopic (UV/Vis, IR, NMR, and resonance Raman) properties of their CO and O2 complexes. On both sides of each porphyrin plane, bulky binaphthyl bridges form hydrophobic cavities that are suitable for the binding of small mols. In the proximal site, an imidazole or pyridine residue is covalently fixed and coordinates axially to the central iron atom. In the distal site, two naphtholic hydroxyl groups overhang toward the center above the heme. The CO affinities of TCPs are significantly lower than those of other heme models. In contrast, TCPs have moderate O2 binding ability. Compared with reported model hemes, the binding selectivity of O2 over CO in TCP-IM and TCP-PY complexes is greatly improved. The high O2 selectivity of the TCPs is mainly attributable to a low CO affinity. The comparison of kon(CO) values of TCPs with those of unhindered hemes indicates the absence of steric hindrance to the intrinsically linear CO coordination to FeII in TCP-IM and TCP-PY. The abnormally large koff(CO) values are responsible for the low CO affinities. In contrast, koff(O2) of TCP-PY is smaller than those of other pyridine-coordinated model hemes. For the CO adducts of TCPs, unusually low ν(Fe-CO) and unusually high ν(C-O) frequencies are obsd. These results can be ascribed to decreased back-bonding from the iron atom to the bound CO. The lone pairs of the oxygen atoms of the hydroxyl groups prevent back-bonding by exertion of a strong neg. electrostatic interaction. On the other hand, high ν(Fe-O2) frequencies are obsd. for the O2 adducts of TCPs. In the resonance Raman (RR) spectrum of oxy-TCP-IM, we obsd. simultaneous enhancement of the Fe-O2 and O-O stretching modes. Furthermore, direct evidence for hydrogen bonding between the hydroxyl groups and bound dioxygen was obtained by RR and IR spectroscopy. These spectroscopic data strongly suggest that O2 and CO binding to TCPs is controlled mainly by the two different electrostatic effects exerted by the overhanging OH groups: destabilization of CO binding by decreasing back-bonding and stabilization of O2 binding by hydrogen bonding.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhvVOnt70%253D&md5=b3d4e33debe89ddde0176a160fbdfb30
      51. 51
        Tsuchida, E.; Nishide, H.; Yuasa, M.; Hasegawa, E.; Matsushita, Y. Liposomal heme as oxygen carrier under semi-physiological conditions. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans. 1984, 1147– 1151,  DOI: 10.1039/dt9840001147
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Liposomal heme as oxygen carrier under semi-physiological conditions
        Tsuchida, Eishun; Nishide, Hiroyuki; Yuasa, Makoto; Hasegawa, Etsuo; Matsushita, Yohichi
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1972-1999) (1984), (6), 1147-51, 1 plateCODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246.
        Complexes of 1-alkyl-2-methylimidazoles [alkyl = Me, CPh3, (CH2)nMe [n = 17, 11 (I)]] with meso-5,10,15,20-tetra(o-pivalamidophenyl)porphyrinatoiron(II) were incorporated into lipid bilayers of phosphatidylcholine to give liposomal hemes. The liposomal heme contg. the I complex reversibly bound mol. O in neutral aq. medium at 37°; the half-life of the O adduct was 0.5 days and the O-binding affinity of the liposomal heme was ∼50 mm Hg, similar to that of Hb in blood. The hydrophobic environment of the inner region of the liposome protected the O adduct from proton-driven oxidn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXls1GksLk%253D&md5=857edc77e8f1efd48a0166a70cf8e47f

        Komatsu, T.; Moritake, M.; Nakagawa, A.; Tsuchida, E. Self-organized lipid-porphyrin bilayer membranes in vesicular form: Nanostructure, photophysical properties, and dioxygen coordination. Chem. - Eur. J. 2002, 8, 5469– 5480,  DOI: 10.1002/1521-3765(20021202)8:23<5469::AID-CHEM5469>3.0.CO;2-1
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Self-organized lipid-porphyrin bilayer membranes in vesicular form: nanostructure, photophysical properties, and dioxygen coordination
        Komatsu, Teruyuki; Moritake, Miho; Nakagawa, Akito; Tsuchida, Eishun
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2002), 8 (23), 5469-5480CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An amphiphilic tetraphenylporphyrin and its Fe complex bearing four phospholipid substituents, in which a trimethylolethane residue connects the two acyl chains (lipid-porphyrins), were synthesized. The free-base lipid-porphyrin (6a = I, M = 2H) self-organizes in aq. media to form spherical unilamellar vesicles with a diam. of 100 nm and a uniform thickness of 10 nm, which corresponds to twice the length of the mol. In the visible absorption spectrum, the porphyrin Soret band was significantly red shifted (12 nm) relative to that of the monomer in benzene/MeOH soln. due to the excitonic interaction of the porphyrin chromophores. The π-A isotherm of 6a gave an area per mol. of 2.2 nm2, which allowed the estn. of the no. of mols. in a single vesicle (2.3 × 104). Double-layered Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) films of 6a on a glass surface exhibited an absorption spectrum identical to that of the 6a vesicles in bulk aq. soln., and probably they contain similar geometric arrangements of the porphyrin moieties. Exciton calcns. from the authors' structural model reproduced the bathochromic shift of the Soret band well. In the photophys. properties of the 6a vesicles, the characteristics of J-aggregated porphyrins substantially predominate: strong fluorescence and extremely short triplet lifetime. The Fe complex (6b = I, M = Fe3+) with a small molar excess of 1-dodecylimidazole (DIm) also formed spherical unilamellar vesicles (100 nm Φ). Scanning force microscopy after evapn. on a graphite surface revealed 6b/DIm vesicles with a vertical height of 19.8 nm, which coincided with the thickness of the double bilayer membranes. The ferrous (6c = I, M = Fe2+) formed a bis(DIm)-coordinated low-spin FeII complex under an N2 atmosphere. Upon addn. of O2 to this soln., a kinetically stable O2 adduct was formed at 37° with a half-life of 17 h. Distinct gel-phase (liq.-crystal) transitions of the lipid-porphyrin membranes were clearly obsd.; the free base 6a displayed a higher transition temp. (56°) than the Fe complex. MCD and IR spectroscopic studies proved that mol. O2 coordinates to the self-organized lipid-porphyrinatoiron(II) vesicles in aq. media.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xps1Wjs70%253D&md5=5c4ce9a728fd4cb5a55e5bb6a0ec96e7

        Komatsu, T.; Hayakawa, S.; Tsuchida, E.; Nishide, H. meso-Tetrakis[o-(N-methyl)pyridinium]porphyrin ensembles with axially coordinated cyclodextrin-penetrating phenethylimidazole: reversible dioxygen-binding in aqueous DMF solution. Chem. Commun. 2003, 50– 51,  DOI: 10.1039/b208882g
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        meso-Tetrakis[o-(N-methyl)pyridinium]porphyrin ensembles with axially coordinated cyclodextrin-penetrating phenethylimidazole: reversible dioxygen-binding in aqueous DMF solution
        Komatsu, Teruyuki; Hayakawa, Shoichi; Tsuchida, Eishun; Nishide, Hiroyuki
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2003), (1), 50-51CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        α-Cyclodextrin (αCD)-penetrating 2-methyl-1-phenethylimidazole coordinates to the zinc(II) and iron(II) complexes of meso-tetrakis[o-(N-methyl)pyridinium]porphyrinate, giving noncovalently linked αCD-porphyrin ensembles. The iron(II) complex can reversibly bind and release dioxygen in aq. DMF soln. The dioxygen adduct reacts with CO to make the CO adduct and also reacts over time to give the iron(III) hydroxide complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Zhou, H.; Groves, J. T. Hemodextrin: a self-assembled cyclodextrin-porphyrin construct that binds dioxygen. Biophys. Chem. 2003, 105, 639– 648,  DOI: 10.1016/S0301-4622(03)00094-2
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        54
        Hemodextrin: a self-assembled cyclodextrin-porphyrin construct that binds dioxygen
        Zhou, Huchen; Groves, John T.
        Biophysical Chemistry (2003), 105 (2-3), 639-648CODEN: BICIAZ; ISSN:0301-4622. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        Synthetic hemoprotein model compds. are of great interest due to the vital roles and complexities of hemoproteins. This study reports a novel, self-assembled hemoprotein model, hemodextrin. The synthesis and characterization of py-PPCD (2A-monopyridylmethyl-perPEGylated-β-cyclodextrin) (2) is described. The mol. design is based on a pegylated cyclodextrin scaffold that bears both a heme-binding pocket and an axial ligand that binds an iron porphyrin. The binding const. for Fe(III)TPPS [iron(III) meso-tetra(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin] by py-PPCD (2) was detd. to be 2×106 M-1 at pH 6.0 by observing characteristic changes in the UV-Vis spectrum of the porphyrin. The pyridyl nitrogen of py-PPCD (2) was shown to ligate to the iron center by observing signal changes in the Fe(II)-porphyrin 1H-NMR spectrum. This hemodextrin ensemble was shown to bind dioxygen reversibly and to form a stable ferryl species.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXnt1Gmurw%253D&md5=d59e703da2a01778f17198b0724984cf
      55. 55
        Shen, L.; Zhao, L.; Qu, R.; Huang, F.; Gao, H.; An, Y.; Shi, L. Complex micelles with the bioactive function of reversible oxygen transfer. Nano Res. 2015, 8, 491– 501,  DOI: 10.1007/s12274-014-0651-4
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Complex micelles with the bioactive function of reversible oxygen transfer
        Shen, Liangliang; Zhao, Lizhi; Qu, Rui; Huang, Fan; Gao, Hongjun; An, Yingli; Shi, Linqi
        Nano Research (2015), 8 (2), 491-501CODEN: NRAEB5; ISSN:1998-0000. (Springer GmbH)
        A complex micelle as a Hb functional model with the biaoactive function of reversible oxygen transfer has been constructed through the hierarchical assembly of the diblock copolymer poly(ethylene glycol)-blockpoly(4-vinylpyridine-co-N-heptyl-4-vinylpyridine) (PEG-b-P(4VP-co-4VPHep)), tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphinato iron(II) (Fe(II)TPPS) and β-cyclodextrin (β-CD). The μ-oxo dimer of Fe(II)TPPS was successfully inhibited because the Fe(II)TPPS was included into the cavities of β-CDs through host-guest interaction. Fe(II)TPPS coordinated with pyridine groups functions as the active site to reversibly bind dioxygen. In adition, the host-guest inclusion (β-CD/Fe(II)TPPS) was encapsulated in the hydrophobic core of the complex micelle and tightly fixed by P4VP chains. The hydrophilic PEG blocks stretched in aq. soln. to constitute the shells which stabilize the structure of the complex micelle as well as endow the complex micelle with sufficient blood circulation time. Dioxygen can be bound to the Fe(II)TPPS located in the confined space and excellent reversibility of the binding-release process of dioxygen can be achieved. The quaternary amine N-heptyl-4-vinylpyridine can coerce abundant S2O42- ions into the core of the complex micelle to facilitate the self-redn. process. Dioxygen adducts (Fe(II)TPPS(O2)) were effectively protected by the double hydrophobic barriers constructed by the cavity of the cyclodextrin and the core of the complex micelle which enhances the ability to resist nucleophilic mols. Therefore, the rationally designed amphiphilic structure can work as a promising artificial O2 carrier. Potentially, the complex micelle can be expected to improve the treatment of diseases linked with hypoxia. [Figure not available: see fulltext.].
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFKltrk%253D&md5=fa9b0d0e37969f9d57911840fa8975ad
      56. 56
        Jiang, T.; Lawrence, D. S. Sugar-coated metalated macrocycles. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995, 117, 1857– 1858,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00111a035
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        Sugar-Coated Metalated Macrocycles
        Jiang, Tao; Lawrence, David S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1995), 117 (6), 1857-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A pyridine-linked cyclodextrin dimer has been evaluated in terms of its ability to assoc. with lipophilic compds. that possess a centrally positioned metal ion. The pyridine bridge not only serves to hold the two cyclodextrin moieties within close proximity to one another but, in addn., is properly positioned to act as a coordinating ligand for metalated macrocyclic guests. In addn., we prepd. a benzene-bridged cyclodextrin dimer. In this species the benzene moiety lacks the coordinating nitrogen atom and therefore should be unable to ligate the central metal atom of metalated macrocyclic guests. Both of the pyridine- and benzene-linked dimers bind a wide variety of metallo-macrocycles, including metalated porphyrins, cyclams, salens, as well as other species. However, in contrast to the benzene-bridged dimer, the pyridine-based species exhibits a special affinity for metalated macrocyclic guests. In the latter case, binding consts. of up to 108 were obtained, which represent an enhancement of four orders of magnitude over that exhibited by the benzene-linked dimer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXjsFahsLY%253D&md5=ec64de49c83fc3796997d2603c35948e
      57. 57
        Kano, K.; Kitagishi, H.; Dagallier, C.; Kodera, M.; Matsuo, T.; Hayashi, T.; Hisaeda, Y.; Hirota, S. Iron porphyrin-cyclodextrin supramolecular complex as a functional model of myoglobin in aqueous solution. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 4448– 4460,  DOI: 10.1021/ic060137b
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Iron Porphyrin-Cyclodextrin Supramolecular Complex as a Functional Model of Myoglobin in Aqueous Solution
        Kano, Koji; Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Dagallier, Camille; Kodera, Masahito; Matsuo, Takashi; Hayashi, Takashi; Hisaeda, Yoshio; Hirota, Shun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (11), 4448-4460CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The 1:1 inclusion complex of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphinato iron(II) (FeIITPPS) and an O-methylated β-cyclodextrin dimer having a pyridine linker (1) binds dioxygen reversibly in aq. soln. The O2 adduct was very stable (t1/2 = 30.1 h) at pH 7.0 and 25°. ESI-MS and NMR spectroscopic measurements and mol. mechanics (MM) calcns. indicated the inclusion of the sulfonatophenyl groups at the 5- and 15-positions of FeIIITPPS or FeIITPPS into two cyclodextrin moieties of (1) to form a supramol. 1:1 complex (hemoCD1 for the FeIITPPS complex), whose iron center is completely covered by two cyclodextrin moieties. Equil. measurements and laser flash photolysis provided the affinities (P1/2O2 and P1/2CO) and rate consts. for O2 and CO binding of hemoCD1 (konO2, koffO2, konCO, and koffCO). The CO affinity relative to the O2 affinity of hemoCD1 was abnormally high. Although resonance Raman spectra suggested weak back-bonding of dπ(Fe) → π*(CO) and hence a weak CO-Fe bond, the CO adduct of hemoCD1 was very stable. The hydrophobic CO mol. dissocd. from CO-hemoCD1 hardly breaks free from a shallow cleft in hemoCD1 surrounded by an aq. bulk phase leading to fast rebinding of CO to hemoCD1. Isothermal titrn. calorimetry furnished the assocn. const. (KO2), ΔH°, and ΔS° for O2 assocn. to be (2.71±0.51) × 104 M-1, -65.2±4.4 kJ mol-1, and -133.9±16.1 J mol-1 K-1, resp. The autoxidn. of oxy-hemoCD1 was accelerated by H+ and OH-. The inorg. anions also accelerated the autoxidn. of oxy-hemoCD1. The O2-FeII bond is equiv. to the O2•--FeIII bond, which is attacked by the inorg. anions or the water mol. to produce met-hemoCD1 and a superoxide anion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XktVSks7g%253D&md5=4dfbed4ac9925e4ad30cfcac05034241

        Kano, K.; Itoh, Y.; Kitagishi, H.; Hayashi, T.; Hirota, S. A. Supramolecular receptor of diatomic molecules (O2, CO, NO) in aqueous solution. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 8006– 8015,  DOI: 10.1021/ja8009583
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        58
        A Supramolecular Receptor of Diatomic Molecules (O2, CO, NO) in Aqueous Solution
        Kano, Koji; Itoh, Yoshiki; Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Hayashi, Takashi; Hirota, Shun
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (25), 8006-8015CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin dimer, Py2CD, was conveniently prepd. via two steps: the Williamson reaction of 3,5-bis(bromomethyl)pyridine and β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) yielding 2A,2'A-O-[3,5-pyridinediylbis(methylene)]bis-β-cyclodextrin (bisCD) followed by the O-methylation of all the hydroxy groups of the bisCD. Py2CD formed a very stable 1:1 complex (Fe(III)PCD) with [5,10,15,20-tetrakis(p-sulfonatophenyl)porphinato]iron(III) (FeIIITPPS) in aq. soln. Fe(III)PCD was reduced with Na2S2O4 to afford the FeIITPPS/Py2CD complex (Fe(II)PCD). Dioxygen was bound to Fe(II)PCD, the P1/2(O2) values being 42.4 ± 1.6 and 176 ± 3 Torr at 3 and 25 °C, resp. The kon(O2) and koff(O2) values for the dioxygen binding were detd. to be 1.3 × 107 M-1s-1 and 3.8 × 103 s-1, resp., at 25 °C. Although the dioxygen adduct was not very stable [K(O2) = kon(O2)/koff(O2) = 3.4 × 103 M-1], no autoxidn. of the dioxygen adduct of Fe(II)PCD to Fe(III)PCD was obsd. These results suggest that the encapsulation of FeIITPPS by Py2CD strictly inhibits not only the extrusion of dioxygen from the cyclodextrin cage but also the penetration of a water mol. into the cage. The carbon monoxide affinity of Fe(II)PCD was much higher than the dioxygen affinity; the P1/2(CO), kon(CO), koff(CO), and K(CO) values being (1.6 ± 0.2) × 10-2 Torr, 2.4 × 106 M-1s-1, 4.8 × 10-2 s-1, and 5.0 × 107 M-1, resp., at 25 °C. Fe(II)PCD also bound nitric oxide. The rate of the dissocn. of NO from (NO)Fe(II)PCD ((5.58 ± 0.42) × 10-5 s-1) was in good agreement with the max. rate ((5.12 ± 0.18) × 10-5 s-1) of the oxidn. of (NO)Fe(II)PCD to Fe(III)PCD and NO3-, suggesting that the autoxidn. of (NO)Fe(II)PCD proceeds through the ligand exchange between NO and O2 followed by the rapid reaction of (O2)Fe(II)PCD with released NO, affording Fe(II)PCD and the NO3- anion inside the cyclodextrin cage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXmsVOgsrw%253D&md5=b39576168b88d724eb3586755f97cf7c
