        89. 89
          Vatansever, F.; de Melo, W. C. M. A.; Avci, P.; Vecchio, D.; Sadasivam, M.; Gupta, A.; Chandran, R.; Karimi, M.; Parizotto, N. A.; Yin, R.; Tegos, G. P.; Hamblin, M. R. Antimicrobial strategies centered around reactive oxygen species - bactericidal antibiotics, photodynamic therapy, and beyond. FEMS Microbiol. Rev. 2013, 37, 955– 989,  DOI: 10.1111/1574-6976.12026
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          89
          Antimicrobial strategies centered around reactive oxygen species - bactericidal antibiotics, photodynamic therapy, and beyond
          Vatansever, Fatma; de Melo, Wanessa C. M. A.; Avci, Pinar; Vecchio, Daniela; Sadasivam, Magesh; Gupta, Asheesh; Chandran, Rakkiyappan; Karimi, Mahdi; Parizotto, Nivaldo A.; Yin, Rui; Tegos, George P.; Hamblin, Michael R.
          FEMS Microbiology Reviews (2013), 37 (6), 955-989CODEN: FMREE4; ISSN:0168-6445. (Wiley-Blackwell)
          A review. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) can attack a diverse range of targets to exert antimicrobial activity, which accounts for their versatility in mediating host defense against a broad range of pathogens. Most ROS are formed by the partial redn. in mol. oxygen. Four major ROS are recognized comprising superoxide (), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radical (•OH), and singlet oxygen (1O2), but they display very different kinetics and levels of activity. The effects of and H2O2 are less acute than those of •OH and 1O2, because the former are much less reactive and can be detoxified by endogenous antioxidants (both enzymic and nonenzymic) that are induced by oxidative stress. In contrast, no enzyme can detoxify •OH or 1O2, making them extremely toxic and acutely lethal. The present review will highlight the various methods of ROS formation and their mechanism of action. Antioxidant defenses against ROS in microbial cells and the use of ROS by antimicrobial host defense systems are covered. Antimicrobial approaches primarily utilizing ROS comprise both bactericidal antibiotics and nonpharmacol. methods such as photodynamic therapy, titanium dioxide photocatalysis, cold plasma, and medicinal honey. A brief final section covers reactive nitrogen species and related therapeutics, such as acidified nitrite and nitric oxide-releasing nanoparticles.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFOhurbF&md5=d45d50f4b36a1e277b6195987b8cfbde
        90. 90
          Galstyan, A.; Block, D.; Niemann, S.; Gruner, M. C.; Abbruzzetti, S.; Oneto, M.; Daniliuc, C. G.; Hermann, S.; Viappiani, C.; Schafers, M.; Loffler, B.; Strassert, C. A.; Faust, A. Labeling and selective inactivation of gram-positive bacteria employing bimodal photoprobes with dual readouts. Chem. - Eur. J. 2016, 22, 5243– 5252,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201504935
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          90
          Labeling and Selective Inactivation of Gram-Positive Bacteria Employing Bimodal Photoprobes with Dual Readouts
          Galstyan, Anzhela; Block, Desiree; Niemann, Silke; Gruener, Malte C.; Abbruzzetti, Stefania; Oneto, Michele; Daniliuc, Constantin G.; Hermann, Sven; Viappiani, Cristiano; Schaefers, Michael; Loeffler, Bettina; Strassert, Cristian A.; Faust, Andreas
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2016), 22 (15), 5243-5252CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Carbohydrate-conjugated silicon(IV) phthalocyanines with bimodal photoactivity were developed as probes with both fluorescent labeling and photosensitizing capabilities, and the concomitant fluorescent labeling and photoinduced inactivation of Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. models was explored. The maltohexaose-conjugated photoprobe provides a dual readout to distinguish between both groups of pathogens, as only the Gram-pos. species was inactivated, even though both appeared labeled with near-IR luminescence. Antibiotic resistance did not hinder the phototoxic effect, as even the methicillin-resistant pathogen Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) was completely photoinactivated. Time-resolved confocal fluorescence microscopy anal. suggests that the photoprobe sticks onto the outer rim of the microorganisms, explaining the resistance of Gram-neg. species on the basis of their membrane constitution. The mannose-conjugated photoprobe yields a different readout because it is able to label and to inactivate only the Gram-pos. strain.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XjtlOitrY%253D&md5=0fb4448a4f641d6a17ee053b7ca9d9ee
        91. 91
          Cook, S. L.; Bull, S. P.; Methven, L.; Parker, J. K.; Khutoryanskiy, V. V. Mucoadhesion: A food perspective. Food Hydrocolloids 2017, 72, 281– 296,  DOI: 10.1016/j.foodhyd.2017.05.043
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          91
          Mucoadhesion: A food perspective
          Cook, Sarah L.; Bull, Stephanie P.; Methven, Lisa; Parker, Jane K.; Khutoryanskiy, Vitaliy V.
          Food Hydrocolloids (2017), 72 (), 281-296CODEN: FOHYES; ISSN:0268-005X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          The role of mucoadhesion in the perception and sensory characterization of food products is becoming more apparent. Traditionally, mucoadhesives are used to enhance drug permeability and retention at mucosal membranes in the body, by adherence to a mucosal membrane formed through various interactions between the mucoadhesive and proteins present in the mucosa. Many polysaccharides used in the food industry as thickeners, emulsifiers, stabilizers and fat replacers also have mucoadhesive properties, and are commonly used in the pharmaceutical industry in drug formulations. More recently, there has been an increasing interest in utilizing these polysaccharides as mucoadhesives to modulate the organoleptic properties of food. This review reflects on the recent developments in mucoadhesion and the limited research into the impact of mucoadhesion when designing food formulations and modifying the organoleptic properties of food. It will also outline the areas of food science that could benefit from an understanding of mucoadhesion, mainly focusing on developing an understanding of how mucoadhesion may explain results found from sensory studies involving polysaccharides. Furthermore, possible neg. impacts of mucoadhesion in foodstuff will be explored. An overview of methods for the measurement of mucoadhesion is also provided. An understanding of the mucoadhesive nature of polysaccharides may be useful to the food industry with regard to new product design.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpvVWltrk%253D&md5=77dc1862fe9b8a23fc386040b0c9257f
        92. 92
          Mbakidi, J.-P.; Herke, K.; Alvès, S.; Chaleix, V.; Granet, R.; Krausz, P.; Leroy-Lhez, S.; Ouk, T.-S.; Sol, V. Synthesis and photobiocidal properties of cationic porphyrin-grafted paper. Carbohydr. Polym. 2013, 91, 333– 338,  DOI: 10.1016/j.carbpol.2012.08.013
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          92
          Synthesis and photobiocidal properties of cationic porphyrin-grafted paper
          Mbakidi, Jean-Pierre; Herke, Klara; Alves, Sandra; Chaleix, Vincent; Granet, Robert; Krausz, Pierre; Leroy-Lhez, Stephanie; Ouk, Tan-Sothea; Sol, Vincent
          Carbohydrate Polymers (2013), 91 (1), 333-338CODEN: CAPOD8; ISSN:0144-8617. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          We report on the synthesis of cellulose paper bearing a cationic porphyrin, designed for antimicrobial applications. Tricationic porphyrin has been covalently grafted on paper, without previous chem. modification of the cellulosic support, using 1,3,5-triazine deriv. as linker. The obtained porphyrin-grafted paper was characterized by IR (ATR-FTIR), UV-visible and diffuse reflectance UV-vis (DRUV) spectroscopies to confirm the triazine linkage. Thermogravimetric anal. (TGA) was used to investigate thermal properties of grafted paper. Antimicrobial activity of porphyrin-cellulose material was tested under visible light irradn. against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. The two bacterial strains deposited on the resulting photosensitizing filter paper are efficiently killed after illumination.

        93. 93
          Yin, R.; Hamblin, M. R. Antimicrobial photosensitizers: drug discovery under the spotlight. Curr. Med. Chem. 2015, 22, 2159– 2185,  DOI: 10.2174/0929867322666150319120134
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          93
          Antimicrobial Photosensitizers: Drug Discovery Under the Spotlight
          Yin, Rui; Hamblin, Michael R.
          Current Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 22 (18), 2159-2185CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
          A review. Although photodynamic therapy (PDT) was discovered over a hundred years ago by its ability to destroy microorganisms, it has been developed mainly as a cancer therapy. In recent years, due to the inexorable rise in multi-antibiotic resistant strains of pathogens, PDT is being considered as a versatile antimicrobial approach to which microbial cells will not be able to develop resistance. The goal of this review is to survey the different classes of chem. compds. that have been tested as antimicrobial photosensitizers. Some of these compds. have been known for many years, while others have been rationally designed based on recently discovered structural principles. Tetrapyrrole-based compds. (some of which are approved as cancer therapies) that efficiently generate singlet oxygen are more efficient and broad-spectrum when they bear cationic charges, As the macrocycle structure moves from porphyrins to chlorins to phthalocyanines to bacteriochlorins the long wavelength absorption moves to the near-IR where tissue penetration is better. Four main types of natural products have been tested: curcumin, riboflavin, hypericin and psoralens. Phenothiazinium dyes, such as methylene blue and toluidine blue, have been tested, and some are clin. approved. A variety of non-phenothiazinium dyes with xanthene, triarylmethane and indocyanine structures have also been tested. New ring structures based on BODIPY, squaraine and fullerene cages can also mediate antimicrobial PDT. Finally the process of photocatalysis using titanium dioxide can also have medical uses. Designing new antimicrobial photosensitizers is likely to keep chemists engaged for a long time to come.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFWmurnO&md5=4054d0fc0dcc11d647b55784b0ec1753
        94. 94
          Celli, J. P.; Spring, B. Q.; Rizvi, I.; Evans, C. L.; Samkoe, K. S.; Verma, S.; Pogue, B. W.; Hasan, T. Imaging and photodynamic therapy: mechanisms, monitoring, and optimization. Chem. Rev. 2010, 110, 2795– 2838,  DOI: 10.1021/cr900300p
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

          Imaging and Photodynamic Therapy: Mechanisms, Monitoring, and Optimization
          Celli, Jonathan P.; Spring, Bryan Q.; Rizvi, Imran; Evans, Conor L.; Samkoe, Kimberley S.; Verma, Sarika; Pogue, Brian W.; Hasan, Tayyaba
          Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (5), 2795-2838CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
          A review.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXktVeqt7o%253D&md5=43f42186964bfb1227739a8acaf82077

          Benkovics, G.; Malanga, M.; Fenyvesi, É. The ‘Visualized’ macrocycles: chemistry and application of fluorophore tagged cyclodextrins. Int. J. Pharm. 2017, 531, 689– 700,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijpharm.2017.04.035
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          95
          The 'Visualized' macrocycles: Chemistry and application of fluorophore tagged cyclodextrins
          Benkovics, Gabor; Malanga, Milo; Fenyvesi, Eva
          International Journal of Pharmaceutics (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2017), 531 (2), 689-700CODEN: IJPHDE; ISSN:0378-5173. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Cyclodextrins are macrocyclic mols. able to form host-guest complexes due to their hydrophobic cavity. Because of their carbohydrate nature they do not absorb light in the UV-vis region (200-800 nm), but they can be converted into spectroscopically active compds. via modification with a chromophore unit. Among the chromophores, the group of fluorophores can provide high sensitivity in anal. applications (chemosensing) and low detection limit in optical imaging methods (fluorescent microscopy). Fluorophore-tagged cyclodextrins therefore combine interesting spectroscopic properties with promising supramol. features which make these conjugates widely applicable in various pharmaceutical fields. The aim of this work is to review the various types of fluorophores which have been used for cyclodextrin tagging, to discuss the synthetic strategies used for the conjugation and to summarize the pharmaceutical applications of these 'visualized' macrocycles including their use in photodynamic therapy. The recent achievements in studying how the fluorophore-appended cyclodextrin derivs. cross biol. barriers are also reviewed.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXmvVCqt7w%253D&md5=61eacad4dbd068ddbf2bc49330de9e41
        96. 96
          Sultan, A. A.; Jerjes, W.; Berg, K.; Høgset, A.; Mosse, C. A.; Hamoudi, R.; Hamdoon, Z.; Simeon, C.; Carnell, D.; Forster, M.; Hopper, C. Disulfonated tetraphenyl chlorin (TPCS2a)-induced photochemical internalisation of bleomycin in patients with solid malignancies: a phase 1, dose-escalation, first-in-man trial. Lancet Oncol. 2016, 17, 1217– 1229,  DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(16)30224-8
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          96
          Disulfonated tetraphenyl chlorin (TPCS2a)-induced photochemical internalisation of bleomycin in patients with solid malignancies: a phase 1, dose-escalation, first-in-man trial
          Sultan, Ahmed A.; Jerjes, Waseem; Berg, Kristian; Hoegset, Anders; Mosse, Charles A.; Hamoudi, Rifat; Hamdoon, Zaid; Simeon, Celia; Carnell, Dawn; Forster, Martin; Hopper, Colin
          Lancet Oncology (2016), 17 (9), 1217-1229CODEN: LOANBN; ISSN:1470-2045. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          Photochem. internalization, a novel minimally invasive treatment, has shown promising preclin. results in enhancing and site-directing the effect of anticancer drugs by illumination, which initiates localized chemotherapy release. We assessed the safety and tolerability of a newly developed photosensitizer, disulfonated tetra-Ph chlorin (TPCS2a), in mediating photochem. internalization of bleomycin in patients with advanced and recurrent solid malignancies. In this phase 1, dose-escalation, first-in-man trial, we recruited patients (aged ≥18 to <85 years) with local recurrent, advanced, or metastatic cutaneous or s.c. malignancies who were clin. assessed as eligible for bleomycin chemotherapy from a single center in the UK. Patients were given TPCS2a on day 0 by slow i.v. injection, followed by a fixed dose of 15 000 IU/m2 bleomycin by i.v. infusion on day 4. After 3 h, the surface of the target tumor was illuminated with 652 nm laser light (fixed at 60 J/cm2). The TPCS2a starting dose was 0·25 mg/kg and was then escalated in successive dose cohorts of three patients (0·5, 1·0, and 1·5 mg/kg). The primary endpoints were safety and tolerability of TPCS2a; other co-primary endpoints were dose-limiting toxicity and max. tolerated dose. The primary anal. was per protocol. This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, no. NCT00993512, and has been completed. Between Oct 3, 2009, and Jan 14, 2014, we recruited 22 patients into the trial. 12 patients completed the 3-mo follow-up period. Adverse events related to photochem. internalization were either local, resulting from the local inflammatory process, or systemic, mostly as a result of the skin-photosensitizing effect of TPCS2a. The most common grade 3 or worse adverse events were unexpected higher transient pain response (grade 3) localized to the treatment site recorded in nine patients, and respiratory failure (grade 4) noted in two patients. One dose-limiting toxicity was reported in the 1·0 mg/kg cohort (skin photosensitivity [grade 2]). Dose-limiting toxicities were reported in two of three patients at a TPCS2a dose of 1·5 mg/kg (skin photosensitivity [grade 3] and wound infection [grade 3]); thus, the max. tolerated dose of TPCS2a was 1·0 mg/kg. Administration of TPCS2a was found to be safe and tolerable by all patients. No deaths related to photochem. internalization treatment occurred. TPCS2a-mediated photochem. internalization of bleomycin is safe and tolerable. We identified TPCS2a 0·25 mg/kg as the recommended treatment dose for future trials.PCI Biotech.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1ygsrzI&md5=3a4e9a287934809afe4a1a48bd3cefc1
        97. 97
          DaCosta, M. V.; Doughan, S.; Han, Y.; Krull, U. J. Lanthanide upconversion nanoparticles and applications in bioassays and bioimaging: A review. Anal. Chim. Acta 2014, 832, 1– 33,  DOI: 10.1016/j.aca.2014.04.030
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          97
          Lanthanide upconversion nanoparticles and applications in bioassays and bioimaging: A review
          DaCosta, Matthew V.; Doughan, Samer; Han, Yi; Krull, Ulrich J.
          Analytica Chimica Acta (2014), 832 (), 1-33CODEN: ACACAM; ISSN:0003-2670. (Elsevier B.V.)
          A review. Through the process of photon upconversion, trivalent lanthanide doped nanocrystals convert long-wavelength excitation radiation in the IR or near IR region to higher energy emission radiation from UV to IR. Such materials offer potential for numerous advantages in anal. applications in comparison to mol. fluorophores and quantum dots. The use of IR radiation as an excitation source reduces autofluorescence and scattering of excitation radiation, which leads to a redn. of background in optical expts. The upconverting nanocrystals offer excellent photostability and are composed of materials that are not particularly toxic to biol. organisms. Excitation at long wavelengths also minimizes damage to biol. materials. In this review, the different mechanisms responsible for the upconversion process, and methods that are used to synthesize and decorate upconverting nanoparticles are presented to indicate how absorption and emission can be tuned. Examples of recent applications of upconverting nanoparticles in bioassays for the detection of proteins, nucleic acids, metabolites and metal ions offer indications of anal. advantages in the development of methods of anal. Examples include multi-color and multi-modal imaging, and the use of upconverting nanoparticles in theranostics.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXntlyjs7Y%253D&md5=6039c57ee299841ad0dbea38aa30b489
        98. 98
          Wang, A.; Jin, W.; Chen, E.; Zhou, J.; Zhou, L.; Wei, S. Drug delivery function of carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin modified upconversion nanoparticles for adamantine phthalocyanine and their NIR-triggered cancer treatment. Dalton Trans. 2016, 45, 3853– 3862,  DOI: 10.1039/C5DT04900H
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          98
          Drug delivery function of carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin modified upconversion nanoparticles for adamantine phthalocyanine and their NIR-triggered cancer treatment
          Wang, Ao; Jin, Weiwei; Chen, Enyi; Zhou, Jiahong; Zhou, Lin; Wei, Shaohua
          Dalton Transactions (2016), 45 (9), 3853-3862CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Near-IR (NIR) light triggered photodynamic therapy (PDT), based on upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs), has attracted great attention because of its high tissue penetration and low photodamage to living organisms. However, most UCNPs cannot be stably dispersed in aq. soln. and cannot carry photosensitive drugs directly. Besides, UCNP mediated PDT is a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) process from the UCNPs to the attached photosensitive drugs. So the drug and UCNPs must be stably connected and close enough. In this manuscript, carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin (COOH-β-CD) was used to connect UCNPs and adamantine modified phthalocyanine (Ad-ZnPc) through a self-assembly process followed by a host-guest interaction. COOH-β-CD can provide good water soly. of the system and short-distance linking between the UCNPs and Ad-ZnPc. Most importantly, the system has a strong NIR light triggered PDT activity toward cancer cells.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsVCntw%253D%253D&md5=f0b94cb5f052ab830f09e2a7d83fc489

          Aggelidou, C.; Theodossiou, T. A.; Gonçalves, A. R.; Lampropoulou, M.; Yannakopoulou, K. A versatile δ-aminolevulinic acid (ΑLA)-cyclodextrin bimodal conjugate-prodrug for PDT applications with the help of intracellular chemistry. Beilstein J. Org. Chem. 2014, 10, 2414– 2420,  DOI: 10.3762/bjoc.10.251
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          99
          A versatile δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)-cyclodextrin bimodal conjugate-prodrug for PDT applications with the help of intracellular chemistry
          Aggelidou, Chrysie; Theodossiou, Theodossis A.; Goncalves, Antonio Ricardo; Lampropoulou, Mariza; Yannakopoulou, Konstantina
          Beilstein Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 10 (), 2414-2420, 7 pp.CODEN: BJOCBH; ISSN:1860-5397. (Beilstein-Institut zur Foerderung der Chemischen Wissenschaften)
          Grafting of δ-aminolevulinic acid (1) moieties on the narrow periphery of a β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) deriv. through hydrolysable bonds was implemented, in order to generate a water-sol., mol./drug carrier with the capacity to undergo intracellular transformation into protoporphyrin IX (PpIX), an endogenous powerful photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy (PDT). The water-sol. deriv. 2 was prepd. by esterifying δ-azidolevulinic acid with heptakis(6-hydroxyethylamino-6-deoxy)-β-cyclodextrin, with an av. degree of substitution, DS = 3. Delivery of water-sol., colorless 2 to cells resulted in intense red fluorescence registered by confocal microscopy, evidently due to the engagement of the intracellular machinery towards formation of PpIX. Conjugate 2 was further complexed with a fluorescein-labeled model guest mol. which was successfully transported into the cells, thereby demonstrating the bimodal action of the deriv. The present work shows the versatility of CDs in smart applications and constitutes advancement to our previously shown PpIX-β-CD conjugation both in terms of water soly. and lack of aggregation.

          Tong, H.; Wang, Y.; Li, H.; Jin, Q.; Ji, J. Dual pH-responsive 5-aminolevulinic acid pseudopolyrotaxane prodrug micelles for enhanced photodynamic therapy. Chem. Commun. 2016, 52, 3966– 3969,  DOI: 10.1039/C6CC00450D
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

          Dual pH-responsive 5-aminolevulinic acid pseudopolyrotaxane prodrug micelles for enhanced photodynamic therapy
          Tong, Hongxin; Wang, Yin; Li, Huan; Jin, Qiao; Ji, Jian

          Novel 5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) pseudopolyrotaxane prodrug micelles with dual pH-responsive properties were prepd. by the host-guest interaction of α-cyclodextrin (α-CD) and poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG). The micelles exhibited pH dependent cellular uptake and pH-sensitive ALA release, enabling enhanced photodynamic therapy.

          Demore, D.; Kasselouri, A.; Bourdon, O.; Blais, J.; Mahuzier, G.; Prognon, P. Enhancement of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin fluorescence emission by inclusion in natural and modified cyclodextrins. Appl. Spectrosc. 1999, 53, 523– 527,  DOI: 10.1366/0003702991947063
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          101
          Enhancement of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin fluorescence emission by inclusion in natural and modified cyclodextrins
          Demore, Delphine; Kasselouri, Athena; Bourdon, Olivier; Blais, Jocelyne; Mahuzier, Georges; Prognon, Patrice
          Applied Spectroscopy (1999), 53 (5), 523-527CODEN: APSPA4; ISSN:0003-7028. (Society for Applied Spectroscopy)
          Fluorescence properties of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin (I), a sensitizer used in photodynamic therapy (PDT), were studied in the presence of the 3 native cyclodextrins (CDs) (α-, β-, and γ-CD) and 2 modified cyclodextrins [heptakis(2,6-di-O-methyl)- (II) and -(2-O-hydroxypropyl)-β-CD (III)]. The CDs studied form inclusion complexes with I, leading to a large enhancement (≤300 times) of I fluorescence intensity, depending on the CD used. Stoichiometry and assocn. consts. were detd. on the basis of the variation of fluorescence intensity. A 1:2 stoichiometry was found for I complexes with γ-CD, II and III. Assocn. consts. as high as K = 9.5 × 108 M-2 for I-II and K = 2.7 × 109 M-2 for I-III complexes were obsd., whereas a lower value (K = 2.4 × 104 M-2) was found for I-γ-CD. Because of the highest fluorescence enhancement (a factor of ∼300) obsd. with II, this compd. would be the most suitable to improve I detection in further pharmacokinetics and biodistribution studies.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXjtlKgtr4%253D&md5=343eaa5ae49edd013509db3a57883eb8
        102. 102
          Desroches, M.-C.; Kasselouri, A.; Bourdon, O.; Chaminade, P.; Blais, J.; Prognon, P. A direct sensitized fluorimetric determination of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin [m-THPC (Foscan)®] in human plasma using a cyclodextrin inclusion complex. Analyst 2001, 126, 923– 927,  DOI: 10.1039/b100808k
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          102
          A direct sensitized fluorimetric determination of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin [m-THPC (Foscan)] in human plasma using a cyclodextrin inclusion complex
          Desroches, Marie-Catherine; Kasselouri, Athena; Chaminade, Pierre; Prognon, Patrice; Bourdon, Olivier; Blais, Jocelyne
          Analyst (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2001), 126 (6), 923-927CODEN: ANALAO; ISSN:0003-2654. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          The 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin (m-THPC) (Foscan) is a photosensitizer used in the photodynamic therapy (PDT) of cancers which is currently under clin. trial. The formation of a m-THPC inclusion complex with dimethyl-β-cyclodextrin (Me-β-CD) in soln. was demonstrated from CD expts. A 1:2 complex stoichiometry was found and an inclusion const. β2 = 2.8(±0.4) × 1010 M-2 was detd. The formation of such a complex was shown to enhance the m-THPC fluorescence intensity. It could be exploited to improve the sensitivity of the direct m-THPC detection in human plasma. Optimization of the operating conditions shows that the best results were obtained by the addn. of 100 μL of a concd. Me-β-CD soln. (3.2 × 10-2 M) to 1 mL plasma samples. Compared to the std. conditions, a 90% increase in sensitivity was obtained. The proposed anal. method which showed a linear response function [0-300 ng mL-1 (440 pM)] and a low limit of detection [1.5 ng mL-1 (2 pM) (S/N = 3)] appears, esp. due to the absence of metab., a simple and specific method suitable for pharmacokinetics studies in patients.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjvF2nurk%253D&md5=2956917112aca64aa19cca639f889668
        103. 103
          Guo, Y.-J.; Zhang, P.; Chao, J.-B.; Shuang, S.-M.; Dong, C. Study on the supramolecular system of 5-(p-hydroxyphenyl)-10,15,20-tris-(4-chlorophenyl)porphyrin with cyclodextrins and its analytical characteristics. Spectrochim. Acta, Part A 2008, 71A, 946– 950,  DOI: 10.1016/j.saa.2008.02.018
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          103
          Study on the supramolecular system of 5-(p-hydroxyphenyl)-10,15,20-tris-(4-chlorophenyl)porphyrin with cyclodextrins and its analytical characteristics
          Guo, Yu-Jing; Zhang, Pu; Chao, Jian-Bin; Shuang, Shao-Min; Dong, Chuan
          Spectrochimica Acta, Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy (2008), 71A (3), 946-950CODEN: SAMCAS; ISSN:1386-1425. (Elsevier B.V.)
          The supramol. systems of 5-(p-hydroxyphenyl)-10,15,20-tris-(4-chlorophenyl)porphyrin (p-HTClPP) with β-cyclodextrin (β-CD), heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-CD (TM-β-CD), carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin (CM-β-CD) and sulfurbutylether-β-CD (SBE-β-CD) were studied by absorption, fluorescence and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The formation of inclusion complexes was confirmed on the base of changes of spectroscopy properties. The double reciprocal method was used to det. the stoichiometry and the inclusion consts. of p-HTClPP with the four cyclodextrins (CDs). P-HTClPP can form 1:1 inclusion complexes with the four CDs. Compared with parent native β-CD, the inclusion abilities of modified β-CDs with p-HTClPP are stronger. The hydrophobic effect plays an important role in the inclusion procedure. The mechanism of inclusion interaction was examd. by 1H NMR technique. During the study of p-HTClPP-TM-β-CD supramol. complex, an efficient enhancement of fluorescence intensity was obsd. Based on this phenomenon, fluorometric method for the detn. of p-HTClPP was developed. The relation between fluorescence intensity and the concn. of p-HTClPP is linear from 1.0 × 10-9 to 7.0 × 10-6 mol/L-1. The limit of detection is 8.3 × 10-10 mol/L-1 and the relative std. deviation is 1.3% (n = 8). This research will provide useful information for further application of p-HTClPP.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXht1KntrzM&md5=8e323952126fedee6f90de976ad5a009
        104. 104
          Semeraro, P.; Chimienti, G.; Altamura, E.; Fini, P.; Rizzi, V.; Cosma, P. Chlorophyll a in cyclodextrin supramolecular complexes as a natural photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy (PDT) applications. Mater. Sci. Eng., C 2018, 85, 47– 56,  DOI: 10.1016/j.msec.2017.12.012
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          104
          Chlorophyll a in cyclodextrin supramolecular complexes as a natural photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy (PDT) applications
          Semeraro, Paola; Chimienti, Guglielmina; Altamura, Emiliano; Fini, Paola; Rizzi, Vito; Cosma, Pinalysa
          Materials Science & Engineering, C: Materials for Biological Applications (2018), 85 (), 47-56CODEN: MSCEEE; ISSN:0928-4931. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Chlorophyll a (Chl a), an amphipathic porphyrin, was employed as natural photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy applications. Due to its lacking soly. in water and high tendency to aggregate, Chl a was included into different modified cyclodextrins (CDs) to form stable water-sol. supramol. complexes. To achieve this aim, 2-Hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (2-HP-β-CD), 2-Hydroxypropyl-γ-cyclodextrin (2-HP-γ-CD), Heptakis(2,6-di-o-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (DIMEB) and Heptakis(2,3,6-tri-o-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TRIMEB) were used. The chem. phys. properties of Chl a/CD complexes in cellular medium were studied by means of UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy. Results demonstrated the good aptitude of 2-HP-γ-CD, and more particularly of 2-HP-β-CD, to solubilize the Chl a in cell culture medium in monomeric and photoactive form. Then, Chl a/2-HP-β-CD and Chl a/2-HP-γ-CD complexes were evaluated in vitro on human colorectal adenocarcinoma HT-29 cell line, and cytotoxicity and intracellular localization were resp. assessed. Further tests, such as phototoxicity, ROS generation, intracellular localization and mechanism of cell death were then focused exclusively on Chl a/2-HP-β-CD system. This complex exhibited no dark toxicity and a high phototoxicity toward HT-29 cells inducing cell death via necrotic mechanism. Therefore, it is possible to affirm that Chl a/2-HP-β-CD supramol. complex could be a promising and potential formulation for applications in photodynamic therapy.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXitVejs7fL&md5=b57ba41431f9ab7d7d3c77f90fe9887d
        105. 105
          Dentuto, P. L.; Catucci, L.; Cosma, P.; Fini, P.; Agostiano, A.; Hackbarth, S.; Rancan, F.; Roeder, B. Cyclodextrin/chlorophyll α complexes as supramolecular photosensitizers. Bioelectrochemistry 2007, 70, 39– 43,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioelechem.2006.03.026
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          105
          Cyclodextrin/chlorophyll a complexes as supramolecular photosensitizers
          Dentuto, P. L.; Catucci, L.; Cosma, P.; Fini, P.; Agostiano, A.; Hackbarth, S.; Rancan, F.; Roeder, B.
          Bioelectrochemistry (2007), 70 (1), 39-43CODEN: BIOEFK; ISSN:1567-5394. (Elsevier B.V.)
          The interactions between chlorophyll a, and three cyclodextrins, hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin and hydroxypropyl-γ-cyclodextrin, were studied in aq. solns. by means of absorption, emission and CD spectroscopy. Nanosecond laser flash photolysis and steady-state singlet oxygen generation expts. were performed to clarify the photoactivity of chlorophyll a in these systems. Moreover the photosensitizing activity of these complexes towards human leukemia T-lymphocytes (Jurkat cells) was tested and compared with that of the free sensitizer, chlorophyll a. The results obtained indicate that each cyclodextrin is able to carry the pigment in monomeric form inside of cells producing singlet oxygen.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhvVShuw%253D%253D&md5=acfa050eab1cc85930e0ac2dcca69696
        106. 106
          Paul, S.; Heng, P. W. S.; Chan, L. W. pH-dependent complexation of hydroxypropyl-beta-cyclodextrin with chlorin e6: effect on solubility and aggregation in relation to photodynamic efficacy. J. Pharm. Pharmacol. 2016, 68, 439– 449,  DOI: 10.1111/jphp.12535
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          106
          pH-dependent complexation of hydroxypropyl-beta-cyclodextrin with chlorin e6: effect on solubility and aggregation in relation to photodynamic efficacy
          Paul, Shubhajit; Heng, Paul Wan Sia; Chan, Lai Wah
          Journal of Pharmacy and Pharmacology (2016), 68 (4), 439-449CODEN: JPPMAB; ISSN:0022-3573. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
          Objectives : The activity of chlorin e6 (Ce6) in photodynamic therapy of cancers is significantly reduced by its propensity to form aggregates. It was postulated that disaggregation of Ce6 could be achieved with the use of hydroxypropyl-beta-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD) through soly. enhancement. Methods : An initial phase soly. study of Ce6 was conducted with various concns. of HP-β-CD at three different pH conditions, i.e. pH 3, pH 5 and pH 7. Soly.-induced disaggregation of Ce6 was illustrated by fluorescence spectroscopy and singlet oxygen generation studies. Interaction between Ce6 and HP-β-CD was further demonstrated by solid-state characterization techniques. Inclusion complex formulations were tested for improved efficacy on squamous cancer cell lines. Key findings : Increase in Ce6 soly. was obsd., esp. at pH 7, indicating the formation of inclusion complex between Ce6 and HP-β-CD. This resulted in disaggregation of Ce6 aggregates illustrated by fluorescence spectroscopy. The mode of binding was predominated by H-bonding supported by temp.-dependent binding studies and mol. simulation work. The inclusion complex demonstrated improved photodynamic efficacy through enhanced singlet oxygen generation and phototoxicity on human oral squamous carcinoma cells. Conclusions : pH-dependent complexation between Ce6- and HP-β-CD-induced disaggregation of Ce6 aggregates and the resultant formulations facilitated improved PDT efficacy on tested cancer cell lines.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xjs1Gnurc%253D&md5=e5602e18158a22abda88de44f0e0c8dd
        107. 107
          Morgan, W.; Smith, A.; Koskelo, P. The Interaction of human serum albumin and hemopexin with porphyrins. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Protein Struct. 1980, 624, 271– 285,  DOI: 10.1016/0005-2795(80)90246-9
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          107
          The interaction of human serum albumin and hemopexin with porphyrins
          Morgan, William T.; Smith, Ann; Koskelo, Pentti
          Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Protein Structure (1980), 624 (1), 271-85CODEN: BBPTBH; ISSN:0005-2795.
          The interactions of the porphyrin-binding proteins of human serum, albumin and hemopexin, with coproporphyrin I (I) and III (II), uroporphyrin I (III), protoporphyrin IX (IV), and Zn-protoporphyrin IX (V) were examd. quant. by equil. dialysis and fluorescence. Albumin bound the porphyrins with a high affinity with the dissocn. const. (Kd) in the micromolar range, with the exception of III which was only weakly bound (Kd of the order of 100 μM). IV and V were more strongly bound than I and II, suggesting common binding sites. Human hemopexin formed complexes with I and II (Kd near 0.5 μM), with IV (Kd near 2 μM), and with V (Kd near 0.5 μM). All porphyrins were bound with an apparent stoichiometry of 1:1, except V, 2 mol of which appeared to be bound/mol hemopexin. As with albumin, only a weak interaction with III was evident (Kd near 50 μM). Formation of the heme-hemopexin complex almost completely abolished subsequent interaction with coproporphyrin, consistent with heme and porphyrins sharing the same primary binding site on hemopexin. Several types of competition expt. were conducted to test directly the relative affinities of the 2 proteins for these porphyrins. Under these conditions, albumin clearly had a higher affinity than hemopexin for both IV and V. Hemopexin was able to compete effectively with albumin for I and II only at low molar ratios of the 2 proteins and appeared unlikely to bind a significant portion of these porphyrins at the molar ratios (approx. 1:40) of hemopexin and albumin found in human serum. Further evidence for species differences in the heme binding site of hemopexin was obtained from fluorescence measurements on the human and rabbit proteins. Human hemopexin displayed a higher apparent stoichiometry of V binding (1.9:1) than rabbit hemopexin (1.3:1), with V-human hemopexin exhibiting a slightly higher relative fluorescence at 595 nm. IV bound to human hemopexin exhibited red-shifted excitation (410 vs. 407 nm) and emission (634 vs. 627 nm) max. compared with rabbit hemopexin. I produced little quenching of human protein compared with that of rabbit protein.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3cXlsVGjsrk%253D&md5=aa49ed3e38391b95024b8beea4a3d592
        108. 108
          Yankovsky, I.; Bastien, E.; Yakavets, I.; Khludeyev, I.; Lassalle, H.-P.; Gräfe, S.; Bezdetnaya, L.; Zorin, V. Inclusion complexation with β-cyclodextrin derivatives alters photodynamic activity and biodistribution of meta-tetra(hydroxyphenyl)chlorin. Eur. J. Pharm. Sci. 2016, 91, 172– 182,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejps.2016.06.012
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          108
          Inclusion complexation with β-cyclodextrin derivatives alters photodynamic activity and biodistribution of meta-tetra(hydroxyphenyl)chlorin
          Yankovsky, Igor; Bastien, Estelle; Yakavets, Ilya; Khludeyev, Ivan; Lassalle, Henri-Pierre; Grafe, Susanna; Bezdetnaya, Lina; Zorin, Vladimir
          European Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (2016), 91 (), 172-182CODEN: EPSCED; ISSN:0928-0987. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Application of meta-tetra(hydroxyphenyl)chorin (mTHPC) one of the most effective photosensitizer (PS) in photodynamic therapy of solid tumors encounters several complications resulting from its insoly. in aq. medium. To improve its soly. and pharmacokinetic properties, two modified β-cyclodextrins (β-CDs) methyl-β-cyclodextrin (M-β-CD) and 2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (Hp-β-CD) were proposed. The aim of this work was to evaluate the effect of β-CDs on mTHPC behavior at various stages of its distribution in vitro and in vivo. For this purpose, we have studied the influence of the β-CDs on mTHPC binding to the serum proteins, its accumulation, distribution and photodynamic efficiency in HT29 cells. In addn., the processes of mTHPC biodistribution in HT29 tumor bearing mice after i.v. injection of PS alone or with the β-CDs were compared. Interaction of mTHPC with studied β-CDs leads to the formation of inclusion complexes that completely abolishes its aggregation after introduction into serum. It was demonstrated that the β-CDs have a concn.-dependent effect on the process of mTHPC distribution in blood serum. At high concns., β-CDs can form inclusion complexes with mTHPC in the blood that can have a significant impact on PS distribution out of the vascular system in solid tissues. Besides, the β-CDs increase diffusion movement of mTHPC mols. that can significantly accelerate the delivery of PS to the targets cells and tissues. In vivo study confirms the fact that the use of β-CDs allows to modify mTHPC distribution processes in tumor bearing animals that is reflected in the decreased level of PS accumulation in skin and muscles, as well as in the increased PS accumulation in tumor. Further studies are underway to verify the optimal protocols of mTHPC/β-CD formulation for photodynamic therapy.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFOlt7fI&md5=478d98e74451ffe77d3a7367c07cda45
        109. 109
          Yakavets, I.; Yankovsky, I.; Bezdetnaya, L.; Zorin, V. Soret band shape indicates mTHPC distribution between bcyclodextrins and serum proteins. Dyes Pigm. 2017, 137, 299– 306,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2016.11.007
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          109
          Soret band shape indicates mTHPC distribution between β-cyclodextrins and serum proteins
          Yakavets, Ilya; Yankovsky, Igor; Bezdetnaya, Lina; Zorin, Vladimir
          Dyes and Pigments (2017), 137 (), 299-306CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          Fluorescence and absorbance characteristics of 5,10,15,20-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin (mTHPC) in several org. solns. and in complexes with various biol. structures have been analyzed. A comparison of data showed that the most variable mTHPC spectral characteristic is the Soret band shape. The ratio of two Soret band peaks are strongly dependent on the kind of biol. structure bound with the pigment mol. It has been suggested, that the obsd. variations of Soret band shape are assocd. with conformational changes of mTHPC mol., caused by the forced rotation of the aryl-substitutes. On the basis of Soret band shape variations, the spectral technique for noninvasive monitoring of mTHPC release from inclusion complex with β-cyclodextrin carriers in blood serum was developed.

          Yakavets, I.; Lassalle, H.-P.; Scheglmann, D.; Wiehe, A.; Zorin, V.; Bezdetnaya, L. Temoporfin-in-cyclodextrin-in-liposome-a new approach for anticancer drug delivery: the optimization of composition. Nanomaterials 2018, 8, 847,  DOI: 10.3390/nano8100847

          110
          Temoporfin-in-cyclodextrin-in-liposome-A new approach for anticancer drug delivery: the optimization of composition
          Yakavets, Ilya; Lassalle, Henri-Pierre; Scheglmann, Dietrich; Wiehe, Arno; Zorin, Vladimir; Bezdetnaya, Lina
          Nanomaterials (2018), 8 (10), 847/1-847/15CODEN: NANOKO; ISSN:2079-4991. (MDPI AG)
          The main goal of this study was to use hybrid delivery system for effective transportation of temoporfin (meta-tetrakis(3-hydroxyphenyl)chlorin, mTHPC) to target tissue. We suggested to couple two independent delivery systems (liposomes and inclusion complexes) to achieve drug-in-cyclodextrin-in-liposome (DCL) nanoconstructs. We further optimized the compn. of DCLs, aiming to alter in a more favorable way a distribution of temoporfin in tumor tissue. We have prepd. DCLs with different compns. varying the concn. of mTHPC and the type of β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) derivs. (Hydroxypropyl-, Methyl- and Trimethyl-β-CD). DCLs were prepd. by thin-hydration technique and mTHPC/β-CD complexes were added at hydration step. The size was about 135 nm with the surface charge of (-38 mV). We have demonstrated that DCLs are stable and almost all mTHPC is bound to β-CDs in the inner aq. liposome core. Among all tested DCLs, trimethyl-β-CD-based DCL demonstrated a homogenous accumulation of mTHPC across tumor spheroid vol., thus supposing optimal mTHPC distribution.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFSjs7zO&md5=c44a0c6e51567d9daffea51adc5f243c
        111. 111
          Ikeda, A.; Satake, S.; Mae, T.; Ueda, M.; Sugikawa, K.; Shigeto, H.; Funabashi, H.; Kuroda, A. Photodynamic activities of porphyrin derivative–cyclodextrin complexes by photoirradiation. ACS Med. Chem. Lett. 2017, 8, 555– 559,  DOI: 10.1021/acsmedchemlett.7b00098
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          111
          Photodynamic Activities of Porphyrin Derivative-Cyclodextrin Complexes by Photoirradiation
          Ikeda, Atsushi; Satake, Shuhei; Mae, Tomoya; Ueda, Masafumi; Sugikawa, Kouta; Shigeto, Hajime; Funabashi, Hisakage; Kuroda, Akio
          ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2017), 8 (5), 555-559CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
          Water-sol. cyclodextrin (CyD) complexed with porphyrin derivs. with different substituents in the meso-positions showed different photodynamic activities toward cancer cells under illumination at wavelengths over 600 nm, the most suitable wavelengths for photodynamic therapy (PDT). In particular, aniline- and phenol-substituted derivs. had high photodynamic activity because of the efficient intracellular uptake of the complexes by tumor cells. These complexes showed greater photodynamic activity than photofrin, currently the main drug in clin. use as a photosensitizer. These results represent a significant step toward the optimization of porphyrin derivs. as photosensitizers.

          Satake, S.; Shinmori, H.; Kawabata, S.; Sugikawa, K.; Funabashi, H.; Kuroda, A.; Ikeda, A. High photodynamic activities of water-soluble inclusion complexes of 5,15-diazaporphyrins in cyclodextrin. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2019, 17, 3141– 3149,  DOI: 10.1039/C9OB00101H
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          112
          High photodynamic activities of water-soluble inclusion complexes of 5,15-diazaporphyrins in cyclodextrin
          Satake, Shuhei; Shinmori, Hideyuki; Kawabata, Shigeki; Sugikawa, Kouta; Funabashi, Hisakage; Kuroda, Akio; Ikeda, Atsushi
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2019), 17 (12), 3141-3149CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Water-sol. inclusion complexes of 5,15-diazaporphyrin derivs. in the cavities of two trimethyl-β-cyclodextrins (TMe-β-CDxs) were synthesized. In the 2 : 1 complexes, two aryl groups of the diazaporphyrins protruded from the upper rims of two TMe-β-CDxs. The complexes displayed high photodynamic activity under photoirradn. at wavelengths longer than 620 nm. Although the substituents on the two aryl groups protruding from TMe-β-CDx barely affected intracellular uptake by HeLa cells, the cellular uptake of these complexes was as high as that of a TMe-β-CDx-tetra(4-hydroxyphenyl)porphyrin complex. Furthermore, the diazaporphyrins in the complexes with TMe-β-CDxs were able to generate high levels of singlet oxygen because of their strong absorption of light with wavelengths greater than 620 nm.

        113. 113
          Kitagishi, H.; Hatada, S.; Itakura, T.; Maki, Y.; Maeda, Y.; Kano, K. Cellular uptake of octaarginine-conjugated tetraarylporphyrin included by per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2013, 11, 3203– 3211,  DOI: 10.1039/c3ob27248f
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          113
          Cellular uptake of octaarginine-conjugated tetraarylporphyrin included by per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin
          Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Hatada, Satoshi; Itakura, Toshiaki; Maki, Yuki; Maeda, Yasuaki; Kano, Koji
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2013), 11 (19), 3203-3211CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          This paper describes the synthesis, structural characterization and cellular uptake of a supramol. 1 : 2 inclusion complex of meso-tetraphenylporphyrin having an octaarginine peptide chain (R8-TPP) and heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TMe-β-CD). R8-TPP was synthesized by 2 approaches: (1) on-resin conjugation of the N-terminal of octaarginine with 5-(4-carboxyphenyl)-10,15,20-triphenylporphyrin, followed by cleavage from the resin, and (2) Michael addn. reaction between 5-[4-(3-maleimidopropylamido)phenyl]-10,15,20-triphenylporphyrin and cysteine-octaarginine peptide (Cys-Arg8). The R8-TPP obtained from both the approaches formed stable inclusion complexes with TMe-β-CD by which non-substituted Ph groups at the 10- and 20-positions were included to form trans-type 1 : 2 inclusion complexes. The complexation prevented the self-aggregation of R8-TPP, which resulted in the solubilization of R8-TPP in aq. media. A cellular uptake study using HeLa cells showed that R8-TPP complexed with TMe-β-CD in a serum-free medium was efficiently taken up by the cells and uniformly dispersed in the cytosol. In the serum-contg. medium, the R8-TPP-TMe-β-CD complex dissocd., and the serum protein bound R8-TPP. The R8-TPP-protein complex was localized in the endosomes of the cells. The cytosol-dispersed R8-TPP showed a higher photo-induced cytotoxicity than its endosome-trapped counterpart.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmtlCgtLc%253D&md5=404392f198efc83fb4661a5b72e695e2
        114. 114
          Kitagishi, H.; Minami, K.; Kano, K. Intracellular Delivery of Anionic meso-tetraarylporphyrin–per-o-methylated β-cyclodextrin supramolecular complexes by an oligoarginine carrier peptide. Chem. Lett. 2014, 43, 1095– 1097,  DOI: 10.1246/cl.140298
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          114
          Intracellular delivery of anionic meso-tetraarylporphyrin-per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin supramolecular complexes by an oligoarginine carrier peptide
          Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Minami, Keiko; Kano, Koji
          Chemistry Letters (2014), 43 (7), 1095-1097CODEN: CMLTAG; ISSN:0366-7022. (Chemical Society of Japan)
          A 1:2 inclusion complex composed of 5-[4-(tetraglutaminylglutaramido)phenyl]-10,15,20-tris(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin and per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin interacted electrostatically with a dodecaarginine in aq. soln. Such a ternary complex dispersed in a serum-contg. culture medium was efficiently taken up by HeLa cells. This cellular uptake was achieved owing to the interaction between the tetraglutamate chain of the porphyrin and dodecaarginine carrier peptide.

          Kitagishi, H.; Chai, F.; Negi, S.; Sugiura, Y.; Kano, K. Supramolecular intracellular delivery of an anionic porphyrin by octaarginine-conjugated per-O-methyl-β-cyclodextrin. Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 2421– 2424,  DOI: 10.1039/C4CC09042J
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          115
          Supramolecular intracellular delivery of an anionic porphyrin by octaarginine-conjugated per-O-methyl-β-cyclodextrin
          Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Chai, Fumihiko; Negi, Shigeru; Sugiura, Yukio; Kano, Koji
          Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (12), 2421-2424CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A convenient and efficient method for intracellular delivery of a water-sol. anionic porphyrin has been developed by utilizing its supramol. interaction with per-O-methyl-β-cyclodextrin bearing an octaarginine chain as a cell-penetrating peptide.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1KmsQ%253D%253D&md5=92c395880f1321258763e6a814c6013d

          Kitagishi, H.; Saito, M.; Mao, Q.; Kiriyama, A.; Negi, S.; Kano, K. Supramolecular complexation in biological media: NMR study on inclusion of an anionic tetraarylporphyrin into a per-O-methylated β-cyclodextrin cavity in serum, blood, and urine. Chem. - Asian J. 2019, 14, 3320,  DOI: 10.1002/asia.201900983

          116
          Supramolecular Complexation in Biological Media: NMR Study on Inclusion of an Anionic Tetraarylporphyrin into a Per-O-Methylated β-Cyclodextrin Cavity in Serum, Blood, and Urine
          Kitagishi, Hiroaki; Saito, Mai; Mao, Qiyue; Kiriyama, Akiko; Negi, Shigeru; Kano, Koji
          Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2019), 14 (19), 3320-3328CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          The supramol. complexation of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin (TPPS) with heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl)-β-cyclodextrin (TMCD) is highly specific in aq. media. The authors used NMR spectroscopy to reveal that this supramol. system also works even in biol. crowded media such as serum, blood, and urine. A 13C-labeled heptakis(2,3,6-tri-O-methyl-13C)-β-cyclodextrin (13C-TMCD) was synthesized and studied using one-dimensional (1D) HMQC spectroscopy in serum and blood. The 1D HMQC spectrum of 13C-TMCD showed clear signals due to the 2-, 3-, and 6-O13CH3 groups, whose chem. shifts changed upon addn. of TPPS due to quant. formation of the 13C-TMCD/TPPS = 2/1 inclusion complex in such biol. media. The 1H NMR signals of non-isotope-labeled TPPS included by 13C-TMCD were detected using the 13C-filtered ROESY technique. A pharmacokinetic study of 13C-TMCD and its complex with TPPS was carried out in mice using the 1D HMQC method. (1) 1D HMQC is an effective technique for monitoring the inclusion phenomena of 13C-labeled cyclodextrin in biol. media and (2) the intermol. interaction between 13C-TMCD and TPPS is highly selective even in contaminated media like blood, serum, and urine.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhs1Cis7zM&md5=1d0fa0342e702a0687b138665c1ad887
        117. 117
          Yu, M.; Chen, Y.; Zhang, N.; Liu, Y. Construction and transmembrane dissociation behavior of supramolecular assembly of quinolinocyclodextrin with porphyrin. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2010, 8, 4148– 4154,  DOI: 10.1039/c0ob00080a
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          117
          Construction and transmembrane dissociation behavior of supramolecular assembly of quinolinocyclodextrin with porphyrin
          Yu, Miao; Chen, Yong; Zhang, Ning; Liu, Yu
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2010), 8 (18), 4148-4154CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Through the stoichiometric 2 : 1 coordination of Zn2+ with 4-amino-N-(2-methylquinolin-8-yl)benzenesulfonamide-modified per-methyl-β-cyclodextrin (MQAS-PMCD) and the strong inclusion complexation of permethyl-β-cyclodextrin cavity with meso-tetrakis-(4-sulfonatophenyl)-porphyrin (TSPP), an environment-sensitive Zn2+/cyclodextrin/porphyrin triad supramol. assembly was constructed, and its structure was fully characterized by UV/vis spectroscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fluorescence spectrometric studies showed that this supramol. assembly was stable and barely emitted green fluorescence in water due to the energy transfer process, but gave the strong green fluorescence when changing to a hydrophobic environment due to the disruption of the assembly. Further studies on the cell staining expts. by means of fluorescence microscopy showed that this supramol. assembly was disrupted to release the MQAS-PMCD/Zn2+ and porphyrin components when interacting with the cell membrane. Subsequently, the released MQAS-PMCD/Zn2+ complex remained in the cell membrane, while the porphyrin component entered the cells. This transmembrane dissocn. property of the supramol. assembly will enable its application in the delivery of biol. and drug mols. contg. the anionic porphyrin skeleton such as β-octaphenyl-meso-tetra(4-carboxyl)-phenylporphyrin and so on.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVKrsbnN&md5=cd245b1ccaa44c3f7c36fa47b91b1c3d

          Construction of a Supramolecular Polymer by Bridged Bis(permethyl-β-cyclodextrin)s with Porphyrins and Its Highly Efficient Magnetic Resonance Imaging
          Sun, Mo; Zhang, Heng-Yi; Liu, Bo-Wen; Liu, Yu
          Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2013), 46 (11), 4268-4275CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
          A supramol. polymer is first constructed through the intermol. inclusion complexation of bridged bis(permethyl-β-cyclodextrin) (I) with MnIII-porphyrin bearing poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) side chains (MnIII-TPP) and characterized by UV/vis absorption spectroscopy, NMR, DLS, AFM, and TEM. MnIII-TPP in the supramol. polymer I·MnIII-TPP would be reduced effectively to a higher electronic spins MnII-TPP by sodium ascorbate, but free MnIII-TPP cannot be reduced in the same condition. The toxicity of the supramol. polymer in vitro and the magnetic resonance imaging effectiveness both in vitro and in vivo are estd., and the results obtained not only demonstrate the supramol. polymer to have no cellular toxicity but also show the magnetic resonance signal enhancement.

          Photodynamic effects induced by meso-tris(pentafluorophenyl)corrole and its cyclodextrin conjugates on cytoskeletal components of HeLa cells
          Barata, Joana F. B.; Zamarron, Alicia; Neves, M. Graca P. M. S.; Faustino, M. Amparo F.; Tome, Augusto C.; Cavaleiro, Jose A. S.; Roder, Beate; Juarranz, Angeles; Sanz-Rodriguez, Francisco
          European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 92 (), 135-144CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
          The aim of this work was to synthesize new corrole β-cyclodextrin conjugates βCD1 (with one β-cyclodextrin moiety) and βCD2 (with two β-cyclodextrin moieties) from 5,10,15-tris(pentafluorophenyl)corrole (TPFC) and to test in vitro the efficacy of these compds. towards tumoral HeLa cells. No dark cytotoxicity was obsd. for TPFC and βCD1 at the concn. used for PDT cell treatment, even during long incubation periods (24 h). Fluorescence microscopy showed that TPFC and βCD1 accumulate in HeLa cells at lysosomes and in the Golgi app., resp.The cell survival after the PDT treatment with visible light was dependent on light exposure level and compd. concn. βCD1 was able to penetrate efficiently in the cytoplasm of the HeLa cells. In particular, we have analyzed the photodynamic effect of the corrole derivs. on the microtubules of HeLa cells and the morphol. alterations on the mitotic spindle. TPFC and βCD1 caused photocytotoxicity in tumoral HeLa cells and induced a rapid metaphase blockage of cells that also showed clearly altered configurations of the mitotic spindle. The results showed that TPFC has the highest photosensitizing efficiency on tumoral cells.

Photophysical properties of glucoconjugated chlorins and porphyrins and their associations with cyclodextrins. J. Photochem. Photobiol., B 2005, 81, 154– 162,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jphotobiol.2005.05.013

          Photophysical properties of glucoconjugated chlorins and porphyrins and their associations with cyclodextrins
          Bautista-Sanchez, Antonia; Kasselouri, Athena; Desroches, Marie-Catherine; Blais, Jocelyne; Maillard, Philippe; Manfrim de Oliveira, Daniela; Tedesco, Antonio C.; Prognon, Patrice; Delaire, Jacques
          Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology, B: Biology (2005), 81 (3), 154-162CODEN: JPPBEG; ISSN:1011-1344. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Glucoconjugated analogs of the meta-hydroxyphenyl porphyrin (m-THPP) and meta-hydroxyphenyl chlorin (m-THPC) has been recently synthesized. The characteristics of their triplet states have been detd. with regard to their involvement in the photodynamic (PDT) efficiency. In the case of porphyrin derivs., triplet quantum yields (ΦT) were ranging from 0.42 to 0.55 and triplet lifetimes (τT) from 1 to 5 μs. High reaction rate consts. (kq) with mol. oxygen (kq: 1.2-1.6 × 109 s-1) have been found. The triplet lifetimes of chlorin derivs. were about four times higher than those of porphyrins whereas the ΦT and kq values remained quite similar. Singlet oxygen yields of glucosylated and non-glucosylated porphyrins and chlorins were not significantly different within exptl. errors (ΦΔ(1O2): 0.41-0.58). Furthermore, it has been shown that glucoconjugated photosensitizers could undergo assocns. with the methyl-β-cyclodextrin (Me-β-CD) which exhibit high triplet lifetimes and singlet oxygen yields ranging from 0.27 to 0.48.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Porphyrin-Cyclodextrin Conjugates as a Nanosystem for Versatile Drug Delivery and Multimodal Cancer Therapy

          The porphyrin-cyclodextrin conjugates were prepd. and tested for selective and effective multifunctional drug delivery and therapy. The porphyrin receptor system combines efficient binding of the selected drug to the cyclodextrin cavity and photosensitizing properties of the porphyrin moiety with high accumulation of the whole complex in cancer tissue. The combined effect of chemotherapy and photodynamic therapy is demonstrated by in vitro and in vivo studies.

          123
          Coordination conjugates of therapeutic proteins with drug carriers: A new approach for versatile advanced drug delivery
          Kejik, Zdenek; Briza, Tomas; Kralova, Jarmila; Pouckova, Pavla; Kral, Ales; Martasek, Pavel; Kral, Vladimir
          Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2011), 21 (18), 5514-5520CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
          We present here a general system for the coordination attachment of therapeutic proteins to a drug delivery system and its application in combined therapy. Proof of concept is demonstrated by the synthesis and testing of the targeted drug delivery system for cytostatics, which is based on a combination of the drug carrier Zn-porphyrin-cyclodextrin conjugates and their supramol. coordination complexes with Igs. This system can be as readily used for a variety of therapeutic and targeting proteins including PAs, MAs, lectins, and HSA. Moreover, it allows combined photodynamic therapy, cell targeted chemotherapy and immunotherapy. When tested in a mouse model with human C32 carcinoma, the therapeutic superiority of the coordination assembly nanosystem was shown in comparison with the efficacy of building blocks used for the construction of the system.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Preparation and Photodynamic Activities of Silicon(IV) Phthalocyanines Substituted with Permethylated β-Cyclodextrins
          Lau, Janet T. F.; Lo, Pui-Chi; Fong, Wing-Ping; Ng, Dennis K. P.
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2011), 17 (27), 7569-7577, S7569/1-S7569/13CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A series of silicon(IV) phthalocyanines PcSi(OXNHCH2R)2 [6a-d Pc = phthalocyaninato(2-), X = (CH2)5, (CH2)2O(CH2)2, (CH2)2, (CH2CH2O)2CH2CH2; R = O-permethylated β-cyclodextrin-6-yl] linked to two permethylated β-cyclodextrin moieties through different spacers at the axial positions have been prepd. and characterized. The effects of these spacers on the photophys. properties and in vitro photodynamic activities have also been examd. Having two bulky hydrophilic substituents, all of these compds. are sol. and essentially nonaggregated in DMF and even in aq. media. The fluorescence and singlet oxygen quantum yields in DMF are lower for the analog with the shortest sepn. between the amino group in the spacer and the phthalocyanine ring. The fluorescence quantum yield of this compd. increases in water probably due to protonation of the amino group, which inhibits the reductive quenching process. This series of compds. also exhibit photocytotoxicity toward HT29 human colon adenocarcinoma and HepG2 human hepatocarcinoma cells with IC50 values in the range of 0.04-1.32 μM. The compd. 6a [X = (CH2)5] shows the highest potency, which can be ascribed to its high cellular uptake and high efficiency in generating intracellular reactive oxygen species. This compd. also shows preferential localization in the lysosome, induces cell death mainly through apoptosis, and inhibits the growth of tumor in vivo. The results suggest that it is a promising photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXnslSlsrg%253D&md5=285c8c12543c7bc7e1c041cd3285e41b

          Unsymmetrical β-cyclodextrin-conjugated silicon(IV) phthalocyanines as highly potent photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy
          Lau, Janet T. F.; Lo, Pui-Chi; Tsang, Yee-Man; Fong, Wing-Ping; Ng, Dennis K. P.
          Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (34), 9657-9659CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A series of unsym. silicon(IV) phthalocyanines with a permethylated β-cyclodextrin unit and a sugar or a diamino moiety as the axial substituents have been prepd. These compds. are highly photocytotoxic with IC50 values as low as 21 nM, which is ca. sevenfold lower than those of the sym. bis(cyclodextrin) analog. Title compds. are highly photo-cytotoxic against HT29 human colorectal carcinoma and HepG2 human hepatocarcinoma cells as highly potent photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy (IC50 range of 21-94 nM).

          A Multifunctional Bichromophoric Nanoaggregate for Fluorescence Imaging and Simultaneous Photogeneration of RNOS and ROS
          Fraix, Aurore; Goncalves, A. Ricardo; Cardile, Venera; Graziano, Adriana C. E.; Theodossiou, Theodossis A.; Yannakopoulou, Konstantina; Sortino, Salvatore
          Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2013), 8 (11), 2634-2641CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          The authors report the design, prepn., and properties of a nanoaggregate formed in phosphate buffer soln. by a porphyrin-β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) conjugate and a nitric oxide photodonor tailored to fit the β-CD cavity. The small nanoassembly with a diam. of ∼13 nm exhibits the typical red fluorescence of the porphyrin chromophore. The empty cavity of the β-CD unit in the nanoaggregate is able to accommodate the NO photodonor, thereby forming a supramol. bichromophoric aggregate with diam. of ∼16 nm. This nanoconstruct preserves the fluorescence of the porphyrin core and is able to generate nitric oxide and singlet oxygen under illumination with visible light. The nanoassembly internalizes in melanoma cells, can be mapped therein by fluorescence microscopy, and induces a significant level of cell mortality, probably due to the combined action of reactive nitrogen oxide species (RNOS) and reactive oxygen species (ROS).
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          The role of nitric oxide in tumour progression
          Fukumura, Dai; Kashiwagi, Satoshi; Jain, Rakesh K.
          Nature Reviews Cancer (2006), 6 (7), 521-534CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
          A review. Nitric oxide (NO) and nitric oxide synthases are ubiquitous in malignant tumors and are known to exert both pro- and anti-tumor effects. We summarize our current understanding of the role of NO in tumor progression, esp. in relation to angiogenesis and vascular functions. We also discuss potential strategies for cancer treatment that modulate NO prodn. and/or its downstream signaling pathways.

          Caruso, Elisa B.; Petralia, Salvatore; Conoci, Sabrina; Giuffrida, Salvatore; Sortino, Salvatore
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (3), 480-481CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The first example of monolayer-protected metal nanoparticles able to deliver nitric oxide upon visible light stimuli is reported. These hybrid nanosystems exhibit a combination of indispensable properties for biol. applications, such as ultrasmall sizes (ca. 1 nm), water soly. and thermal stability under physiol. conditions, photoactivation with low-energy light, and photogeneration of nontoxic intermediates.

          Kirejev, V.; Gonçalves, A. R.; Aggelidou, C.; Manet, I.; Mårtensson, J.; Yannakopoulou, K.; Ericson, M. B. Photophysics and ex vivo biodistribution of β-cyclodextrin-meso-tetra(m-hydroxy-phenyl)-porphyrin conjugate for biomedical applications. Photochem. Photobiol. Sci. 2014, 13, 1185– 1191,  DOI: 10.1039/C4PP00088A
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          129
          Photophysics and ex vivo biodistribution of β-cyclodextrin-meso-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)porphyrin conjugate for biomedical applications
          Kirejev, V.; Goncalves, A. R.; Aggelidou, C.; Manet, I.; Maartensson, J.; Yannakopoulou, K.; Ericson, M. B.
          Photochemical & Photobiological Sciences (2014), 13 (8), 1185-1191CODEN: PPSHCB; ISSN:1474-905X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Low aq. soly. of porphyrin-based photosensitizers hampers their clin. use in photodynamic therapy because of complex delivery. In this study, we explore meso-tetra(m-hydroxyphenyl)-21,23H-porphyrin (mTHPP), a potent photosensitizer, covalently attached to β-cyclodextrin (CD-mTHPP) with a focus on topical delivery and cellular uptake. The photophys. properties of CD-mTHPP were examd. using steady-state fluorescence and lifetime measurements verifying increased aq. soly. Confocal and fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy on human squamous carcinoma cells (A431) evidenced a cytoplasmic uptake of CD-mTHPP in predominantly monomeric form. CD-mTHPP was also delivered to human skin ex vivo and the skin penetration was assessed using two-photon fluorescence microscopy. The results indicated that CD-mTHPP exhibits improved skin distribution compared to mTHPP alone using aq. vehicles. Thus the CD-mTHPP conjugate demonstrates improved biodistribution ex vivo compared to mTHPP and is a promising multimodal system for photodynamic therapy.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFOjtLjL&md5=622054c3288fbbd27021c52572c85c9b

          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          130
          Photochemical disruption of endocytic vesicles before delivery of drugs: A new strategy for cancer therapy
          Prasmickaite, L.; Hegset, A.; Selbo, P. K.; Engesaeter, B. O.; Hellum, M.; Berg, K.
          British Journal of Cancer (2002), 86 (4), 652-657CODEN: BJCAAI; ISSN:0007-0920. (Nature Publishing Group)
          The development of methods for specific delivery of drugs is an important issue for many cancer therapy approaches. Most of macromol. drugs are taken into the cell through endocytosis and, being unable to escape from endocytic vesicles, eventually are degraded there, which hinders their therapeutic usefulness. We have developed a method, called photochem. internalization, based on light-induced photochem. reactions, disrupting endocytic vesicles specifically within illuminated sites e.g. tumors. Here we present a new drug delivery concept based on photochem. internalization-principle - photochem. disruption of endocytic vesicles before delivery of macromols., leading to an instant endosomal release instead of detrimental stay of the mols. in endocytic vesicles. Previously we have shown that illumination applied after the treatment with macromols. substantially improved their biol. effect both in vitro and in vivo. Here we demonstrate that exposure to light before delivery of protein toxin gelonin improves gelonin effect in vitro much more than light after. However, in vitro transfection with reporter genes delivered by non-viral and adenoviral vectors is increased more than 10- and six-fold, resp., by both photochem. internalization strategies. The possible cellular mechanisms involved, and the potential of this new method for practical application of photochem. internalization concept in cancer therapy are discussed.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XislCmtL8%253D&md5=ad33118904a3ba240e2ea9dc0ec2cdbe
        131. 131
          Theodossiou, T. A.; Gonçalves, R. A.; Yannakopoulou, K.; Skarpen, E.; Berg, K. Photochemical internalization of tamoxifens transported by a “trojan-horse” nanoconjugate into breast-cancer cell lines. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54, 4885– 4889,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201500183
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          131
          Photochemical Internalization of Tamoxifens Transported by a "Trojan-Horse" Nanoconjugate into Breast-Cancer Cell Lines
          Theodossiou, Theodossis A.; Goncalves, A. Ricardo; Yannakopoulou, Konstantina; Skarpen, Ellen; Berg, Kristian
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (16), 4885-4889CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Photochem. internalization (PCI) has shown great promise as a therapeutic alternative for targeted drug delivery by light-harnessed activation. However, it has only been applicable to therapeutic macromols. or medium-sized mols. Herein we describe the use of an amphiphilic, water-sol. porphyrin-β-cyclodextrin conjugate (mTHPP-βCD) as a "Trojan horse" to facilitate the endocytosis of CD-guest tamoxifens into breast-cancer cells. Upon irradn., the porphyrin core of mTHPP-βCD expedited endosomal membrane rupture and tamoxifen release into the cytosol, as documented by confocal microscopy. The sustained complexation of mTHPP-βCD with tamoxifen was corroborated by 2D NMR spectroscopy and FRET studies. Following the application of PCI protocols with 4-hydroxytamoxifen (4-OHT), estrogen-receptor β-pos. (Erβ+, but not ERβ-) cell groups exhibited extensive cytotoxicity and/or growth suspension even at 72 h after irradn.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXkvF2mt7o%253D&md5=bfffe56db440af4e61536fd1dc160e0e
        132. 132
          Aggelidou, C.; Theodossiou, T. A.; Yannakopoulou, K. Protoporphyrin IX-β-cyclodextrin bimodal conjugate: nanosized drug transporter and potent phototoxin. Photochem. Photobiol. 2013, 89, 1011– 1019,  DOI: 10.1111/php.12127
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          132
          Protoporphyrin IX-β-Cyclodextrin Bimodal Conjugate: Nanosized Drug Transporter and Potent Phototoxin
          Aggelidou, Chrysie; Theodossiou, Theodossis A.; Yannakopoulou, Konstantina
          Photochemistry and Photobiology (2013), 89 (5), 1011-1019CODEN: PHCBAP; ISSN:0031-8655. (Wiley-Blackwell)
          Topical or systemic administration of 5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and its esters results in increased prodn. and accumulation of protoporphyrin IX (PpIX) in cancerous lesions allowing effective application of photodynamic therapy (PDT). The large concns. of exogenous ALA practically required to bypass the neg. feedback control exerted by heme on enzymic ALA synthesis and the strong dimerization propensity of ALA are shortcomings of the otherwise attractive PpIX biosynthesis. To circumvent these limitations and possibly enhance the phototoxicity of PpIX by adjuvant chemotherapy, covalent bonding of PpIX with a drug carrier, β-cyclodextrin (βCD) was implemented. The resulting PpIX + βCD product had both carboxylic termini of PpIX connected to the CD. PpIX + βCD was water sol., was found to preferentially localize in mitochondria rather than in lysosomes both in MCF7 and DU145 cell lines while its phototoxiciy was comparable to that of PpIX. Moreover, PpIX + βCD effectively solubilized the breast cancer drug tamoxifen metabolite N-desmethyltamoxifen (NDMTAM) in water. The PpIX + βCD/NDMTAM complex was readily internalized by both cell lines employed. Furthermore, the multimodal action of PpIX + βCD was demonstrated in MCF7 cells: while it retains the phototoxic profile of PpIX and its fluorescence for imaging purposes, PpIX + βCD can efficiently transport tamoxifen citrate intracellularly and confer cell death through a synergy of photo- and chemotoxicity.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtl2lt7bO&md5=5b2a4c534dd732d3c36dc42010e6a539

          Amphiphilic phthalocyanine-cyclodextrin conjugates for cancer photodynamic therapy
          Lourenco, Leandro M. O.; Pereira, Patricia M. R.; Maciel, Elisabete; Valega, Monica; Domingues, Fernando M. J.; Domingues, Maria R. M.; Neves, Maria G. P. M. S.; Cavaleiro, Jose A. S.; Fernandes, Rosa; Tome, Joao P. C.

          Three zinc phthalocyanines (Pcs) conjugated with α-, β- and γ-cyclodextrins (CDs) were prepd. and their application as photosensitizer (PS) agents was assessed by photophys., photochem. and in vitro photobiol. studies. The photoactivity of Pc-α-CD and Pc-γ-CD ensures their potential as PDT drugs against UM-UC-3 human bladder cancer cells.
